Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 4 Sep 2017\nSource: The Nation [edited]\nhttp://www.nationmultimedia.com/detail/breakingnews/30325707\n\n\nA 3-year-old girl has died of hand foot and mouth disease (HFMD) after she contracted it from a nursery in a tambon in Tak's Ban Tak district.\n\nWP, 42, said her daughter died on Sun [3 Sep 2017], 2 days after she was admitted to Somdejphrajaotaksin Maharaj Hospital. She was transferred there from a district hospital after her condition did not improve. She died of heart failure. WP said her daughter went to the nursery of the Tambon Thongfah Administrative Organisation for the 1st time this year [2017]. She said the nursery was closed for a week following the spread of HFMD there.\n\nBut after the nursery was reopened just for one day, kids contracted the disease, so the nursery was closed for another week, she said. She said her daughter fell ill with a severe headache, stomach pains, and vomiting after the nursery was closed for the 2nd time.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This report describes only briefly the symptoms experienced by the child before succumbing to heart failure.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the _Enterovirus_ genus (group), including polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nCoxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease, but other coxsackieviruses can also cause the illness. Enterovirus 71 (EV71) has also been associated with cases and outbreaks of hand, foot, and mouth disease. Less often, EV71 has been associated with severe disease, such as encephalitis. Several types of enteroviruses may be identified in outbreaks of hand, foot and mouth disease; however, most of the time, one or 2 enteroviruses are identified.\n\nSince the initial description of EV71 in 1974 [1], outbreaks of infection with this virus have occurred periodically throughout the world [2-8]. EV71 infection manifests most frequently as the childhood exanthem known as 'hand, foot, and mouth disease' (HFMD), and it is clinically indistinguishable from HFMD caused by Coxsackie virus A16 (CA16). A molecular study of the evolution of human enteroviruses has shown that EV71 and CA16 have a close genetic relationship, and, together with CA7 and CA14, they form a distinct genetic subgroup within cluster A of the _Enterovirus_ genus of the family Picornaviridae [9]. Despite the close genetic relationship between EV71 and CA16, EV71 has a propensity to cause neurological disease during acute infection [2, 3], a feature not observed in CA16 infections. Children under 4 years of age are particularly susceptible to the most severe forms of EV71-associated neurological disease, including meningitis, brain-stem and/or cerebellar encephalitis, and poliomyelitis-like paralysis. The neurological complications of EV71 infection may occasionally cause permanent paralysis or death. Several large epidemics of severe EV71 infection in young children, including numerous cases of fatal brain-stem encephalitis, have recently been reported in Southeast Asia [10-12; excerpted and edited from Peter McMinn et al. Neurological Manifestations of Enterovirus 71 Infection in Children during an Outbreak of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease in Western Australia. Clinical Infectious Diseases, Volume 32, Issue 2, 15 January 2001, Pages 236-242, https://doi.org/10.1086/318454\n(https://academic.oup.com/cid/article/32/2/236/319948/Neurological-Manifestations-of-Enterovirus-71). See paper for references cited above.]\n\nAlso see Hand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249 for information on an earlier outbreak in the country this year [2017]. - Mod.LK\n\nHealthMaps:\nThailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/151\nBan Tak, Tak, Thailand: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/63089]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE (08): THAILAND (BAN TAK)\n**********************************************************\n \n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the _Enterovirus_ genus (group), including polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses. \n\nAlso see Hand, foot & mouth disease update (06): Thailand 20170701.5144249 for information on an earlier outbreak in the country this year [2017]. http://www.nationmultimedia.com/detail/breakingnews/30325707\n\n\nA 3-year-old girl has died of hand foot and mouth disease (HFMD) after she contracted it from a nursery in a tambon in Tak's Ban Tak district. Several types of enteroviruses may be identified in outbreaks of hand, foot and mouth disease; however, most of the time, one or 2 enteroviruses are identified. A total of 86.49 percent of the cases are reported in Bangkok followed by provinces in upper central region and upper southern region.\n\nHowever, Dr Jetsads Chokedamrongsook, director-general of Diseases Control Department, noted that the incidence of hand-foot-mouth disease was abnormally high in the past week [week of 18-24 Jun 2017] compared to the same period during the past 5 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[While the subtype of Coxsackie A virus is not stated in the report, Coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16; Picornaviridae) is the enterovirus type most frequently associated with hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) in children. It is a common infection in children 1 - 5-years-old during the hot and humid season across East and South-East Asia. Severe disease and complications are mainly associated with EV71 as compared with CV-A16. Transmission of HFMD is increased in crowded and closed environments, including kindergartens and child daycare centers, where infectious droplets can easily spread via sharing of objects or surfaces (fomites).\n\nA time-resolved phylogenetic analysis conducted in Europe (France) together with HFMD surveillance data indicated that CV-A16 persistence is sustained by continuing virus migration at different geographic scales, from community transmission [as likely is the case in Thailand] to virus transportation between distant countries (J Virol. 2017 Jun 28. pii: JVI.00630-17. doi: 10.1128/JVI.00630-17).\n\nThailand health officials had issued an advisory [in February 2017] after reporting increased numbers of hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD), mostly in children under the age of 5.\n\nSee ProMED-mail Hand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK) 20170623.5125187 and Hand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744 for a discussion of HFMD in Thailand.\n\nMaps of Thailand may be found at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_Thailand and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/151. - Mod.LK\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/151.]", "summary": "\n\nBetween 40 000 -- 76 000 people are infected with hand-foot-mouth disease each year during the past 5 years and 2 -- 3 people die from the disease annually. \n\nSee ProMED-mail Hand, foot, & mouth disease update (05): Thailand (SK) 20170623.5125187 and Hand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744 for a discussion of HFMD in Thailand. It is also confused to the unrelated foot and mouth disease, which infects animals.\n\nDr Beck, who is Ballarat Health Services Base Hospital emergency department deputy director, said part of the challenge was children were often not particularly sick, more in discomfort, and it was best to see a general practitioner for treatment.\n\n'Because there is no immunization schedule for hand, foot and mouth, this is one of the few remaining ones that tends to cause outbreaks,' Dr Beck said.\n\n'One of the unusual things is that because the rash forms early in the virus, and it's very specific where it forms, naming it hand, foot and mouth disease helps doctors remember and quickly identify it, rather than using the medical term.'\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease tends to spread among children aged under 5.\n\nThere is no set quarantine period for affected children, or their families, but Dr Beck said like other viral diseases, children should be kept home until blisters have dried.\n\nThe lesions are predominantly found on the soles of feet, in palms and inside the mouth. Fluid in the blisters is infectious, as is other bodily fluids.\n\nMost incidents of the disease are in summer and autumn, according to the Victorian Health Department, with an incubation period of 3 to 7 days. Symptoms can persist for up to 10 days.\n\nTips to prevent spreading hand, foot and mouth disease\n\n- exclusion from school/child care until all blisters have dried\n- covering lesions on hands and feet, if possible, and allowing them to dry naturally\n- avoiding piercing lesions, as the fluid within the blisters is infectious\n- good hand washing and cleaning and disposal of soiled articles\n- avoiding close contact or sharing eating and drinking utensils\n\n[Byline: Melanie Whelan]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[There are no case numbers in this report, but it suggests a small outbreak of the disease.\n\nHFMD is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. However, it can sometimes occur in older children and adults. It usually starts with a fever, reduced appetite, sore throat, and a feeling of being unwell (malaise). One or 2 days after the fever starts, painful sores can develop in the mouth, often in the back of the mouth, as small red spots that blister and can become ulcers. A skin rash with red spots, and sometimes with blisters, may also develop over 1 or 2 days on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet; it may also appear on the knees, elbows, buttocks or genital area. Dehydration may occur because blisters in the mouth create pain with swallowing. Some people, especially adults, may show no symptoms at all, but they can still pass the virus to others. (Excerpted from CDC)\n\nA map of Victoria, Australia may be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/288. - Mod.LK\n\n\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4057.]", "summary": "\n\nTips to prevent spreading hand, foot and mouth disease\n\n- exclusion from school/child care until all blisters have dried\n- covering lesions on hands and feet, if possible, and allowing them to dry naturally\n- avoiding piercing lesions, as the fluid within the blisters is infectious\n- good hand washing and cleaning and disposal of soiled articles\n- avoiding close contact or sharing eating and drinking utensils A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'One of the unusual things is that because the rash forms early in the virus, and it's very specific where it forms, naming it hand, foot and mouth disease helps doctors remember and quickly identify it, rather than using the medical term.' KITTS AND NEVIS), WHO (WESTERN PACIFIC REGION), USA (MIDWEST)\n**********************************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Caribbean (St. Kitts and Nevis)\n[2] WHO: Western Pacific Region Situation update Number 524\n[3] USA (Midwest)\n\n******\n[1] Caribbean (St. Kitts and Nevis)\nDate: Wed 1 Nov 2017\nSource: 98.9 WINN FM [edited]\nhttp://www.winnfm.com/news/local/24161-raise-in-hand-foot-and-mouth-disease-reports-prompts-release-by-health-officials\n\n\nIn the past weeks health officials have become concerned over the rise in the number of reported cases of hand-foot-mouth Disease (HFMD).\n\nThe disease typically affects children under the age of 5 years; however adults and older children can be affected. The cause of the disease is attributed to the Coxsackie virus and the early symptoms include sore throat and fever that can later develop painful, blister-like lesions on the tongue, gums, and inside of the cheeks and blister can also develop on the palms of hands, soles of feet, knees, elbows, buttocks, or genital areas.\n\nMinistry of Health officials are asking the general public to take the following precautions:\n\nIf diagnosed remain at home and isolated until the fever, mouth sores and blisters have resolved.\n\nMake sure children wash hands after wiping the face and mouth, and before and after using the toilet.\n\nAdults are reminded to wash their hands thoroughly before and after using the toilet or changing a diaper, and before preparing food and eating.\n\nDisinfect all common areas with soap and water as well as bleach.\n\nAnd avoid kissing, hugging, or sharing eating utensils or cups with someone who has HFMD.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED that shows the Caribbean region where St. Kitts and Nevis are located can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31]\n\n******\n[2] WHO: Western Pacific Region Situation Update Number 524\nDate: Tue 24 Oct 2017\nSource: WHO Western Pacific region [edited]\nhttp://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/hfmd_biweekly_report_20171024.pdf?ua=1\n\n\nSurveillance summary in the Western Pacific Region This surveillance summary includes information from countries and areas where transmission of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) occurs and case counts are routinely reported.\n\nCountries in the temperate zone\n-------------------------------\nChina. Between one and 30 Sep 2017, a total of 218 880 cases of HFMD including 4 deaths were reported in China. The number of HFMD cases followed the same seasonal patterns in the past 5 years (2012 to 2016).\n\nJapan. The number of HFMD cases reported in week 41 of 2017 was 5889. As of [Wed 18 Oct 2017], there have been 316 683 HFMD cases reported in 2017, and this follows seasonal trends of the same period observed between 2010 and 2016.\n\nRepublic of Korea. In week 41 of 2017, the number of HFMD cases per 1000 consultations was 3.2 which were lower than the previous week (5.7 per 1000 consultations). This follows seasonal trends of the same period observed between 2013 and 2016.\n\nCountries/regions in the tropical zone\n--------------------------------------\nHong Kong SAR, China. The number of HFMD cases requiring hospitalisation reported from sentinel sites was 34 in week 41 of 2017. The was surge of HFMD case started in week 40 where 38 cases was reported compared to only 16 cases in week 39. This is higher than the number of hospitalisations at sentinel sites for the same week in previous years since 2012.\n\nMacao SAR, China. As of week 41 in 2017, a total of 2617 HFMD cases were reported in Macao SAR. There were 44 cases of HFMD reported in that week, which was 29 percent lower than the number of cases reported in the previous week (62 cases in week 40 of 2017). The seasonal peak was observed in June this year [2017], later than seasonal peaks in previous years.\n\nSingapore. In week 41 of 2017, there were 721 cases of HFMD reported. The current number of reported HFMD cases is comparable to previous years.\n\nViet Nam. The number of reported HFMD cases admitted to hospital was 1833 in week 41, which was a 13.3 percent decrease from 2076 cases in the previous week. No deaths were reported. The cumulative number of admitted cases as of 15 October 2017 was 38 814 in 63 provinces, an increase of 16.6 percent compared to the same period of 2016. So far this year [2017], no deaths have been reported.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See URL for figures year by year beginning 2012.]\n\n******\n[3] USA (Midwest)\nDate: Mon 16 Oct 2017 11:18AM\nSource: AOL [edited]\nhttps://www.aol.com/article/news/2017/10/16/hand-foot-and-mouth-disease-gaining-momentum-in-the-midwest/23244816/\n\n\nA highly contagious and painful disease has reared its ugly head in the US and shows no signs of slowing down.\n\nStates have reported an uptick in hand-foot-and mouth disease (HFMD) cases in the Midwest. The disease, which has so far gained momentum in Kansas and parts of Missouri, can cause those infected to develop painful blisters on their hands, feet and in and around their mouths.\n\nHFMD is caused is usually caused by the coxsackievirus A16 and enterovirus 71, but you may hear your doctor simply refer to it as the coxsackie virus.\n\nThough anyone can contract the disease, it's most commonly found in children under the age of 10 and can spread when a person makes skin-to-skin contact with a blister or inhales droplets from an infected person's breath.\n\nEarly symptoms of the disease may include a sore throat and fever in addition to painful blisters that can look similar to cold sores and often will appear on the inside of an infected person's mouth or around the lips.\n\nA rash can also develop on the palm of the person's hands and soles of their feet around day one or 2 after the 1st symptoms appear.\n\nHowever, remembering to wash your hands can greatly reduce your risk of contracting HFMD.\n\n[Byline: Aris Folley]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand-foot-mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the Enterovirus genus, including polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\n- Coxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of hand-foot-mouth disease in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses can also cause the illness.\n- Enterovirus 71 has also been associated with cases and outbreaks of hand-foot-mouth disease. Less often, enterovirus 71 has been associated with severe disease, such as encephalitis.\n- Several types of enteroviruses may be identified in outbreaks of hand-foot-mouth disease, however most of the time, one or 2 enteroviruses are identified more frequently.\n\nHealth complications from hand-foot-mouth disease are not common.\n- Viral or 'aseptic' meningitis can occur with hand-foot-mouth disease, but it is rare. It causes fever, headache, stiff neck, or back pain and may require the infected person to be hospitalized for a few days.\n- Encephalitis (inflammation of the brain) or polio-like paralysis can occur, but this is even rarer.\n- Fingernail and toenail loss have been reported, occurring mostly in children within a few weeks after having hand-foot-mouth disease. At this time, [it is not known] whether nail loss was a result of the disease in reported cases. However, in the reports reviewed, the nail loss was temporary, and the nail grew back without medical treatment.\n\nExcerpted from https://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/about/transmission.html. - Mod.LK\n\nA Healthmap/ ProMED of the United States can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106\n\n\n]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A Healthmap/ProMED that shows the Caribbean region where St. Kitts and Nevis are located can be seen at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/31]\n\n******\n There were 44 cases of HFMD reported in that week, which was 29 percent lower than the number of cases reported in the previous week (62 cases in week 40 of 2017). Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 16 Mar 2017\nFrom: anonymous contributor [edited]\n\n\nThis information has been received through the ProMED submit info form from a source who prefers to remain anonymous\n\n'Since last week [week 6 to 12 Mar 2017], an increased number of hand foot and mouth disease (HFMD) have been reported from Rawalpindi district, the twin of Islamabad (federal capital of Pakistan). Recently some cases have also been reported in Lahore, the 2nd biggest metropolitan city of Pakistan.\n\nThe Health department has been investigating this outbreak internally, but so far, no news has been shared on mass media. The disease is mild and has affected under 5 children of play group and Kindergarten.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a self-limiting contagious illness caused commonly by enteroviruses affecting mostly infants and children aged less than 5 years. Numerous non-polio enteroviruses as coxsackie viruses A16, A4, A5, A9, A10, B2 and B5 and enterovirus 71 are associated with HFMD. However, the most common causes are coxsackie virus A16 (CAV 16) and enterovirus 71 (EV 71).\n\nThe virus is shed in saliva, sputum, nasal mucus, blister fluid, and feces of an infected person. HFMD is spread from one person to another through close contact, coughing and sneezing, contact with feces and blister fluids, and touching objects or surfaces contaminated with the virus. An infected person is most contagious during the 1st week of illness https://www.cdc.gov/features/handfootmouthdisease/index.html. The incubation period is generally 3 to 5 days. The epidemiological pattern varies by geographical region and climate, but the incidence of infection is higher in the summer and autumn months in temperate climates while remaining prevalent year-round in tropical climates.\n\nHFMD presents as fever, rash on hands and feet, and vesicles in the mouth (known as herpangina), conjunctivitis, encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis, acute respiratory problem and myopericarditis. It should be noted that infection with EV 71 may result in complications without producing clinically-evident HFMD. The rash does not itch. The illness is usually mild and resolves spontaneously within 7 to 10 days without any treatment.\n\nHFMD is treated symptomatically as there is no specific treatment or vaccine. Patients should drink plenty of fluids to prevent dehydration. Early diagnosis and isolation is the key to prevent spread of HFMD.\n\nThe above information relates to cases from 2 densely populated districts of Punjab Province in Pakistan. While PromedMail is thankful to the anonymous contributor, further information on the epidemiology of the suspected cases and any confirmatory laboratory tests in this regard would be highly appreciated. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/941.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The disease is mild and has affected under 5 children of play group and Kindergarten.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< This information has been received through the ProMED submit info form from a source who prefers to remain anonymous\n\n'Since last week [week 6 to 12 Mar 2017], an increased number of hand foot and mouth disease (HFMD) have been reported from Rawalpindi district, the twin of Islamabad (federal capital of Pakistan). promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a self-limiting contagious illness caused commonly by enteroviruses affecting mostly infants and children aged less than 5 years. \n\nHFMD presents as fever, rash on hands and feet, and vesicles in the mouth (known as herpangina), conjunctivitis, encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis, acute respiratory problem and myopericarditis. KS, edited]\nhttps://www.debate.com.mx/salud/ALERTA-Virus-Coxsackie-amenaza-a-bebes-en-estos-estados-20170629-0060.html\n\n\nCoxsackie virus disease lasts between 7 and 10 days, but besides that there is no specific treatment; the important thing is to control the fever.\n\nThe health departments in Tlaxcala, Oaxaca, Hidalgo, Estado de M\u00e9xico, Quer\u00e9taro, Zacatecas and Tamaulipas issued a health alert due to detecting outbreaks of coxsackie, a virus that poses no risk if detected early.\n\nAlfredo Gobera Farro, secretary of Health in Quer\u00e9taro, explains that coxsackie is a virus that mainly affects babies and children under 5 years of age.\n\nThe disease is frequent because it is common for children to put their hands or feet in their mouths, which -- if the virus is present in their body -- causes sores or pimples around the lips and other parts of the body that have contacted with the saliva.\n\nSymptoms such as high fever, general malaise, and sore throat may occur; the average age of infection is 2 years old and it is transmitted in places of high coexistence, such as daycare centers.\n\nThe disease tends to last between 7 and 10 days, but there is no specific treatment except to try to control the fever. 'The virus can spread, even when there are no symptoms, through feces, from diaper changes and respiratory secretions. The contagion occurs in the first 3 days of contact and then the symptoms appear,' said the Secretary of Health.\n\nThey also warn that the disease can be confused with the common cold, flu or stomach infections, as it manifests with flu-like symptoms.\n\nRecommendations\n---------------\nAmong the recommendations issued by health authorities are:\n- frequent hand washing and the use of individual cutlery;\n- shared toys such as in day-care centers should be disinfected regularly because the virus can live on these objects for several days;\n- avoid kissing others;\n- sneeze into your [tissue or handkerchief];\n- and go to the doctor with any symptoms;\n- avoid self-medication and notify childcare organizations, so that preventive measures can be taken to avoid further spread of the disease, especially to family members and childcare workers.\n\nOnce treated, symptoms should disappear in a week and there is little risk of morbidity or mortality, as long as symptoms are promptly treated, the authorities state.\n\nHighest number of cases\n-----------------------\nIn Mexico, the region with the highest number of registered cases is Tlaxcala (about 100), where the Ministry of Health (Sesa) promoted training for the population in general, nursery managers and educational institutions, to identify signs and symptoms.\n\nThe Secretary of Health in Tlaxcala, Alberto Jonguitud Falc\u00f3n, reported that the patients are mainly inhabitants of the municipalities of Apizaco, Tlaxcala and Chiautempan. He explained that the State Commission for the Protection against Health Risks (Coeprist) supervises the chlorination and disinfection of water tanks and cisterns; 'We have carried out an exhaustive verification of the educational establishments and also verified chlorination in the water wells of localities that register cases.'\n\nIn the Mixteca region of Oaxaca, where approximately 80 cases have been reported, education authorities have asked parents and school authorities to be alert.\n\nHidalgo is the state with the 3rd-highest number of cases, reporting 61. The public policy director of the Health Ministry, Concepci\u00f3n Carmona Ramos, said the outbreak has been concentrated in the central area, including the regions of Pachuca, Mineral de la Reforma, Tizayuca and the Tula-Tepeji, among others. She emphasized that since it is not a disease subject to epidemiological surveillance, a comparison with other years cannot be made; however, it is clear that its prevalence has increased in 2017. The official commented that, as schoolchildren are the most affected, there is constant coordination with the Ministry of Public Education, to carry out case control and surveillance.\n\nThe State of Mexico has registered 40 cases, including 20 in Quer\u00e9taro, 5 in Tamaulipas, and 3 in Zacatecas.\n\nThe 1st outbreak was detected in the United States. The coxsackie virus is named after the city of Coxsackie, New York, where it was 1st discovered, although there are no data from the time when this occurred.\n\nInfections occur throughout the year, but in colder climates, outbreaks of coxsackie virus occur more often in summer and fall.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nKathryn Soderholm\n<kathryn.soderholm@gmail.com>\n\n[Coxsackie virus A16 is the most common cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses can also cause the illness. The virus is a member of the family _Picornaviridae_, genus _Enterovirus_, which also includes polioviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nCoxsackie virus is highly contagious. Oral ingestion is the main source of infection and HFMD. The illness spreads by person-to-person contact with an infected person's nasal secretions or throat discharge, saliva, fluid from blisters, stool, respiratory droplets sprayed into the air after a cough or sneeze. Good hygiene must be maintained as the virus persists on surfaces for several days and infected individuals may shed virus for several weeks. Fortunately, the disease is generally self-limited.\n\nInformation on these non-polio enteroviruses can be found at https://www.cdc.gov/non-polio-enterovirus/index.html. More information on HFMD is also available in Spanish at the URL above.\n\nA Healthmap of Mexico can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/14 - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Among the recommendations issued by health authorities are:\n- frequent hand washing and the use of individual cutlery;\n- shared toys such as in day-care centers should be disinfected regularly because the virus can live on these objects for several days;\n- avoid kissing others;\n- sneeze into your [tissue or handkerchief];\n- and go to the doctor with any symptoms;\n- avoid self-medication and notify childcare organizations, so that preventive measures can be taken to avoid further spread of the disease, especially to family members and childcare workers. Most of the patients were small children aged under 5. He has instructed the provincial public health offices nationwide to ask local child development centers and kindergartens to continuously prevent more infections.\n\nThe best way to prevent the disease is to keep oneself clean and to wash children's hands often, said the Public Health Minister.\n\nThe hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by a virus. Patients will experience fever and sores in or on their mouth, hands, and feet.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Six thousand seven hundred and ninety cases is a high number, but although severe disease may occur, most notably with EV71 infection in children, severe disease was not noted here. But see discussion in [2].\n\nHFMD is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. However, it can sometimes occur in older children and adults. It usually starts with a fever, reduced appetite, sore throat, and a feeling of being unwell (malaise). One or 2 days after the fever starts, painful sores can develop in the mouth, often in the back of the mouth, as small red spots that blister and can become ulcers. A skin rash with red spots, and sometimes with blisters, may also develop over 1 or 2 days on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet; it may also appear on the knees, elbows, buttocks or genital area. Dehydration may occur because blisters in the mouth create pain with swallowing. Some people, especially adults, may show no symptoms at all, but they can still pass the virus to others. (Excerpted from CDC). - Mod.LK]\n\n[A healthmap of Thailand may be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/151.]\n\n******\n[2] Vietnam\nDate: Wed 1 Mar 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/hand-foot-mouth-disease-cases-30-vietnam-14661/\n\n\nThe number of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) cases reported in Vietnam in 2017 is increased compared to the same period in 2016, according to the General Department of Preventive Medicine, Ministry of Health, Viet Nam.\n\nThe cumulative number of cases as of [Sat 11 Feb 2017] is 5252 cases with no deaths. Compared to the same period in 2016 (3999 cases and 6 deaths), the number of cases is greater by 31 percent.\n\nHFMD is typically a benign and self-limiting disease. Most common in young children, it presents as fever, oral lesions and rash on the hands, feet and buttocks. The oral lesions consist of rapidly-ulcerating vesicles on the buccal mucosa, tongue, palate and gums. The rash consists of papulovesicular lesions on the palms, fingers and soles, which generally persist for 7 to 10 days, and maculopapular lesions on the buttocks.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the Enterovirus genus (group). This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nEnterovirus 71 has been implicated in HFMD outbreaks in Southeast Asia over several years. EV 71 is a non-polio enterovirus.\n\nComplications associated with HFMD caused by the more pathogenic EV-71 strain include encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema or hemorrhage and myocarditis. Most deaths in HFMD occur as a result of pulmonary edema or hemorrhage.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is caused by such non-polio enteroviruses as coxsackie viruses A16, A4, A5, A9, A10, B2 and B5 and enterovirus 71. Its most common causes are coxsackie virus A16 (CAV 16) and enterovirus 71 (EV 71).\n\nInfection with EV71 is usually asymptomatic or associated with a mild non-specific illness. More severe presentations do occur, particularly in children. Presentations include exanthems (including HFMD), herpangina, conjunctivitis, encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis, acute respiratory problem and myopericarditis. It should be noted that infection with EV 71 may result in complications without producing clinically-evident HFMD. This occurred in the context of a large outbreak of EV 71 in Bulgaria.\n\nEV 71 is transmitted through direct contact with discharge from the nose and throat, saliva, fluid from blisters or the stools of an infected person. Cases are most infectious during the 1st week of acute illness but may continue to shed virus in stool for weeks. The incubation period is 3-5 days. The epidemiological pattern varies by geographical region and climate, but the incidence of infection is higher in the summer and autumn months in temperate climates while remaining prevalent year-round in tropical climates. (Excerpted and edited from http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/id-mi/ev71-eng.php). - Mod.LK]\n\n[A HealthMap of Viet Nam can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152.\n\n\n]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Six thousand seven hundred and ninety cases is a high number, but although severe disease may occur, most notably with EV71 infection in children, severe disease was not noted here. has been closed after a 2-year-old boy died from [hand-foot-mouth disease].\n\nThe elder sister of the boy now feels sick and was sent to Siriraj Hospital in Bangkok.\n\nCaptain Apinan Songkramchai, a provincial commander, said that the Kilosong Tessaban kindergarten was ordered closed on [Tue 20 Jun 2017] and public health officials and staff are now cleaning the premises with disinfectants.\n\nThe boy lived in Aranyaprathet district and had been suffering from the foot-and-mouth virus for about 4 days. His death alerted authorities, which led to the closure of the kindergarten, Apinan said.\n\nMeanwhile Kornchai Srikoon, the mayor of Muang Aranyaprathet municipality, said that he was alerted of the death of the pupil on Tuesday afternoon [20 Jun 2017].\n\nAt a temple, the boy's father said that he usually took his children to Rongklua border Market and he suspected that his boy caught the disease there.\n\nHe revealed that his daughter, aged 4, now feels sick with the same symptoms as her brother, so his wife took their daughter to hospital on Tuesday night [20 Jun 2017].\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Thailand health officials had issued an advisory in February 2017, after reporting increased numbers of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD), mostly in children under the age of 5. [See ProMED mail Hand, foot & mouth disease update (02): Thailand, Viet Nam 20170303.4875744.]\n\nSince the beginning of the year through 19 Feb 2017, the Thailand Bureau of Epidemiology reported a total of 7684 cases from all 77 provinces. No deaths were reported. The highest rates of infection were reported from Suratthani, Chanthaburi, Chiengrai, Lampang, and Phuket provinces.\n\nHFMD is typically a benign and self-limiting disease. Most common in young children, it presents as fever, oral lesions, and rash on the hands, feet, and buttocks. The oral lesions consist of rapidly-ulcerating vesicles on the buccal mucosa, tongue, palate, and gums. The rash consists of papulovesicular lesions on the palms, fingers, and soles, which generally persist for 7 to 10 days, and maculopapular lesions on the buttocks.\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the _Enterovirus_ genus (group). This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nEnterovirus 71 has been implicated in HFMD outbreaks in Southeast Asia over the several years. EV71 is a non-polio enterovirus.\n\nComplications associated with HFMD caused by the more pathogenic EV71 strain include encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema or hemorrhage, and myocarditis. Most deaths in HFMD occur as a result of pulmonary edema or hemorrhage. [excerpted, edited from 26 Feb 2017 http://outbreaknewstoday.com/thailand-issues-warning-spread-hand-foot-mouth-disease-hfmd-64381/].\n\nDeath may occur following HFMD infection as reported in MMWR 1988; 47(30); 629-32 (https://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/00054640.htm). Following the death of one 7-year-old child, autopsy findings included acute encephalomyelitis, mild interstitial pneumonitis, and pulmonary hemorrhage. No histopathologic evidence of myocarditis was detected. Neurons in areas of inflammation and tissue necrosis were positive for enterovirus 71 (EV71) using immunohistochemical staining with a monoclonal anti-EV71 antibody.\n\nThis occurred in Taiwan during an outbreak in 1998 where there were approximately 90 000 reports of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) among young children based on passive surveillance from sentinel physicians. Approximately 320 children [were] hospitalized with HFMD associated with suspected meningitis, encephalitis, or acute flaccid paralysis (AFP), and at least 55 died.\n\nThis was the 3rd known EV71 outbreak resulting in rapid clinical deterioration and death among young children; previous outbreaks primarily among children aged less than 3 years occurred in Bulgaria during May-September 1975 (44 cases) and in Malaysia during April-June 1997 (28 cases).\n\nMaps of Thailand may be found at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Provinces_of_Thailand and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/39356. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Thailand health officials had issued an advisory in February 2017, after reporting increased numbers of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD), mostly in children under the age of 5. [CHCC] Chief Executive Officer Esther Muna says there have been 7 cases of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) confirmed at the Commonwealth Health Center's emergency department in the past month, and 1 case at the hospital's Children's Clinic.\n\nBut there have been no cases identified since 20 Oct 2016, she said.\n\nHFMD is a viral infection that can be spread through close personal contact, coughing or sneezing, contact with feces or sharing of straws, cups, and other contaminated surfaces.\n\nIt is usually a mild, common childhood disease with limited consequences, according to CHCC.\n\n'The viral illness usually affects infants and children younger than age 5.\n\n'Of the 8 cases diagnosed at CHC in the last month, 5 or 63 percent were under the age of 5.'\n\nSometimes adults can get the illness, but this is much less common.\n\nHFMD symptoms include a fever, reduced appetite and sore throat.\n\nOne or 2 days after the fever, painful sores can develop in the mouth (called herpangina). They are usually in the back of the mouth as small red spots that blister and become ulcers. A skin rash with red spots and at times blisters can occur on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.\n\n'Not everyone will develop all the symptoms. Some people may show no symptoms but still pass on the virus.'\n\nAccording to CHCC, 'A person with HFMD is most contagious during the 1st week of illness.'\n\nThere is no vaccine for HFMD, but members of the public can prevent/reduce their risk of being infected by:\n- Washing their hands often with soap and water.\n- Cleaning and disinfecting touched surfaces including toys.\n- Avoid close contact including kissing, hugging, or sharing utensils/cups with a person suffering from HFMD.\n\n'For the painful mouth sores, you can use over-the-counter mouthwashes or sprays that numb mouth pain. Take over-the-counter Tylenol or Ibuprofen to relieve pain and fever. Aspirin should not be given to children.'\n\nCommunity members are advised to stay home if they have HFMD. Talk to your primary care doctor if you are unsure when you should return to work. It also applies to taking children back to school and/or daycare.\n\n[Byline: Bryan Manabat]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Northern Mariana Islands (United States) can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/381. - 2016].\n\nDM, 22, her partner CB, 26, and their daughter B, one, said they were not told before travelling of the ongoing hand, foot and mouth outbreak at the hotel.\n\nThey booked the holiday through tour operator Thomson.\n\nThe disease is an infection that causes mouth ulcers and spots on the hands and feet and is particularly common in children under the age of 10.\n\nJust a few days into the holiday B developed a fever and a high temperature.\n\nIn the following days she developed spots on her arms, legs and around her mouth, which later became a full rash.\n\nA total of 17 holidaymakers have now instructed law firm Irwin Mitchell to investigate the outbreak at the hotel.\n\nClare Pearson, a personal injury lawyer at Irwin Mitchell, representing the 17 holidaymakers, said: 'The hand, foot and mouth disease outbreak at the Family Life Mar De Menorca is obviously extremely concerning as children are more susceptible to the disease and the hotel is advertised as a 'destination well suited to families'.\n\n'The people who have contacted us were shocked that they were not informed of the outbreak before they arrived as many of them would not have chosen to stay at the hotel had they known of the problems.\n\n'This is of particular concern for some holidaymakers who had young children and were pregnant at the time of their holidays.\n\nDM, from Colchester [England, UK], said the soft play area was not very clean, highchairs were not disinfected after being used and the same cleaning equipment was used in all rooms.\n\nDM, who took time off work to look after B on their RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4847712", "date": "2017-02-18 13:52:33", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE UPDATE (01): SOUTHEAST ASIA, UK (ESSEX) USA (CALIFORNIA) DOMINICAN REPUBLIC (LA ALTAGRACIA) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n************************************************************************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] Cambodia\n[2] Viet Nam\n[3] UK (Essex)\n[4] USA (California)\n[5] RFI: Dominican Republic (La Altagracia)\n\n******\n[1] Cambodia\nDate: Mon 13 Feb 2017\nSource: Khmer Times [edited]\nhttp://www.khmertimeskh.com/news/35382/hand--foot--mouth-disease-alert/\n\n\nThe Health Ministry's Communicable Disease Control (CDC) department has urged people to be cautious of the spread of hand, food and mouth disease (HFMD) and asked that infants or children displaying symptoms be brought to seek medical treatment immediately.\n\nMinistry spokesperson and director of the CDC Ly Sovann said yesterday [12 Feb 2017] that hospitals have been seeing a rise in HFMD cases and appealed to all parents to be vigilant in identifying the symptoms so that children can be given treatment immediately.\n\n'Especially for children with dangerous symptoms, they have to be sent to the Children's Specialized Hospital immediately. Dangerous symptoms include vomiting as well as arm and foot convulsions or weakness,' he said.\n\nMr. Sovann also recommended that people regularly wash their hands with either soap or an alcohol-based solution such as hand sanitizer, especially after touching blisters or ulcers, before preparing or eating food, before feeding infants or children, after using the toilet and after changing a baby's diaper.\n\nHe also asked that parents keep their children away from sick or symptomatic children, to provide nutritious meals for their children, to provide clean drinking water and to use separate utensils when feeding each child.\n\nAccording to the CDC, HFMD is an infectious disease which commonly affects infants and children under the age of 10. Symptoms include fever, painful mouth ulcers as well as blisters and a rash on the palms and soles of the feet.\n\n'While HFMD is a mild ailment, with most patients being able to recover within 7-10 days without treatment, there are also rare cases where the disease can develop serious complications affecting the nerve and respiratory systems.\n\n'The child then needs to be sent to the nearest hospital immediately,' Mr. Sovann said.\n\nThe virus is spread by direct contact with respiratory fluids such as saliva, sputum, mucus, fluid from blisters and the stool of patients.\n\nIn 2012, dozens of children were infected with a deadly strain of HFMD which killed 52, Time magazine quoted the World Health Organization and the Health Ministry as saying.\n\nThe epidemic that spread in April 2012 landed 62 children in hospital as medical practitioners struggled to identify the EV-71 strain, previously unrecognized in Cambodia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] Viet Nam\nDate: Thu 16 Feb 2017\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/vietnam-issues-hand-foot-mouth-disease-warning-76944/\n\n\nAfter reporting about 50 000 hand, foot and mouth disease cases in 2016, Vietnamese health officials with the General Department of Preventive Medicine are warning the public to take protective measures as more than 2100 cases have been seen in 57 localities so far in 2017.\n\nA local media report does note that the total number of cases is still 38.6 percent lower than in the same period last year [2016], with most cases reported in south.\n\nHFMD is typically a benign and self-limiting disease. Most common in young children, it presents as fever, oral lesions and rash on the hands, feet and buttocks. The oral lesions consist of rapidly-ulcerating vesicles on the buccal mucosa, tongue, palate and gums. The rash consists of papulovesicular lesions on the palms, fingers and soles, which generally persist for 7-10 days, and maculopapular lesions on the buttocks.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the Enterovirus genus (group). This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nEnterovirus 71 has been implicated in HFMD outbreaks in Southeast Asia over several years. EV-71 is a non-polio enterovirus. Complications associated with HFMD caused by the more pathogenic EV-71 strain include encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema or hemorrhage and myocarditis. Most deaths in HFMD occur as a result of pulmonary edema or hemorrhage.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap of Cambodia and Viet Nam can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/145.]\n\n******\n[3] UK (Essex)\nDate: Fri 17 Feb 2017\nSource: Essex Live [edited]\nhttp://www.essexlive.news/hand-foot-and-mouth-in-essex-what-to-expect/story-30144000-detail/story.html\n\n\nParents are on alert over an outbreak of the highly contagious hand, foot and mouth disease. Cases have been reported across Essex, with parents in Brentwood this week announcing appearances of the virus.\n\nThe infectious disease causes mouth ulcers and spots on the hands and feet and is most common in young children, particularly those under 10. It can, however, also affect older children and adults.\n\nThe symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease usually develop between 3-5 days after being exposed to the infection.\n\nThe 1st symptoms may include a high temperature, usually around 38-39 C [100-102 F], a general sense of feeling unwell, loss of appetite, coughing, abdominal pain and a sore throat and mouth.\n\nThe infection is not related to foot and mouth disease, which affects cattle, sheep and pigs.\n\nThe disease can be unpleasant, but it will usually clear up by itself within 7-10 days. Doctors say children can be normally looked after at home.\n\n[Byline: Piers Meyler]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the UK (Essex) can be found at http://www.propertysurveying.co.uk/ESSEX/images/essex-map.jpg.]\n\n******\n[4] USA (California)\nDate: Wed 14 Feb 2017\nSource: KESQ-TV [edited]\nhttp://www.kesq.com/news/hfm-disease-hits-local-elementary-school/334018574\n\n\nThere were recently 4 confirmed cases of hand, foot and mouth disease at an elementary school [Palm Springs Unified School District] in Desert Hot Springs.\n\nParents with children in kindergarten and 1st grade were sent a letter warning them about possible exposure to the disease.\n\nOne doctor said that while it sounds terrible, the name is scarier than the illness.\n\n'The virus is called Coxsackie. It's within the same family [as] chicken pox [see comment below]. It's not necessarily, though, as significant of a disease,' pediatrician Ernesto Millan said.\n\nMillan said the disease causes painful blisters on the inside of the mouth, hands and feet.\n\nAccording to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, it can be spread through saliva, blister fluid and feces. That is why doctors recommend people wash their hands often.\n\n'If you live with the person, there's not much you can do other than [wash your hands], you know, just keeping it from spreading to someone else and of course, like you tell all the kids, cover your cough,' Millan said.\n\nMillan said it's usually seen in children under 6 and lasts about 10 days. It's a virus, and doctors can only treat the symptoms, such as fever, rash, and blisters.\n\n'We offer Tylenol for significant fever of 102 F [39 C] and higher. We provide and encourage oral and liquid intakes to make sure they are not getting dehydrated,' Dr. Millan said.\n\nMillan said a child is no longer contagious even if a rash remains once symptoms like fever and pain from the blisters are relieved.\n\nHe says students can return to school after those symptoms have cleared-up.\n\nPrevention Tips:\n\n- Wash any clothing and bed linens used by someone carrying the virus.\n- Avoid using shared items in the home.\n- Wash hands regularly and frequently to prevent the spread of the virus.\n- Throw away all toothbrushes used in the home by family members and replace with new ones.\n\nMore information can be found on the Centers For Disease Control and Prevention's website.\n\n[Byline: Zarina Khairzada]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A HealthMap showing the location of California in the USA can be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]\n\n******\n[5] RFI: Dominican Republic (La Altagracia)\nDate: Fri 17 Feb 2017\nSource: Online Submission/Direct Communication [edited]\n\n[The following information was received from a ProMED-mail subscriber who wishes to remain anonymous.]\n\n\nAt least one child was reportedly infected with hand, foot, and mouth (HFM) disease while vacationing in Punta Cana, Dominican Republic. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Humans can contract the animal disease (FMDV) although this is rare, and animals do not typically get the human disease under normal circumstances.\n\nLarge outbreaks of hand, foot, and mouth disease are not common in the United States. However, in some countries in Asia, outbreaks are large and occur often. Thousands of people may get infected. Some people, particularly young children, may have severe disease requiring hospitalization or even causing death. Travelers to these countries can protect themselves by practicing personal hygiene tips (CDC). - Mod.LK]\n\n[Any additional information on these cases or other cases in the Dominican Republic would be appreciated, as HFM may not be known to many international travelers despite its frequent occurrence in daycare facilities in North America. China (03): (HK)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4543101", "date": "2016-10-07 11:30:55", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (03): (HONG KONG)\n******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 5 Oct 2016\nSource: 7th Space [edited]\nhttp://7thspace.com/headlines/530879/local_hand_foot_and_mouth_disease_and_acute_gastroenteritis_activity_increasing.html\n\n\nThe [Hong Kong] Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health today [5 Oct 2016] reported that the local activity of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) and acute gastroenteritis (AGE) are increasing, and again urged the public and management of institutions to maintain strict personal and environmental hygiene.\n\n'The latest surveillance data show that activity of both diseases is increasing and may further increase in the following weeks. Members of the public should heighten vigilance,' a spokesman for the CHP said.\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease [HFMD]\n------------------------------\nThe number of institutional HFMD outbreaks increased from 3 (affecting 18 persons) in the week ending 3 Sep to 24 (77 persons) last week [week of 26 Sep 2016].\n\nAs of [4 Oct 2016], 14 (42 persons) had been reported this week. In the past 4 weeks, kindergartens and child care centres reported most outbreaks (69 per cent), followed by primary schools (20 per cent).\n\n'The usual summer peak of HFMD is from May to July, with a possible smaller peak from October to December. Last year [2015], the summer peak lasted longer than usual.\n\nSchools, institutions, and play facilities should observe our guidelines and health advice against outbreaks to better protect young children who are more prone to infections,' the spokesman added.\n\nAs for enterovirus (EV) 71 infection, as of [4 Oct 2016], 22 cases (including one with severe complications) had been recorded this year. Last year [2015], 56 cases including 6 with severe complications were filed. Regarding severe paediatric EV infection other than EV71 and poliovirus, 9 cases had been detected so far this year with 8 last year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See map of Hong Kong at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198.\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is caused by viruses that belong to the _Enterovirus_ genus, including polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nEnterovirus 71 (EV71) is one of a large family of viruses which multiply in the human gastrointestinal tract. EV71 infection can cause illness ranging from mild through to serious with life threatening complications. Outbreaks have been reported in Asia over many years.\n\nSpread is from person to person through contamination of hands or objects (for example, toys) with infected faeces. The virus is then taken in by the mouth. Spread also occurs by contact with the saliva, nasal mucus or sputum (phlegm) of an infected person. In people with hand-foot-mouth disease, direct contact with fluid from blisters on the infected person can also spread the virus.\n\nSigns and symptoms\n------------------\nEV71 is one of many possible viruses that cause hand-foot-mouth disease [HFMD]. Not all children with EV71 infections will have HFMD, [which often is] caused by other viruses.\n\nThe symptoms of hand-foot-mouth disease are: fever, rash, tiredness, loss of appetite, ulcers or blisters in the mouth, and on the hands and feet. Often there is a sore mouth for a few days before the ulcers or blisters appear and affected young children may refuse to eat or drink.\n\nEV71 infection usually causes only a mild illness in adults and children. However children under 5 years old, especially those under 2 years, are at higher risk of developing a severe EV71 infection.\n\n(Excerpted and edited from South Australia Health website http://bit.ly/2cWZ1jo) - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n The [Hong Kong] Centre for Health Protection (CHP) of the Department of Health today [5 Oct 2016] reported that the local activity of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) and acute gastroenteritis (AGE) are increasing, and again urged the public and management of institutions to maintain strict personal and environmental hygiene. CPS advises to take extra measures to prevent outbreaks by washing of hands often with soap and water.\n\nHand foot and mouth disease is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children who are 10-years of age or younger. It can sometimes occur in adults. There is no vaccine to protect against the viruses that cause it.\n\nPeople with symptoms should consult their family physician and take measures to mitigate an increase in the number of cases.\n\nSymptoms include cold-like conditions, fever, mouth sores, loss of appetite, cough, and a skin rash; a non-itchy red rash that develops on the hand and the feet, and sometimes the rash can develop into painful blisters; painful mouth ulcers.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative agent for hand foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is an enterovirus. It is not the same as other diseases that have similar names: foot-and-mouth disease (sometimes called hoof-and-mouth disease). See previous ProMED post Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA (04): (CA) 20160505.4204778 for a discussion of HFMD.\n\n[A map of St. Maarten in the Caribbean can be accessed at http://www.caribbean-direct.com/St-Martin-Direct/Maps/SMFmapsM.html - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Connecticut)\nDate: 21 Sep 2016, 11:56 AM ET\nSource: Patch [edited]\nhttp://patch.com/connecticut/shelton/virus-outbreak-hits-derby-high-school\n\n\nAn outbreak of coxsackie virus has hit Derby High School and several students have been affected, officials announced.\n\n'On 19 Sep 2016 several cases of the coxsackie virus were reported to school officials at Derby High School,' wrote Principal Martin Pascale in a letter to parents this week. 'As a safety precaution, Derby High School will be thoroughly cleaned and disinfected by the facilities management team. In addition, parents are encouraged to check your child/children for signs of a blister rash on the palms of their hands, soles of their feet and inside their mouths. Symptoms may also include a fever.'\n\nIn addition to the warning to parents, the 23 Sep [2016] football game between Derby and Seymour high schools has been postponed, because 4 members of the Derby team have contracted the virus, reports GameTime CT.\n\nCoxsackie virus, also known as hand, foot, and mouth disease, is 'spread through close personal contact. This can occur when there is direct contact with nose, throat, and fecal discharges of infected persons,' according to a coxsackie virus fact sheet from the Connecticut Department of Public Health.\n\nWho gets coxsackie virus?\n-------------------------\nAnyone can be infected, but the disease seems to occur predominately in children under 10 years of age.\n\nWhen can a person spread the virus to others?\n---------------------------------------------\nA person may spread the virus to others just prior to the onset of symptoms, during the acute stage of illness and perhaps longer, since this virus may persist in the stool for several weeks. The incubation period is usually 3 to 5 days.\n\nWhat are the symptoms and when do they appear?\n----------------------------------------------\nSymptoms develop 3 to 5 days after exposure. Most children will complain of a sore throat or sore mouth and loss of appetite. Fever of 101-102 degF [approx. 38-39 degC] lasts 1-2 days and is usually accompanied by sores in the mouth. Sores can also occur on the hands and feet and occasionally on the buttocks. The illness is mild and lasts 1 week or less.\n\nWhat is the treatment?\n----------------------\nAt this time, there is no specific treatment.\n\nWhat can be done to prevent the spread of this disease?\n-------------------------------------------------------\nParticular attention should be paid to hand washing and personal hygiene.\n\n[Byline: Alfred Branch]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of Connecticut, United States may be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/210. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The causative agent for hand foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is an enterovirus. LK]\n\n******\n Who gets coxsackie virus?\n \nParticular attention should be paid to hand washing and personal hygiene.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-09-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-03-25 00:00:00", "2016-09-21 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "CONNECTICUT", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "http://healthmap.org/promed/p/210", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4529788", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA (08): (CT, OH)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4529788", "date": "2016-10-01 14:59:26", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA (08): (CONNECTICUT, OHIO)\n************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nIn this update:\n[1] USA (Watertown, Connecticut) schools\n[2] USA (Parma, Ohio) schools\n\n******\n[1] USA (Watertown, Connecticut) schools\nDate: Thu 29 Sep 2016\nSource: Town Times News [edited]\nhttp://www.primepublishers.com/towntimesnews/news/top_stories/schools-cautious-about-virus-outbreak/article_0cbf5cc2-85ac-11e6-9b65-a778eba2ca4b.html\n\n\nCoxsackie Virus (A or B) HFMD: 15 cases in schools in Watertown, Connecticut\n----------------------------------------------------------------------------\nWatertown school administration decided to postpone an open house set for Thursday, 22 Sep [2016], due to an outbreak of Coxsackie virus, or hand, foot and mouth disease, in all 5 schools, according to Curriculum Director Janet Parlato.\n\nAdditionally, the Suffield Swim Team and Holy Cross Boys Soccer and Holy Cross Girl Soccer teams cancelled games with Watertown on Friday [23 Sep 2016]. Those decisions were made by the administration of the other schools, as Ms. Parlato said that after cleaning and disinfecting all 5 schools on Thu afternoon and evening, that Watertown was 'business as usual.'\n\nCustodial staff washed and disinfected surfaces students and staff are likely to have touched, such as desktops, chairs, door handles, hand railings, health office beds, etc.\n\nMs. Parlato said the schools had 15 confirmed cases since last week until Thursday [22 Sep 2016], but had no additional cases as of Friday [23 Sep 2016]. Cancelling the open house on Thursday was really the administration exercising 'an abundance of caution,' according to Ms. Parlato.\n\n'There would have been a lot of parents there,' Ms. Parlato said. 'Rather than expose them, we postponed.'\n\nNo new date has been scheduled for the open house or the swim team meet, but the boys soccer team was set for Monday, 26 Sep [2016], and the girls soccer team was rescheduled for Wednesday, 5 Oct [2016].\n\nAccording to the state Department of Public Health website, hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral infection that causes a blister-like rash that is spread by coughing, sneezing, and touching infected persons or contaminated surfaces. Coxsackie viruses are spread through close personal contact. This can occur when there is direct contact with nose, throat, and fecal discharges of infected persons. Anyone can be infected, but the disease seems to occur predominately in children under 10 years of age.\n\nA person may spread the virus to others just prior to the onset of symptoms, during the acute stage of illness and perhaps longer, since this virus may persist in the stool for several weeks. The incubation period is usually 3-5 days.\n\nSymptoms develop 3-5 days after exposure. Most children will complain of a sore throat or sore mouth and loss of appetite. A fever of 101 to 102 degrees F lasts 1-2 days and is usually accompanied by sores in the mouth. Sores can also occur on the hands and feet and occasionally on the buttocks. The illness is mild and lasts one week or less.\n\nThere is no specific treatment for the disease, but its spread can be prevented by paying 'particular attention to hand washing and personal hygiene,' according to the state website.\n\nChildren and pregnant women are at greatest risk. If diagnosed, a child will need a doctor's note to return to school.\n\nMs. Parlato said the outbreak is 'not unique' to Watertown, as there have been a number of cases across the state.\n\nIn addition to the cleaning, a number of precautions have been put into effect. Administrators, teachers, nurses, athletic directors, and coaches will be speaking to students with a consistent message about the importance of maintaining good hygiene, including frequent hand washing and not sharing personal items, such as water bottles and utensils. The administration also asked that parents remind their children at home 'about these important and appropriate precautions.'\n\n[Byline: Jim Taylor]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Coxsackieviruses belong to the family Picornaviridae and the genus Enterovirus, which also includes poliovirus and echovirus. Enteroviruses are among the most common and important human pathogens. Coxsackie viruses share many characteristics with poliovirus. With control of poliovirus infections in much of the world, more attention has been focused on understanding the nonpolio enteroviruses such as coxsackie virus.\n\nCoxsackieviruses are nonenveloped viruses with linear single-stranded RNA. Coxsackieviruses are divided into group A and group B viruses based on early observations of their pathogenicity in mice. Group A coxsackieviruses were noted to cause a flaccid paralysis, which was caused by generalized myositis, while group B coxsackieviruses were noted to cause a spastic paralysis due to focal muscle injury and degeneration of neuronal tissue. At least 23 serotypes (1-22, 24) of group A and 6 serotypes (1-6) of group B are recognized.\n\nIn general, group A coxsackieviruses tend to infect the skin and mucous membranes, causing herpangina, acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis (AHC), and hand, foot and mouth (HFM) disease. Group B coxsackieviruses tend to infect the heart, pleura, pancreas, and liver, causing pleurodynia, myocarditis, pericarditis, and hepatitis. Both group A and group B coxsackieviruses can cause nonspecific febrile illnesses, rashes, upper respiratory tract disease, and aseptic meningitis (http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/215241-overview). - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] USA (Ohio) schools\nDate: Fri 30 Sep 2016\nSource: News 5 [edited]\nhttp://www.newsnet5.com/news/local-news/oh-cuyahoga/hand-foot-and-mouth-virus-breaks-out-in-parma-city-schools\n\n\nAn outbreak of hand, foot and mouth virus has been confirmed in Parma City Schools [Ohio] by district officials\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------------\nThe virus usually begins with a moderate fever before small, round blisters begin to develop inside the mouth, usually along the tongue and inside of the cheeks. Fluid-filled blisters can appear on the tops of the hands, soles of the feet and between fingers and toes. The virus usually lasts up to 2 weeks.\n\nTypically, hand, foot and mouth disease is transmitted by direct contact with respiratory drainage from a sick person. No medicine exists to cure the sickness. Sick children are advised to drink cold fluids and frequently wash their hands.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the US showing the locations of Connecticut and Ohio may be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \nWatertown school administration decided to postpone an open house set for Thursday, 22 Sep [2016], due to an outbreak of Coxsackie virus, or hand, foot and mouth disease, in all 5 schools, according to Curriculum Director Janet Parlato. It's considered a minor illness, like the common cold.\n\nFamilies in the district were alerted after the cases of HFMD were confirmed.\n\nIn young children symptoms of HFMD are mild and usually resolve in 7-10 days, according to a fact sheet from the Wisconsin Department of Health Services. HFMD usually starts with a fever, poor appetite and a sore throat. 1-2 days after the fever starts, painful sores usually develop in the mouth, beginning as small red spots that blister and often become ulcers. A skin rash also develops, usually on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet.\n\nSymptoms usually appear 3-7 days after exposure. HFMD is spread by contact with discharges from the nose or throat or the feces of infected people, according to the fact sheet.\n\nThe best way to prevent the spread of illness is to wash hands often, Heidelmeier said.\n\nParents in the district were reminded that if their child is experiencing a fever or rash on their hands, feet, and/or mouth, they should be kept home from school until at least 24 hours after the fever breaks and exposed vesicles are dry. Students will be checked by school health assistants to make sure the lesions are dry before being allowed back at school, Heidelmeier added.\n\n[Byline: Carol Spaeth-Bauer]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See map of Wisconsin, United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/250. - Mod.LK]\n\n******\n[2] Arizona (Yavapai County)\nDate: Wed 5 Oct 2016\nSource: Daily Courier [edited]\nhttp://www.dcourier.com/news/2016/oct/05/hand-foot-mouth-disease-outbreaks-require-vigilanc/\n\n\nLittle kids and nasty germs just seem to go together.\n\nLocal health officials say there is now some outbreaks of a common childhood ailment known as hand-foot-mouth disease, one caused by the coxsackie virus.\n\nIt is a fairly benign, yet easily transmittable, illness that occurs most often in preschool-age children.\n\nThe illness manifests itself in small blisters around the mouth, hands, and feet, and is usually preceded by a slight fever, usually not a high fever but one that can last for a few days, said local health officials.\n\nThere is no treatment for this ailment, but it rarely requires more than a few days home and some over-the-counter medications to lower the fever and treat any discomfort, health officials said.\n\n'It is a fairly mild disease with fever, some blisters, and it is self-limiting. It goes away after a while; usually the incubation is 3-6 days,' said Yavapai County Community Health Services Epidemiologist Stephen Everett.\n\nHe said his department has been advised by several local day care and preschools that they have some outbreaks. The national Centers for Disease Control and Prevention do not require tracking of this illness because it is a common childhood ailment that tends to run its course without complications.\n\nOf course, Everett said he always advises families to consult with their family physicians when a child is ill just to be certain that they get proper care, and if other symptoms arise they are attended to immediately. In rare cases, Everett said this can spread into the spinal cord and cause a mild form of meningitis.\n\nAs for prevention, Everett said the key to preventing contagious illnesses of this type are to keep children home from daycare or preschool when they spike any level of fever. The condition is most contagious when a child has a fever, he said.\n\nMost preschool and day care administrators are aware when outbreaks occur to do thorough cleanings of all communal toys and gathering places, and to be cautious when changing diapers as the virus is also found in a child's stool, he said. Regular handwashing with young children is always advisable, he noted.\n\nYavapai Regional Medical Center Marketing and Communications Director Ken Boush advised on Tue 4 Oct 2016, that the hospital's PhysicanCare Ponderosa Pediatric practice reported a recent increase in this ailment among their young patients.\n\nEverett said the condition is most common in summer, spring, and fall, with the virus typically becoming dormant come the winter months.\n\nOutbreaks are 'not unusual,' Everett said. 'We have them every year. What we try to stress, and some parents have a hard time with this, is do not send kids to school if they have a fever... they spread disease,' Everett said, noting the flu can spread in the same way. 'It's tough for parents because if their kid isn't in daycare, they're not at work ... But it's important. If a kid has a fever, don't send them to school!'\n\n[Byline: Nanci Hutson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See map of Arizona, United States at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/17068.\n\nSee discussion on HFMD in Hand, foot & mouth disease - USA (08): (CT, OH) 20161001.4529788. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe illness manifests itself in small blisters around the mouth, hands, and feet, and is usually preceded by a slight fever, usually not a high fever but one that can last for a few days, said local health officials. \n\nParents in the district were reminded that if their child is experiencing a fever or rash on their hands, feet, and/or mouth, they should be kept home from school until at least 24 hours after the fever breaks and exposed vesicles are dry. \n\nThere is no treatment for this ailment, but it rarely requires more than a few days home and some over-the-counter medications to lower the fever and treat any discomfort, health officials said. In most cases, the disease is mild and self-limiting, but more severe clinical presentation with neurological symptoms such as meningitis, encephalitis and polio-like paralysis may occur.\n\nIn the 1st 6 months of 2016, China and Japan are reporting different patterns of the viral disease compared with last year [2015].\n\nIn China through 30 Jun, a total of 1 305 593 cases of HFMD including 122 deaths were reported in 2016. This includes 452 668 cases reported in June alone. This compares with the same period in 2015 when China reported 984 699 cases of HFMD and 28 deaths.\n\nThe reverse is true in Japan this year to date. Japan saw a big HFMD year in 2015; however, so far this year the numbers are way down. Through the 1st 7 months of the year, Japan has reported 17 387 HFMD cases. This compares to the same period in 2015 when the country reported 216 971 cases of HFMD.\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the Enterovirus genus (group). This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 is the commonest cause of HFMD in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Enterovirus 71 has also been associated with HFMD and outbreaks of this disease.\n\nEV-71 has been implicated in HFMD outbreaks in South East Asia over the several years. EV 71 is a non-polio enterovirus.\n\nComplications associated with HFMD caused by the more pathogenic EV-71 strain include encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema or hemorrhage and myocarditis. Most deaths in HFMD occur as a result of pulmonary edema or hemorrhage.\n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of HFMD in earlier posts by this moderator.\n\nA map of China can be accessed at https://sites.google.com/site/chinamapsite/, and of Japan at https://binged.it/2bpy0W5. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/155.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: Bernama]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See ProMED-mail: Hand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia: alert 20160618.4295321 for more information on HFMD in Malaysia this year (2016). \n\n[byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of HFMD in earlier posts by this moderator.
