you have young children.\n\nPiedmont doctors are seeing an increase in hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nIt's a viral infection that can come with painful blisters in the mouth and on the hands and feet.\n\nDr. Amy Jo Wallace is a pediatrician with Brenner Children's Hospital in the Kernersville Pediatrics office.\n\nWallace has seen a number of recent cases.\n\n'The past several weeks we have seen a lot of cases of hand, foot and mouth,' she said.\n\nIt's more common in infants and toddlers and is more prevalent during spring and summer.\n\nCone Health pediatricians report seeing several cases recently.\n\nNovant Health reports that its Meadowlark Pediatrics office has seen about 25 patients in the past few weeks with 2 people coming in today [26 Jul 2016].\n\nThe virus is contagious and can spread easily at summer camps, day care centers or other environments where kids are in close proximity.\n\nThe Learning Place, a day care affiliated with Novant Health, is taking precautions.\n\n'Every day, especially for our infants and toddlers, we sanitize all toys in a bleach-water solution,' said Nancy Hollis, childcare manager at The Learning Place.\n\nThere is no medication doctors can prescribe for hand, foot and mouth disease because it is a viral infection.\n\nDoctors say it will usually go away on its own in a few days.\n\nParents can use medicine to reduce fever and should also make sure their child stays hydrated.\n\nIf a child is unable to drink because of blisters, Wallace says an ice pop is another option.\n\nHand-washing is the best preventative measure.\n\nAdults can get hand, foot and mouth disease, but it is not as common as it is among children.\n\n[Byline: Natalie Wilson]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Other genotypes include coxsackievirus A16 (CAV16) and enterovirus 71 (EV71). Although CAV6 is commonly associated with hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) and herpangina, it had not been of concern until the 2012 global outbreaks of HFMD.\n\nIn Thailand, HFMD usually occurs during the rainy season (June-August); average incidence during 2007-2011 was 20.2 cases per 100 000 population. In 2012, an extensive outbreak of HFMD occurred; the incidence rate was 3-fold higher than the average incidence rate of 58.15 cases per 100 000 population or more than 36 000 cases; the 2012 outbreak included 2 fatal cases of EV71 encephalitis.\n\nGenerally, the clinical manifestations of HFMD were fever; drooling, and refusal to eat (among young children); painful lesions in the mouth, especially on the soft palate; and vesicular rashes on the palms and feet.\n\nExcerpted from\nPuenpa J, Chieochansin T, Linsuwanon P, et al: Hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by coxsackievirus A6, Thailand, 2012. 'Hand, foot and mouth disease can be spread to little ones,' LCHD Administrator Julie Schilling said. 'It spreads by cough, sneeze or by contact with stool. It's typical in child care facilities.'\n\nDaycare operations and preschools can be ripe ground for communicable diseases that travel by close personal contact, proximity to dirty diapers and shared saliva or mucus on toys and other surfaces. Adults can spread the virus to children without having symptoms themselves. 'It can be spread pretty easily,' Schilling said.\n\nSymptoms are a general feeling of being unwell, a fever, painful sores in the throat and mouth, and rash and blisters on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, according to Schilling. Mouth and throat sores can affect a baby or child's appetite, so intake of fluid and food should be encouraged.\n\n'There's no specific treatment,' Schilling said. 'Take comfort measures and watch them. If they don't eat or drink for a time, call a health care provider.' Comfort measures can include mouthwashes or sprays that numb mouth pain and over-the-counter medications other than aspirin to relieve pain and fever. Aspirin should not be given to children.\n\nVaccinations have not been developed for HFMD, and there is no treatment.\n\nPrevention tips\n---------------\nThe Centers for Disease Control give tips for lessening the risks of sharing or contracting HFMD:\n- Keep children home from school or daycare if they have symptoms.\n- Wash hands often with soap and water, especially after changing diapers and using the toilet.\n- Clean and disinfect commonly touched surfaces and soiled items, including toys.\n- Avoid close contact such as kissing, hugging, or sharing eating utensils or cups with people with hand, foot and mouth disease.\n- If a person has mouth sores, it might be painful to swallow. However, it is important for people with hand, foot and mouth disease to drink enough liquids to prevent dehydration (loss of body fluids). If a person cannot swallow enough liquids, they may need to receive them through an IV in their vein.\n\n[Byline: Cindy Lutzi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Keokuk is a city and a county seat of Lee County, Iowa, United States. The usual peak season is from May to July, with a possible smaller winter peak from October to December. Schools, institutions and play facilities should observe our guidelines and health advice against outbreaks to better protect young children who are more prone to both diseases,' a spokesman for the CHP said.\n\nThe number of institutional HFMD outbreaks increased from 5 (affecting 16 persons) in the week ending 30 Apr [2016] to 30 (124 persons) last week. As of 17 May [2016], 13 (42 persons) had been reported this week. In the past 4 weeks, kindergartens and child care centres (KG/CCCs) reported most outbreaks (63 per cent), followed by secondary schools (20 per cent) and primary schools (17 per cent).\n\nAs for EV71 infection in 2016, as of 17 May, 3 cases were recorded with no severe cases or deaths. In 2015, 56 cases including 6 with severe complications were filed. Regarding severe pediatric enterovirus infection other than EV71 and poliovirus, 3 cases had been recorded so far this year [2016] while 8 were recorded in 2015, with no deaths in both years.\n\nHealth officials also note some neighboring areas have also entered the peak season since late April. The Health and Family Planning Commission of Guangdong Province reported 88 366 HFMD cases to date, including 3 deaths, rising 72 per cent from last year [2015]. In Taiwan, according to the Centers for Disease Control, the EV activity is increasing and 17 000 EV consultations were recorded last week, rising 27.8 per cent from the preceding week.\n\n'HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as Coxsackievirus and EV71. It is clinically characterized by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,' a CHP spokesman said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n- Maintain good air circulation;\n- Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n- Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n- Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n- Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding one part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n- Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted;\n- Avoid going to overcrowded places; and\n- Parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\nRead the CHP's page on HFMD and EV71 infection (http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/16354.html) for more information. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198.]", "summary": "Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n- Maintain good air circulation;\n- Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n- Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n- Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n- Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding one part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n- Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted;\n- Avoid going to overcrowded places; It is the highest number since 2012.\n\nThe most affected areas are Yaeyama, and the southern and middle parts of Okinawa main island including Naha. There have been a total of 913 cases in the prefecture from 1 Jan [2016] through 19 Jun [2016]. 39.9 per cent of the patients were less than 1 year old, 19.5 per cent were 1-2 years old.\n\nThe hand, foot and mouth disease is a common infectious viral illness that mostly affects infants and children younger than 5 years of age. The symptoms include fever, mouth sores and a skin rash on hands and feet. Children get it easily especially in the summer. In rare cases it can lead to meningitis, which is the reason for the warning. The virus spreads through sneezing and coughing, and parents of small children are advised to wash their hands carefully after changing diapers of their infants.\n\n--\nJennifer Dixon\n<dixon.jenny@gmail.com>\n\n[ProMED thanks Jennifer Dixon for submitting this report.\n\nAs of 8 Jun 2016, there have been 3856 hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) cases reported in Japan in 2016. The 18 241 infections so far is the 2nd highest for the 1st 21 weeks of a year, exceeded only by the 21 102 in 2012. In contrast, the median number for the 1st 21 weeks over the past 5 years is 8193.\n\nAssociate Professor Chong Chia Yin, senior infectious disease consultant at KK Women's and Children's Hospital, said more than 200 children have been hospitalised at KKH for HFMD this year [2016]. She said: 'Most of these children were admitted for fever and poor feeding, mild dehydration or febrile fits due to their high fever. None suffered serious complications.'\n\nSerious complications are rare, but the infection could damage the brain, lungs or heart. Symptoms of HFMD include fever, ulcers in the mouth and tongue, blisters on hand, feet and bum, poor appetite and lethargy. A child can get dehydrated from not drinking enough because it hurts to do so.\n\nDuring an outbreak of HFMD in 2000-2001 associated with the more dangerous EV71 strain, there were 7 deaths.\n\nThe current epidemic has been fuelled in part by parents who send their sick kids to childcare centres, and refuse to take them home when asked to. Marjorie Zaccheus, principal of Presbyterian Community Services Tampines Childcare Centre, which has been hit by a spate of cases, said that when she suspects a child has HFMD, she keeps them away from other children and asks their parents to take them home. 'The parents say they are coming but they don't turn up until closing time. Others don't answer the phone,' said Madam Zaccheus. She said holding full-time jobs is no excuse.\n\nThe children are checked for fever and ulcers or rash when they arrive. But Madam Zaccheus said sometimes, the person bringing the child is not a parent or guardian. 'In these cases, I have to accept them. I have no alternative.' But the centre, which has 79 children, does not have the resources to effectively quarantine a sick child. It had 20 cases in the last month and a half.\n\n[A parent], 38, whose daughter, aged 3, was one of the 20 infected, said: 'It's irresponsible for parents to leave a sick child here.' He added: 'Not only is the child already uncomfortable because of the sickness, they would feel lonely and isolated if they have to be separated from the other children.' Despite the high rates of infection at the centre, many parents have chosen not to keep their children away.\n\nAdults too can get HFMD, and it is usually more severe. [The parent] recalls when his wife caught the infection from their infant son some years back. She was sick in bed for a week with a high fever and had a hard time eating because her mouth was full of ulcers.\n\n[byline: salma@sph.com.sg and rkurohi@sph.com.sg]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of HFMD in Singapore in ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20160505.4203981. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/150.]", "summary": "\n\n[byline: salma@sph.com.sg and rkurohi@sph.com.sg]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[See discussion of HFMD in Singapore in ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20160505.4203981. Uyen Phuong, edited]\nhttp://www.saigon-gpdaily.com.vn/Health/2016/5/118814/\n\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease has reoccurred in 61 cities and provinces across the country, although the number of cases declined by 23.2 percent compared to the same period last year [2015]. There has been no vaccine or medication available at peak season for the disease.\n\nThe Department of Preventive Medicine under the Ministry of Health on 12 May [2016] warned parents of an outbreak of the disease during the hot weather.\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease, or HFMD, is a contagious illness that is caused by different viruses. Infants and children younger than 5 years old are more likely to get this disease. Symptoms usually begin with a fever, reduced appetite, sore throat, and a feeling of being unwell. A day or 2 after the fever starts, painful sores can develop in the mouth. A skin rash with flat red spots may also develop on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. Sometimes, a rash also occurs on the knees, elbows, and buttocks. This rash may blister but won't itch.\n\nHFMD infection cases are recorded year round, yet it escalates in March to May and September to October.\n\nThe Ministry of Health said that although since the beginning of the year [2016] cases of HFMD have decreased by 23.2 percent compared to the same period last year, most cities and provinces in the country have reported cases. Meanwhile, there is no vaccine to prevent the disease, but people can take simple steps like washing hands often and practicing good hygiene to reduce the risk of infection.\n\nTo minimize HFMD cases amongst children, parents should keep personal hygiene by washing hands many times a day for kids; adults should wash their hands before cooking, carrying babies, after going to the toilet, and not let babies put their hands into mouths, and regularly disinfect house floors and toys. Preschools must clean floors and disinfect toys. Ill kids should be isolated at home to prevent transmission to others.\n\n[Byline: Minh Khang]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the past decade, HFMD has become more predominant in the Asia-Pacific region and has become a pressing problem for global public health.\n\nIn Viet Nam, HFMD circulates year-round in most provinces, with 2 associated peaks, from March to May and from September to December, as stated above. The southern region is the most affected area and accounted for over 60% of cases for the whole country.\n\nIn 2011 Viet Nam experienced a significant increase in HFMD activity with 112 370 cases and 169 deaths reported from 63/63 provinces.\n\nThe response of the Viet Nam Ministry of Health included: (1) strengthened surveillance, early detection and treatment; (2) enhanced communication on HFMD preventive measures, including a national campaign to prevent and control HFMD; (3) improved clinical management of cases and hospital infection control practices through training of hospital staff; and (4) training of epidemiological, clinical, laboratory and public health staff to raise awareness and reduce morbidity and mortality.\n\nWHO has developed and disseminated WPRO (Western Pacific region) guidelines on clinical management and a public health response to HFMD.\n\nWHO has provided technical support to the Ministry of Health to:\n- establish sentinel surveillance;\n- improve clinical case management, particularly for severe cases requiring intensive care;\n- improve laboratory diagnosis;\n- identify risk factors for severe cases and deaths;\n- evaluate control and prevention measures;\n- support the conduct of research studies.\n\n(Excerpted from http://www.wpro.who.int/vietnam/topics/hand_foot_mouth/factsheet/en/). - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152.]", "summary": "\n\nWHO has provided technical support to the Ministry of Health to:\n- establish sentinel surveillance;\n- improve clinical case management, particularly for severe cases requiring intensive care;\n- improve laboratory diagnosis;\n- identify risk factors for severe cases and deaths;\n- evaluate control and prevention measures;\n- support the conduct of research studies. \n\nThe response of the Viet Nam Ministry of Health included: (1) strengthened surveillance, early detection and treatment; There were 1052 HFMD cases from 17 Apr to 23 Apr this year [2016], which is the highest number since mid-October 2013, when 1247 weekly cases were reported, according to MOH figures.\n\nThe numbers started increasing in February this year [2016]: there were 587 cases reported from 7 Feb to 13 Feb, rising to 756, 2 weeks later. The number of cases rose above the 900-mark in early March, before hitting the current high late last month [April 2016]. As of 23 Apr, 12 166 cases in total have been reported to MOH so far this year. In contrast, 8835 cases were reported between January and 25 Apr last year [2015].\n\nInfectious disease expert Leong Hoe Nam of Mount Elizabeth Novena Hospital said the upward trend will likely continue in the next 2-3 weeks, and it could become an epidemic. 'The number that exceeds 1000 is very significant: it tells us that many people have not been exposed to (the virus). We have a fresh group of people getting exposed to it and in turn this 1000 will spread easily to another 1000 to 2000 people,' said Dr Leong. 'I think this is going to be an epidemic; if not we are already at the threshold of a new epidemic,' Dr Leong added, while pointing out that the current strain is not life-threatening.\n\nHFMD can be transmitted from person to person by direct contact with bodily fluids such as saliva. While both adults and children can get HFMD, children below the age of 5 are more susceptible.\n\nAs more cases have been reported, childcare centers have been working to deal with the problem. At Tai Pei childcare centre, a total of 14 HFMD cases had been reported since 2 Mar [2016] with about half of them affecting children below 3 years of age. The centre stepped up hygiene standards, and has been clear of HFMD since 15 Apr [2016]. 'To stop the chain of transmission, sterilization is very important. We even have to sterilize stationery. Usually, we only sterilized the common areas. Children's belongings like toys are sterilized once they've been played with. Everything that they touch, even charts and the walls along the corridor are all sterilized,' said the school's principal, Drolma Teh. 'We also take children's temperatures and conduct health checks up to 3 times a day,' Ms Teh added. Before the outbreak, children temperatures were taken twice daily.\n\nFour childcare centers on MOH's watch list\n------------------------------------------\nChildcare centers with more than 10 HFMD cases or with more than 13 percent of the enrolment contracting the virus and a transmission period of more than 16 days are put on a watch list on the MOH website. A total of 4 childcare centers are currently on the list: PCF Sparkletots Preschool at Sembawang, PCF Sparkletots Preschool at Paya Lebar, The Little Skool-House at Kent Vale and MY World at Woodlands Circle.\n\nIn a statement to Channel NewsAsia, the PAP Community Foundation (PCF) said: 'Several cases have been reported in the outbreak of HFMD at PCF at Sembawang and PCF at Paya Lebar centers.' The PCF added that most of the children have recovered and no new cases have been reported at PCF at Sembawang and PCF at Paya Lebar centers since 26 Apr and 20 Apr [2016], respectively.\n\n'During outbreaks of infectious diseases, our centers would immediately increase the frequency of such precautionary measures and activate additional steps such as suspending large group activities to minimize contact between children, and where necessary, engage professional cleaners to disinfect the premises.'\n\nA spokesperson from Little Skool-House International, which manages Little Skool-House at Kent Vale, said it takes all necessary precautionary measures to detect and prevent the spread of HFMD. 'This includes conducting health checks every morning before a child enters school, and subsequent checks done when needed through the day. There are regular washing and sanitization of classrooms, children's cutlery and toys.' 'Should there be a confirmed case, the class affected will be isolated and communal activities such as morning assembly will cease,' the spokesperson added. A parent [...] said 'the school should take precautionary measures and ensure the premises are clean.'\n\nMOH has been approached for comments on the current situation.\n\n[Byline: Lim Jia Qi]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[In the past decade, HFMD has become more predominant in the Asia-Pacific region and has become a pressing problem for global public health. After a large outbreak in 2008, the incidence of HFMD in Singapore has varied from 346.4/100 000 in 2009 to 698.8/100 000 in 2012. Coxsakievirus A16 (CVA16) and coxsakievirus A6 (CVA6) were predominant in HFMD cases. Moreover, about half of the cases were co-infected with 2 or 3 pathogens.\n\nHFMD usually attacks children under the age of 5, causing mild symptoms including fever, rash, vesiculation [blistering], and inappetence, but some symptoms are extremely severe and are accompanied by several neurological complications such as encephalitis, encephalomeningitis and neurogenic pneumonedema; circulatory disturbance; and can even lead to death.\n\nHuman enteroviruses (new enterovirus, coxsakievirus and echovirus) are the most common pathogenic agents of HFMD. Specimens initially considered to be infected with CVA16 were found to be co-infected with CVA16 and EV71 after inspection.\n\nAlthough HFMD is classically a mild disease, large outbreaks in the Asia-Pacific region have been described since 1997, with a high incidence of fatal cardiopulmonary and neurological complications, particularly when the causative virus is EV-71.\n\nThe development of HFMD vaccines has rapidly expanded and pre-clinical studies are already finished and several clinical phases even completed, there are still no available vaccines and effective anti-virus therapies for HFMD.\n\n(Excerpted/edited from Z-C Zhuang, et al., Viruses. 2015 Dec; 7(12): 6400-6411. http://www.mdpi.com/1999-4915/7/12/2947.) - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/150.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\n'During outbreaks of infectious diseases, our centers would immediately increase the frequency of such precautionary measures and activate additional steps such as suspending large group activities to minimize contact between children, and where necessary, engage professional cleaners to disinfect the premises.' \n\nHFMD usually attacks children under the age of 5, causing mild symptoms including fever, rash, vesiculation [blistering], and inappetence, but some symptoms are extremely severe and are accompanied by several neurological complications such as encephalitis, encephalomeningitis and neurogenic pneumonedema; circulatory disturbance; and can even lead to death. 'It seems more prevalent this year than last year, and just seems to keep spreading and spreading.' Ramirez says doctors won't prescribe antibiotics, because this is a virus. Controlling those symptoms is important with ibuprofen or tylenol.'\n\nSanger Unified posted a message on its Facebook page warning parents that a number of students got the virus. In Europe and North America, it is not a notifiable disease but epidemiological studies of outbreaks caused by different EV-A types (CV-A16, CV-A10 and CV-A6) have been described in recent years. EV-71 also has been detected in several European countries and the USA and, although rare, infections with fatal outcomes have been reported.\n\nHFMD generally is a mild illness that causes sores in or on the mouth and on the hands, feet, and sometimes the buttocks and legs. The sores may be painful. The illness usually doesn't last more than a week or so. The disease is common in children but can also occur in adults. It can occur at any time of year but is most common in the summer and fall.\n\nThe virus spreads easily through coughing and sneezing. It can also spread through infected stool, such as when you change a diaper or when a young child gets stool on his or her hands and then touches objects that other children might then put in their mouths. Often the disease breaks out within a community.\n\nIt usually takes 3 to 6 days for a person to get symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease after being exposed to the virus.\n\n(Partly excerpted/edited from http://www.webmd.com/children/guide/hand-foot-and-mouth-disease-topic-overview.) - Mod.LK\n\nA map of California may be found at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/204.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nIt usually takes 3 to 6 days for a person to get symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease after being exposed to the virus. \nCases of a contagious virus are on the rise across the Central Valley [California] -- and schools are taking extra measures to protect students from hand, foot and mouth disease. ProMED regrets the delay in posting and the original error. - CopyEd.MSP]\n\nA variation of coxsackievirus causing hand, foot and mouth disease [HFMD] is affecting many local children [in the San Luis Obispo, CA area], doctors say.\n\nThe airborne virus is highly contagious and causes those affected to develop blisters on their hands, feet, and mouths. These lesions can be accompanied by a fever, sore throat, and severe discomfort. The blisters, which can last up to a week and be quite painful, can make doing everyday activities difficult.\n\n'She couldn't walk for a couple days because she had so many blisters on her feet,' says a local mom about her one-year-old daughter. 'So she was in the stroller or in our arms, which was really hard. It's just really hard to see our kid in pain and not really be able to do anything to help them.'\n\nAlthough people of any age can catch it, the virus is especially common among very young populations. 'Eventually, 100 percent of the children will be exposed to the coxsackievirus virus,' says Dr. Rene Bravo of Bravo Pediatrics. However, this does not mean all children will develop symptoms. About 20 percent of those exposed to the virus will catch it.\n\nDr. Bravo recommends that children who catch the virus be taken out of school or daycare to prevent the spread of the disease. 'Wait until the blisters heal and no new one shows up, and then you are welcome to come back to daycare,' says owner of Little Blossoms Daycare and Preschool.\n\nAlthough there is no immediate cure, at-home treatments can be used to make the affected person more comfortable. According to Dr. Bravo, over-the-counter medicines like Tylenol and Advil can help with pain, while calamine lotion can help calm the skin. If you suspect that your child has hand, foot and mouth disease, take a picture on your phone and email it to your pediatrician to save yourself a trip into the doctor's office.\n\n[Byline: Amanda Starrantino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common human syndrome caused by highly contagious intestinal viruses. HFMD is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by an enterovirus, most commonly coxsackievirus A16. However, other enteroviruses like coxsackievirus A10 or A6 have also been detected in outbreaks. Internationally, enterovirus 71 is another common etiologic agent.\n\nHFMD is highly contagious and is transmitted by nasopharyngeal secretions such as saliva or nasal mucus, by direct contact, or by fecal-oral transmission. Preventive measures include avoiding direct contact with infected individuals (including keeping infected children home from school), proper cleaning of shared utensils, disinfecting contaminated surfaces, and proper hand hygiene. These measures have been shown to be effective in decreasing the transmission of the viruses responsible for HFMD.\n\nA diagnosis usually can be made by the presenting signs and symptoms alone. If the diagnosis is unclear, a throat swab or stool specimen may be taken to identify the virus by culture.\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. Currently, there is no specific curative treatment for hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nReference: Sarma, N (March-April 2013): 'Hand, foot and mouth disease: current scenario and Indian perspective.' Indian Journal of Dermatology, Venereology, and Leprology 79 (2): 165-175. doi:10.4103/0378-6323.107631. PMID 23442455.\n\nDisease management typically focuses on achieving symptomatic relief. Pain from the sores may be eased with the use of analgesic medications. Infection in older children, adolescents, and adults is typically mild and lasts approximately one week but may occasionally run a longer course. Fever reducers and lukewarm baths can help decrease body temperature.\n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. Non-neurologic complications such as inflammation of the heart, fluid in the lungs, or bleeding into the lungs may also occur.\n\nCurrently, there is no vaccine available against coxsackievirus-associated HFMD. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/1036.]", "summary": "\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. \n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. The disease is not required to be reported by physicians.\n\nSix calls were received from schools who say they took their children to doctors who diagnosed their children with hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nThe reports are troubling to some who have seen the diagnosed children being taken around town into businesses. According to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC), the disease is readily spread by close personal contact, contact with contaminated surfaces and objects such as doorknobs, and even through the air from coughing and sneezing. Some businesses are concerned that affected children may spread the disease to customers.\n\nAccording to one report, a parent with an affected child was asked to leave a Goldendale store and told the disease was highly contagious.\n\n'What am I supposed to do?' the parent is said to have responded. 'I need to go shopping, and I can't leave him at home.'\n\nThe CDC says there is no vaccine to protect against the viruses that cause hand, foot and mouth disease. A person can lower their risk of being infected by:\n\n- Washing hands often with soap and water, especially after changing diapers and using the toilet.\n- Cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces and soiled items, including toys.\n- Avoiding close contact such as kissing, hugging, or sharing eating utensils or cups with people with hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nIf a person has mouth sores, it might be painful to swallow. However, it is important for people with hand, foot and mouth disease to drink enough liquids to prevent dehydration (loss of body fluids). If a person cannot swallow enough liquids, they may need to receive them through an IV in their vein.\n\nThere is no specific treatment for the disease, the CDC states. The airborne virus is highly contagious and causes those affected to develop blisters on their hands, feet, and mouths. These lesions can be accompanied by a fever, sore throat, and severe discomfort. The blisters, which can last up to a week and be quite painful, can make doing everyday activities difficult.\n\n'She couldn't walk for a couple days because she had so many blisters on her feet,' says a local mom about her one-year-old daughter. 'So she was in the stroller or in our arms, which was really hard. It's just really hard to see our kid in pain and not really be able to do anything to help them.'\n\nAlthough people of any age can catch it, the virus is especially common among very young populations. 'Eventually, 100 percent of the children will be exposed to the coxsackievirus virus,' says Dr. Rene Bravo of Bravo Pediatrics. However, this does not mean all children will develop symptoms. About 20 percent of those exposed to the virus will catch it.\n\nDr. Bravo recommends that children who catch the virus be taken out of school or daycare to prevent the spread of the disease. 'Wait until the blisters heal and no new one shows up, and then you are welcome to come back to daycare,' says owner of Little Blossoms Daycare and Preschool.\n\nAlthough there is no immediate cure, at-home treatments can be used to make the affected person more comfortable. According to Dr. Bravo, over-the-counter medicines like Tylenol and Advil can help with pain, while calamine lotion can help calm the skin. If you suspect that your child has hand, foot and mouth disease, take a picture on your phone and email it to your pediatrician to save yourself a trip into the doctor's office.\n\n[Byline: Amanda Starrantino]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common human syndrome caused by highly contagious intestinal viruses. HFMD is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Hand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by an enterovirus, most commonly coxsackievirus A16. However, other enteroviruses like coxsackievirus A10 or A6 have also been detected in outbreaks. Internationally, enterovirus 71 is another common etiologic agent.\n\nHFMD is highly contagious and is transmitted by nasopharyngeal secretions such as saliva or nasal mucus, by direct contact, or by fecal-oral transmission. Preventive measures include avoiding direct contact with infected individuals (including keeping infected children home from school), proper cleaning of shared utensils, disinfecting contaminated surfaces, and proper hand hygiene. These measures have been shown to be effective in decreasing the transmission of the viruses responsible for HFMD.\n\nA diagnosis usually can be made by the presenting signs and symptoms alone. If the diagnosis is unclear, a throat swab or stool specimen may be taken to identify the virus by culture.\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. Currently, there is no specific curative treatment for hand, foot and mouth disease.\n\nReference: Sarma, N (March-April 2013): 'Hand, foot and mouth disease: current scenario and Indian perspective.' Indian Journal of Dermatology, Venereology, and Leprology 79 (2): 165-175. doi:10.4103/0378-6323.107631. PMID 23442455.\n\nDisease management typically focuses on achieving symptomatic relief. Pain from the sores may be eased with the use of analgesic medications. Infection in older children, adolescents, and adults is typically mild and lasts approximately one week but may occasionally run a longer course. Fever reducers and lukewarm baths can help decrease body temperature.\n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. Non-neurologic complications such as inflammation of the heart, fluid in the lungs, or bleeding into the lungs may also occur.\n\nCurrently, there is no vaccine available against coxsackievirus-associated HFMD. - Mod.UBA\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/284.]", "summary": "\n\nMedications are usually not needed as hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral disease that typically gets better on its own. \n\nA minority of individuals with hand, foot and mouth disease may require hospital admission due to uncommon neurologic complications such as inflammation of the brain, inflammation of the meninges, or acute flaccid paralysis. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common human syndrome caused by highly contagious intestinal viruses. The significance is that EV71 Inactivated Vaccine has now formally begun usage in Guangxi. However, older children and adults can also get it. HFMD typically presents with a prodrome of non-specific symptoms that last 1-2 days, followed by a rash that lasts 7 to 10 days. The exanthem is usually a macular, maculopapular, or vesicular rash on the hands, feet, and buttocks. The enanthem is similar in the mouth.\n\nThe disease may be complicated by meningitis, encephalitis, flaccid paralysis, or myopericarditis. The diagnosis is made clinically, but PCR can be performed on samples from the throat, stool, urine, and vesicular fluid. Treatment is supportive.\n\nIn January 2016, China approved Sinovac's vaccine for HFMD. No vaccine existed before December 2015. But in December 2015, the China FDA approved the 1st vaccine against the virus, Enterovirus 71 (EV71), made by the Institute of Medical Biology at the Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences. But competition was not far behind: the agency approved a 2nd vaccine against the virus in January 2016, this one developed by Sinovac ($SVA).\n\nHaving 2 vaccines against HFMD made locally is a boon for China's public health and local manufacturing sectors. While other countries in Asia have reported cases and outbreaks of HFMD, China reported far more cases in 2014 than its neighbors did: 2.7 million cases and 394 deaths, according to the World Health Organization. In contrast, Japan reported 79 000 cases and no deaths, and Singapore reported 21 400 cases and no deaths.\n\n'EV71 vaccine is the 1st innovative vaccine product successfully developed and commercialized by Sinovac,' said Weidong Yin, Sinovac CEO and president, in a statement. 'We envision opportunities to collaborate with relevant government authorities to further test the safety and immunogenicity of the EV71 vaccine in order to provide scientific evidence of using this vaccine on a broader population.'\n\nSinovac will manufacture the EV71 vaccine at a facility in Beijing, which is expected to produce 20 million doses annually.\n\nThe vaccine is a 2-dose regimen for infants aged between 6 months and 3 years. The company expects to receive its Good Manufacturing Practices license in early 2016, after which it will immediately commence production of the EV71 vaccine, Sinovac said in the statement. It expects to have the jab on the market 4-5 months later.\n\nThe company plans to go through the private pay sector of the Chinese vaccine market, where it has experience selling hepatitis and flu vaccines. This strategy allows Sinovac to leverage its existing sales networks to quickly boost sales of the EV71 vaccine. However, not all cases were confirmed to be HFMD.\n\nOn 26 Mar 2016, Nobding lower secondary school (LSS) in Wangdue reported 12 female students displaying symptoms similar to HFMD. The school's principal, Kelzang Wangyal, said that the girls were immediately isolated from the rest of the students, with health officials consulted in the nearest basic health unit (BHU). Health officials from the Bajo regional hospital ruled out HFMD, and the girls were found to be suffering from allergies. 'All the girls recovered the next day after the case was reported and are now attending their regular classes,' Kelzang Wangyal said.\n\nBikhar LSS in Trashigang also reported that 27 students were suffering from fever, headache and sores in the mouth. BLSS's health in-charge Sungyel said that while HFMD has not been confirmed, the students were isolated.\n\nMeanwhile, Lingmithang primary school in Mongar sent 2 students home yesterday [3 Apr 2016]. A total of 48 cases have been recorded there so far. The primary school's health in-charge, Saha Dev Rai, said that 2 students of the 48 have recovered and are attending regular classes, while others are still on leave. 'I personally go to students during lunch break and ask them to wash hands with soap before eating their packed-lunch,' the health in-charge said. All the class teachers are asked to check their students for symptoms.\n\nChangjiji satellite clinic reported 4 cases, while the Motithang satellite clinic and Genekha BHU reported 2 cases each. Bumthang hospital also reported 21 cases from Chamkhar. Thimphu schools alone reported 85 cases between 19-31 Mar [2016]. Children suffering from the disease are aged between 5 and 11 years.\n\n[Byline: Dechen Tshomo]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Until 1956, Bhutan had 9 provinces, but currently the country is divided into 20 dzongkhags. A dzongkhag is an administrative and judicial district of Bhutan.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. However, the 2 diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Hoof and mouth disease is caused by a picornavirus, the prototypical member of the _Aphthovirus_ genus. Hand, foot, and mouth disease, on the other hand, is caused by an enterovirus, most commonly coxsackievirus A16. However, other enteroviruses (such as coxsackievirus A10) can cause hand, foot, and mouth disease. Recently, coxsackievirus A6 has been detected in outbreaks. Internationally, enterovirus 71 is a common etiologic agent.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is a common illness in young children, with worldwide distribution. Recent large outbreaks have been reported in Cambodia, China, Japan, Korea, Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan, and Viet Nam [excerpted from http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/yellowbook/2016/infectious-diseases-related-to-travel/hand-foot-mouth-disease].\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is spread from person to person through coughing and sneezing, or contact with blister fluid or feces (stool) of an infected person. Risk of infection is decreased by:\n\n- Washing your hands often with soap and water\n- Disinfecting dirty surfaces and soiled items\n- Avoiding close contact such as kissing, hugging, or sharing eating utensils or cups with infected people\n\nNo vaccine existed before December 2015, but in December 2015, the China FDA approved the 1st vaccine against the virus, Enterovirus 71 (EV71), made by the Institute of Medical Biology at the Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences. A 2nd vaccine against the virus developed by Sinovac came out in January 2016. See ProMED-mail post 'Hand, foot & mouth disease - China: (BJ, GX) vaccine 20160329.4124126.' - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/154.]", "summary": "\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease (also called hoof-and-mouth disease), which affects cattle, sheep, and swine. Risk of infection is decreased by:\n\n- Washing your hands often with soap and water\n- Disinfecting dirty surfaces and soiled items\n- Avoiding close contact such as kissing, hugging, or sharing eating utensils or cups with infected people\n\nNo vaccine existed before December 2015, but in December 2015, the China FDA approved the 1st vaccine against the virus, Enterovirus 71 (EV71), made by the Institute of Medical Biology at the Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences. China (05): (HK) update, school outbreaks, EV71", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3821764", "date": "2015-11-26 18:10:31", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (05): (HONG KONG) UPDATE, SCHOOL OUTBREAKS, ENTEROVIRUS 71\n***********************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 25 Nov 2015\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/severe-pediatric-enterovirus-71-infection-investigated-in-hong-kong-80427/\n\n\nHong Kong health officials announced today they are investigating a case of severe pediatric enterovirus (EV) 71 infection as well as an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) at a secondary school in Eastern District and urged the public to be vigilant against the disease.\n\nThe patient is a 13-year-old boy with good past health. He has presented with fever, sore throat, headache, neck stiffness and rash since 7 Nov 2015. He was taken to the Accident and Emergency Department of Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital on 14 Nov 2015 and was admitted on the same day for further management. The clinical diagnosis was meningitis and he has been in a stable condition all along. His stool specimen tested positive for EV71 upon testing by the Centre for Health Protection's (CHP) Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Initial investigation revealed that the patient had no recent travel history. His home contacts remain asymptomatic.\n\nA CHP spokesman noted that there was a HFMD [hand foot mouth disease] outbreak in the secondary school in Eastern District, which the patient attended as a form-2 student. Apart from the patient, 12 form-2 students, comprising 9 boys and 3 girls aged 13 to 14, have developed fever, oral ulcers, rash and vesicles on their hands or feet since 10 Nov 2015. All affected pupils sought medical treatment and no hospitalisation is required. They are now in a stable condition. Officers of the CHP have conducted a site visit and advised the staff of the school on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The school has been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n'EV71 is among the causative agents for HFMD. The infection is transmitted from person to person by direct contact with nose and throat discharges, saliva, fluid from blisters, or the stool of infected persons. Good personal and environmental hygiene are the most important measures to prevent EV71 infection,' a spokesman for the CHP said. This is the 56th laboratory-confirmed EV71 case in Hong Kong in 2015 and the 6th case classified as severe.\n\nAs of 7 Nov 2015, a total of 736 hospital admissions of HFMD have been reported in 2015, higher than the same reporting period in 2014 (n=327).\n\nHFMD is typically a benign and self-limiting disease. Most common in young children, it presents as fever, oral lesions and rash on the hands, feet and buttocks. The oral lesions consist of rapidly ulcerating vesicles on the buccal mucosa, tongue, palate and gums. The rash consists of papulovesicular lesions on the palms, fingers and soles, which generally persist for 7-10 days, and maculopapular lesions on the buttocks.\n\nHFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the Enterovirus genus (group). This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nCoxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Enterovirus 71 has also been associated with hand, foot, and mouth disease and outbreaks of this disease. EV-71 has been implicated in HFMD outbreaks in Southeast Asia over the several years. EV 71 is a non-polio enterovirus.\n\nComplications associated with HFMD caused by the more pathogenic EV-71 strain include encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema or hemorrhage and myocarditis. Most deaths in HFMD occur as a result of pulmonary edema or hemorrhage. According to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), there is no vaccine to protect against the viruses that cause hand, foot, and mouth disease.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The above information is from a CHP press release:\nhttp://www.chp.gov.hk/en/content/116/42246.html\n\nFor a discussion of hand-foot-mouth disease, please see moderator comments in the prior ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Oman 20151116.3794098.\n\nMaps of Hong Kong can be found at http://www.travelchinaguide.com/images/map/hongkong/hongkong-map.gif and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198. - Mod.ML]", "summary": "http://www.chp.gov.hk/en/content/116/42246.html\n\nFor a discussion of hand-foot-mouth disease, please see moderator comments in the prior ProMED-mail post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Oman 20151116.3794098. This individual also described possible HFMD in his child, and in other children in the resort.\n\nWe wonder whether the broader ProMED community is aware of an ongoing HFMD outbreak in Caribbean resort areas. We believe that it would be important to identify such an outbreak, both because HFMD-linked viruses can cause more severe illness (such as encephalitis) and also because (as described below), the oral lesions that have been described with Zika virus infection may make this an important differential diagnosis.\n\nCase report\n-----------\nA 45-year-old man vacationed with his wife and 2-year-old daughter at a resort in Punta Cana, Dominican Republic, from 22 Jan-1 Feb 2016. On 27 Jan 2016, he and his wife noticed that their daughter had developed a 'heat rash' described as red spots on her hands, feet, and back. Notably, they reported that there were at least 2 other children at the resort with a similar rash.\n\nOn 28 Jan 2016, the man began to feel unwell, describing fever, nausea, headache, sore throat, and myalgia as his main symptoms. On 30 Jan 2016, he developed a rash, which appeared similar to his daughter's rash, on his hands, feet, buttocks, and in his mouth. His description suggests that the rash initially was comprised of erythematous papules and vesicles. Over the following days, the rash evolved and appeared as erythematous macules and patches, which appeared petechial [pinpoint red or purple spots] and purpuric [brownish-red spots].\n\nOn 2 Feb 2016, he presented to an outpatient clinic in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. On the basis of his clinical course, similar illness in children, and the appearance and progression of the rash he received a clinical diagnosis of HFMD. Serological evaluations, including antibody testing for chikungunya, dengue, and Zika viruses, were negative. Syphilis serology was negative. Stool PCR for enteroviruses was negative. The infectious disease consult service recommended that urine and pharyngeal specimens also be sent for viral studies, but this unfortunately was not done. In a follow up telephone discussion with a treating physician (24 Feb 2016) this individual indicated that he was recovering and his rash was resolving but stated that he was 'losing a layer or 2 of skin on [his] feet.'\n\nComment\n-------\nWhile virological confirmation is lacking in this case, the clinical features and course of this illness are most consistent with HFMD. HFMD is most commonly observed in children under the age of 5, but there are several case studies and case series on this disease in adults. It is caused by enteroviruses, most commonly coxsackievirus A16 and enterovirus A71. It is transmitted through the fecal-oral route or by contact with fluid from the throat or vesicles. Its incubation period is usually 3 to 5 days. The virus is shed in the stool for 4 to 8 weeks [1].\n\nThe disease may cause outbreaks; the 1st description of a HFMD outbreak was made in 1958, by investigators in Toronto, Canada [2].\n\nHFMD typically presents with a prodrome [early symptoms and signs indicating the onset of a disease] of non-specific symptoms that last 1 to 2 days, followed by a rash that lasts 7 to 10 days. The exanthem is usually a macular, maculopapular, or vesicular rash on the hands, feet, and buttocks. The enanthem is similar in the mouth.\n\nThe disease may be complicated by meningitis, encephalitis, flaccid paralysis, or myopericarditis. The diagnosis is made clinically, but PCR can be performed on samples from the throat, stool, urine, and vesicular fluid. Treatment is supportive [1].\n\nAn epidemiological study of HFMD found no differences in either clinical presentation or enterovirus type between adults and children [3]. There have been 2 recent published HFMD case series about HFMD in adults caused by a less commonly isolated enterovirus, coxsackievirus A6 [4,5]. Some of the patients described in these case series presented similarly to the present case. Namely, their rashes appeared petechial and purpuric, with desquamation in affected areas about one month after rash onset.\n\nThese case series suggested that the incidence of coxsackievirus A6 as a cause of HFMD is increasing in the adults, and that adults infected with coxsackievirus A6 may have atypical rash. The occurrence of HFMD in this individual with subsequent desquamation may suggest infection with coxsackievirus A6.\n\nThe oral lesions observed in this instance were typical of HFMD. However, given the recent emergence of Zika virus in the Western Hemisphere, it is important to note that news reports described Zika virus presented as a febrile illness with rash and oral lesions during a recent outbreak in French Polynesia [6]. While this individual's serological evaluation was negative, the short time interval (5 days) between onset of symptoms and serological testing likely decreased the sensitivity of serological diagnosis.\n\n[We thank Dr John Brownstein of http://healthmap.org for useful discussions regarding oral lesions in Zika virus infection.]\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Other types of enteroviruses sometimes also cause hand-foot-mouth disease.\n\nProMED-mail thanks Dr Fisman for submitting this interesting case report. It certainly emphasizes the problem of differential diagnosis of HFMD based on symptomatology alone with the emergence of Zika in the Americas. It also is an important report because it is not clear how extensive is the level of virus activity causing HFMD in Caribbean resorts, and non-polio enteroviruses have the potential to cause severe neurological disease. It will therefore be important for doctors to be aware of the similarities and differences between presentation of rash and oral lesions by Zika virus and the non-polio enteroviruses, as they may look vey similar. All of them sought medical attention and one was hospitalised. All are now in stable condition.\n\nThe stool specimens collected from 2 affected children tested positive for enterovirus (EV) by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch.\n\nOfficers of the CHP have conducted a site visit and advised the staff of the institution on necessary infection control and preventive measures.\n\nThe institution has been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n'HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as coxsackievirus and EV71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles, and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,' a spokesman for the CHP said.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures: maintain good air circulation; wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials; keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing; cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly; clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding one part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water; children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted; avoid going to overcrowded places; and parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\nThe public may visit the CHP's page on HFMD and EV71 infection at\n(www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/16354.html) for more information.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Mong Kok is an area in the Yau Tsim Mong District, on the western part of Kowloon Peninsula in Hong Kong (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mong_Kok). 'Then the fever got worse and she started vomiting.'\n\nThe Royalton Riviera Cancun resort offered KB complimentary late checkout if she signed a non-disclosure agreement. She refused the resort's offer and chose to share her tale online.\n\n'I just wanted to make sure it didn't happen to anyone else because it was awful.' said KB. 'When I talked to the hotel they weren't willing to inform the other families that were there at the moment and that's all I wanted.'\n\nKB's Facebook post has been shared more than 19 000 times and she says she's received a Facebook message from a mother whose child contracted hand-foot-mouth disease at the resort in mid-February [2016].\n\nA family from Kamloops [British Columbia] had a similar experience during their January [2016] visit to Tulum, roughly 100 km [62 KM] south of Cancun on the coast of the Gulf of Mexico, when their toddler contracted an ailment.\n\n'Just like that little girl that was posted on Facebook, it starts at the feet but worked its way up just past the knees and elbows,' said [the toddler's mother]. 'Then his mouth was covered as well.'\n\nA doctor in Cancun diagnosed the 16-month-old boy's condition as hand-foot-mouth disease, which was becoming increasingly frequent in the area.\n\n'He said that he'd handed out multiple prescriptions for this over the last week, that there must be some sort of an outbreak because he's been handing them out like crazy,' 'At the resort, they were like 'Oh, we've never seen this before'.'\n\nSymptoms of the infection include fever, vomiting, and blisters within the patient's throat and on their skin. [The woman] suspects her son caught the virus at the resort likely from a high chair or playpen.\n\nJason Kmet, a pharmacist with the Polaris Travel Clinic in Calgary, says scientists are working to develop a vaccine for hand-foot-mouth disease but, for now, the best prevention is to thoroughly wash hands and surfaces that may carry the virus.\n\nKmet says there are medications available to treat the symptoms of hand-foot-mouth disease but the patient normally heals in due time.\n\n'Very rarely it can turn into a more serious neurological problem but that's relatively a minority,' explains Kmet. 'Usually it just passes through time.'\n\nThe Royalton Riviera Cancun issued the following statement to CTV Calgary regarding the possible hand-foot-mouth disease outbreak:\n\nRegrettably, we have recently been alerted that some children that visited Royalton Riviera Cancun have exhibited symptoms of hand-foot-mouth disease while staying with us. As the health and safety of our guests are of the utmost priority, we take great care and dedication to prevent the spread of any germs on hotel grounds.\n\nOn a daily basis, we engage in extensive precautionary measures and thorough sanitization practices, including the following: maintenance of pool and jacuzzi chlorination levels and filter systems; daily sanitization of all guest rooms and public spaces including the Kids Clubhouse and Hangout Teens Club; and thorough restaurant cleanings, which includes disinfecting high chairs and wrapping them in plastic cling wrap between use.\n\nWe sincerely apologize for any inconvenience or concern these unforeseen circumstances may have caused our guests. As always, we encourage guests to practice good hygiene by using hand sanitizers provided throughout the resort. We ask that if a guest is exhibiting hand-foot-mouth disease symptoms during their stay with us to immediately visit our onsite medical doctor.\n\n[The toddler's mother] says the staff at the undisclosed resort near Tulum did not take her son's health concerns seriously.\n\n'It's one thing that our holiday is ruined but you're going to give this playpen and dirty high chair and everything to somebody else?' asks [the woman]. 'If somebody has a disease like this and I've told you about it, surely somebody's got to come in and do a deep cleaning of the room, because my baby's picked that up somewhere and going to pass it on to another baby, and another baby, and another baby.'\n\n[Byline: Ryan White]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It appears from the response provided by the resort in Cancun that they do take precautions to attempt prevention of spread of infectious diseases by sanitization and decontamination.\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease is a common viral illness that mainly affects infants and children but can sometimes occur in adults. It is caused by a group of viruses called enteroviruses, including certain coxsackie viruses (most commonly A16 in the United States) and enterovirus 71, which has been occasionally associated with severe disease, such as encephalitis.\n\nThe risk of infection depends on destination and time of year: in temperate climates, travellers are most at risk during the summer and autumn months. In tropical climates, the risk of infection is year-round.\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease is spread by coming into contact with secretions (fluids) from the nose and throat, saliva, fluid from blisters or stool (feces) of an infected person. It is spread through close personal contact (kissing or hugging), coughing, and sneezing or from touching objects and surfaces that have been contaminated with the virus.\n\nThe symptoms can take 3 to 7 days to appear. Symptoms usually include fever, loss of appetite, sore throat, generally feeling unwell, painful blister-like sores in the mouth, and a rash with or without small blisters, usually on the palms of the hands or on fingers, soles of the feet or on toes, and may also appear on the knees, elbows, buttocks, or genital area. The disease is usually mild and most people recover in 7 to 10 days. Rare complications can include encephalitis and meningitis, which may lead to death.\n\nThere is no specific treatment for hand-foot-mouth disease; there is no vaccine or medication that is protective. Symptoms can be treated with medications that provide relief for the pain of mouth sores, fever, and aches. It is important to stay well hydrated.\n\nPartly extracted from http://travel.gc.ca/travelling/health-safety/diseases/hand-foot-mouth. - Mod.LK\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Canada can be accessed at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/12 and of Mexico at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/506. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]", "summary": "\n\nThe Royalton Riviera Cancun issued the following statement to CTV Calgary regarding the possible hand-foot-mouth disease outbreak:\n\nRegrettably, we have recently been alerted that some children that visited Royalton Riviera Cancun have exhibited symptoms of hand-foot-mouth disease while staying with us. \n\nKB's Facebook post has been shared more than 19 000 times and she says she's received a Facebook message from a mother whose child contracted hand-foot-mouth disease at the resort in mid-February [2016]. \n\nJason Kmet, a pharmacist with the Polaris Travel Clinic in Calgary, says scientists are working to develop a vaccine for hand-foot-mouth disease but, for now, the best prevention is to thoroughly wash hands and surfaces that may carry the virus. \n\nHand-foot-mouth disease is spread by coming into contact with secretions (fluids) from the nose and throat, saliva, fluid from blisters or stool (feces) of an infected person. \n\nKmet says there are medications available to treat the symptoms of hand-foot-mouth disease but the patient normally heals in due time. \n\nA doctor in Cancun diagnosed the 16-month-old boy's condition as hand-foot-mouth disease, which was becoming increasingly frequent in the area. 'The number of cases is down 30 percent from last year [2014],' Tran Dac Phu, director of the ministry's Centre for Preventive Health, said. Phu instructed health agencies in southern localities to remain wary of EV71 [enterovirus-71], [a major pathogen for severe hand-foot-mouth disease].\n\nLast year [2014] Viet Nam recorded more than 76 300 cases.\n\nDoctors have urged people to maintain hygiene at home and in public areas as the disease spreads through contact with human waste and body fluids. Dr A Parthasarathi, specialist paediatrician and neonatologist at the Badr Al Samaa Hospital, said the virus is spreading in Oman. 'We are currently seeing around 10 to 12 cases in our outpatient department every day,' he revealed.\n\nDr Santosh Ramaswamy, paediatrician at the Atlas Medical Hospital, said the disease is characterised by a mild fever, painful sores in the mouth and rashes with blisters on hands and feet. 'It comes in specific areas where sores may be painful,' he stated. Ramaswamy also said the virus is easily spread through coughing and sneezing, and often the disease breaks out within a community. 'Initially, your child may feel tired, get a sore throat, or have a mild fever. Then, sores or blisters may appear in the mouth, feet, and sometimes the buttocks,' doctors said.\n\nSince most HFMD symptoms resemble those of chickenpox, another contagious viral infection, many parents can be easily misled, warned experts. 'Although this disease runs its course without requiring any treatment, it is important for parents to still visit a paediatrician,' doctors said.\n\nIn case of chickenpox, children develop rashes, mainly on the body near the abdomen areas and head. 'The blisters look different from those in the case of HFMD,' Ramaswamy said. Though hand-foot-and-mouth disease is common among children, it can also occur in adults during periods when the weather is changing.\n\nCases of chicken pox and scarlet fever have also been reported in various parts of the country. 'The infections and fever are common, as winter is setting in. The number of people taking to bed will keep increasing whenever there is a gap between maximum and minimum temperatures,' doctors said. 'The best thing to do this season is to practice good hygiene and wash hands regularly, as a good hand wash will kill the virus,' they added.\n\nThe Indian School Jaalan Bani Bu Ali had to recently declare a 10-day holiday for 1 class after more than 15 students in 1 particular grade had contracted chicken pox.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following has been mostly extracted from the comments of moderator Craig Pringle in prior ProMED-mail posts on this subject:\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is caused by a group of RNA viruses called enteroviruses that includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of HFMD in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses can also cause the illness. Only rarely is the precise agent identified because the outcome of infection is generally benign. However, enterovirus 71 has been associated with more severe disease, such as encephalitis.\n\nHFMD is characterized by fever, malaise, painful sores in the mouth and a rash on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, as well as a rash around the mouth, over the knees, and on the buttocks or genital area. Pictures of the oral and skin lesions can be found at http://www.ijdvl.com/article.asp?issn=0378-6323;year=2013;volume=79;issue=2;spage=165;epage=175;aulast=Sarma. Temporary fingernail and toenail loss, called onychomadesis, have been reported, occurring mostly in children within a few weeks after having HFMD.\n\nHFMD is commonly spread via the fecal-oral route, blister fluid, and respiratory secretions. Generally, a person with HFMD is most contagious during the 1st week of illness. People can sometimes be contagious for days or weeks after symptoms go away. Some people, especially adults, may not develop any symptoms, but they can still spread the virus to others. This is why susceptible individuals should always try to maintain good hygiene to reduce exposure to any of the enteroviruses associated with HFMD. HFMD is not transmitted to or from pets or other animals. There is no specific vector.\n\nRegarding grading of HFMD, from the Academia website:\n'Grade 1 is uncomplicated fever along with rash on the hands, feet and mouth; grade 2 shows twitching in the \ufb01ngers indicating nervous system af\ufb02iction. In Grade 3 disease manifests with more serious symptoms: persistent fever, lethargy, irritability, limb weakness, meningism, and seizure. Grade 4 is the most serious level of disease, presenting with cardiorespiratory compromise. Grading is useful for deciding treatment options: child presenting with grade 2 should be hospitalized and carefully observed for further progression. At grade 3 and 4, the child's life is seriously at risk, and intensive care becomes a necessity.' The 21 affected pupils, 9 boys and 12 girls aged between 2 and 5, have developed fever, oral ulcers, and rash and vesicles on their hands or feet since 8 Aug 2015. All of them sought medical attention and did not require hospitalisation. They have been in a stable condition all along.\n\nThe stool specimen of an affected pupil tested positive for enterovirus (EV) upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Officers of the CHP have conducted a site visit and advised the staff of the kindergarten on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The school has been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n'HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs [Enteroviruses] such as Coxsackie virus and Enterovirus 71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,' a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n- Maintain good air circulation;\n- Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n- Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n- Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n- Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently (with 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n- Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted; and\n- Parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest [condition] of their sick children.\n\nThe public may visit the CHP's page on HFMD and EV71 infection for more information.\n<www.chp.gov.hk/en/view_content/16354.html>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2226.]", "summary": "\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n- Maintain good air circulation;\n- Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n- Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n- Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n- Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently (with 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n- Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted; The illness is characterized by fever, painful sores in the mouth, and a rash with blisters on hands, feet and also buttocks. It usually begins with a fever, poor appetite, malaise, and frequently with a sore throat.\n\nThere is no specific way to prevent HFMD infection, but the DOH said practicing good hygiene can help in decreasing risk of transmission.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The location of the 15 Senatorial Divisions of the Philippines can be seen at https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Senatorial_districts_of_the_Philippines.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the Enterovirus genus, including polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of hand, foot, and mouth disease in the United States, but other coxsackieviruses can also cause the illness. Enterovirus 71 has also been associated with cases and outbreaks of hand, foot, and mouth disease. Less often, enterovirus 71 has been associated with severe disease, such as encephalitis. It is likely that the virus responsible for the current outbreaks in the Philippines is one of the enteroviruses associated with childhood febrile illness.\n\nGenerally, a person with hand, foot, and mouth disease is most contagious during the 1st week of illness. People can sometimes be contagious for days or weeks after symptoms go away. Some people, especially adults, may not develop any symptoms, but they can still spread the virus to others.
