Enterovirus 71 has also been associated with cases and outbreaks of hand, foot, and mouth disease.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2015-09-21 00:00:00", "1971-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2014-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-01-01 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Philippines", "country": "Philippines"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3730968", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Turcs and Caicos Islands RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3730968", "date": "2015-10-20 19:33:19", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - TURCS AND CAICOS ISLANDS REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n*******************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 20 Oct 2015\nSource: Turks and Caicos Sun [abridged and edited]\nhttp://suntci.com/new-disease-in-tci-p1957-108.htm\n\n\nThe Ministry of Health is reporting an outbreak of hand foot and mouth disease [HFMD] in the Turks and Caicos Islands affecting some schools and children.\n\nThe SUN understands that up to 20 cases have already been reported to the Ministry of Health, Agriculture and Human Services. It is not clear how many schools are affected, but a source reported that it could be up to 6, and at least one of them is a government school. The TCI Hospitals, when contacted, confirmed that they have been dealing with HFMD patients but declined to divulge the numbers, telling us instead to obtain such records from the Ministry of Health. The Ministry of Health said: 'A few suspected cases have recently been reported from health care facilities in Providenciales.'\n\nThe Ministry of Health, Agriculture and Human Services (MOHAHS) issued a press statement on the disease informing the public that it is in the process of collecting specimens to dispatch to the Caribbean Public Health Agency to confirm that the ailment is in fact HFMD. The ministry further noted that it has embarked on an enhanced surveillance and education campaign to ensure that suspected cases are identified as quickly as possible and schools and daycare facilities are educated on proper implementation of prevention and hygiene measures. HFMD is a contagious viral illness that primarily affects infants and children younger than 5 years old. It is transmitted by direct contact with nasal secretions, (droplets produced by coughing or sneezing), saliva, fluid from blisters and stool of infected individuals. HFMD is most prevalent in childcare settings due to frequent contact with soiled diapers and children putting their hands in their mouths.\n\nHFMD occasionally occurs in adolescents and adults. Symptoms include some or all of the following: painful sores in the mouth, rashes on the hands and feet, which may be associated with blisters, fever, headache, feeling generally unwell or irritable, runny nose, and/or sore throat. It is mostly a mild and self-limiting illness lasting for a few days. However, there are more severe, albeit uncommon, forms of the disease which are associated with neurological complications as a result of meningitis (associated with fever, headache, and neck stiffness) and encephalitis (resulting in paralysis).\n\nPeople can sometimes be contagious for days or weeks after the symptoms have ended. There is no specific treatment for hand-foot-and-mouth disease. Symptom control, such as the use of paracetamol (Panadol or Tylenol) for fever and pain relief, is often all that is necessary. In some cases, HFMD can cause a sore mouth and throat, which makes it difficult to swallow. It is, therefore, important to maintain adequate fluid intake to avoid dehydration that could result in hospitalization. Symptoms usually resolve within 10 days. Persons with suspected HFMD should abstain from school and report to a healthcare provider to obtain guidance, including when to return to work, school or daycare. The MOHAHS will continue to monitor the situation and provide updates as appropriate, the Ministry of Health said.\n\nMedical practitioners advise that if your child's fever remains elevated despite appropriate fever-reducing drugs, or if he or she develops any signs or symptoms of dehydration (dry skin and mucous membranes, weight loss, persistent irritability, lethargy, or decreased urine output), you should seek immediate medical attention. When concerned or in doubt, contact your child's health care provider.\n\nThe method of control is to:\n* Limit person-to-person contact such as hugging, kissing or sharing utensils.\n* Promote good hygiene practices such as hand washing with soap and water; covering nose and mouth when sneezing.\n* Appropriate infection control practices are recommended to prevent the spread of hand, foot and mouth disease. These include immediately separating suspected cases of HFMD from the general school population and sending them home and frequent disinfection of schools in order to prevent the spread of this disease. It is recommended that schools should clean all areas and items that are more likely to have frequent hand contact (for example, taps, toys, keyboards, door handles, or desks) at least twice a day and also clean these areas immediately when visibly handled by ill persons. It is also recommended to wash items with soap and water and then to disinfect them with a 5 percent bleach solution (which is commonly sold commercially) diluted one part bleach to 10 parts water.\n\nThe Ministry of Health, Agriculture and Human Services (MOHAHS) of the Turks and Caicos Islands (TCI) wishes to inform the public that there have been media reports of an ongoing outbreak of HFMD in Singapore and Japan and recent reports of cases in neighboring Caribbean countries. The Turks and Caicos Islands is the latest country that has experienced an outbreak of the disease. Jamaica's schools are said to have been grappling with the ailment, forcing that country's ministry of health to close down a number of school and initiate an extensive sanitizing exercise. Parents with children attending schools in the TCI have reported getting information from schools regarding the disease and how to diminish the chances of their children contracting it.\n\nHand foot and mouth disease is a common childhood illness caused by different enteroviruses such as a Coxsackie virus. It is said that the illness most often occurs between March and June and between September and December, but it can occur at any time. It is most frequently seen in young children, infants and toddlers. Hand foot and mouth disease is characterised by fever and a blister-like rash affecting the palms of the hands and soles of the feet along with blisters inside the mouth. Research shows that children usually become infected with the virus from other children through hugging, kissing or contact with stool. It typically occurs in small epidemics in nursery schools or kindergartens.\n\nIt is not the same as other diseases that have similar names: foot-and-mouth disease (sometimes called hoof-and-mouth disease) or mad cow disease. These diseases almost always occur in animals. The virus spreads easily through coughing and sneezing. It can also spread through infected stool, such as when you change a diaper or when a young child gets stool on his or her hands and then touches objects that other children put in their mouths. Often the disease breaks out within a community. It usually takes 3 to 6 days for a person to get symptoms of hand-foot-and-mouth disease after being exposed to the virus. This is called the incubation period.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This account of enterovirus infection resulting in HFMD is not precise about the species of virus that was involved. Khanh said.\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease is a common viral illness among children under the age of 3 years, especially those between 6 months and 12 months, who contract the disease easily and their condition deteriorates rapidly. In Grade 3 disease manifests with more serious symptoms: persistent fever, lethargy, irritability, limb weakness, meningism, and seizure. Grade 4 is the most serious level of disease, presenting with cardiorespiratory compromise. Grading is useful for deciding treatment options: child presenting with grade 2 should be hospitalized and carefully observed for further progression. It is most commonly caused by Coxsackie virus A16. The illness spreads by contact with an infected person. It is mainly breaking out in schools as children come in contact with others in school. In the past few days, I have been seeing around 6 to 7 new cases every day,' said Dr Ramu DS, pediatric consultant of BGS Hospital.\n\nHe added, 'There is no specific treatment. However, antipyretics can be used for fever and pain. Children should take plenty of fluids. In general, the disease clears up by itself within 7 to 10 days. Last year, the number of cases was much more. It is a viral disease so we treat it symptomatically. We give local painkillers as it interferes with feeding in children.'\n\nEchoing her view, district health officer Rajani M said, 'There is no need to panic. It is essentially a zoonotic disease. The Police College, next to Ocean Park, has undergone a massive clean-up and tightened hygiene measures since the 14 Aug 2015 outbreak while the Centre for Health Protection investigates the source of the virus.\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease has been rife in 2015, the centre warned, with 237 institutional outbreaks reported by 20 Aug. 7 cases, all of them children, were severe but none proved fatal. There were 346 cases of institutional outbreaks in 2014 compared with 779 in 2013.\n\n'Several classes of recruits whose colleagues have been infected are now receiving training separately in an effort to prevent the spread of the disease,' a police source familiar with the outbreak said. 'The college's facilities are being cleaned and disinfected 3 or 4 times a day.' He said no new cases had been reported on Wednesday or Thursday [26-27 Aug].\n\nNone of the 21 patients -- all male constables aged 18 to 30 -- required hospital care. All have been in stable condition since contracting the disease. They were given sick leave by doctors and stayed at home to recover. Half of them have now returned to the college.\n\nIt is understood the decision to close the pool and gymnasium was made by police themselves. The source said the force did not receive any advice from the Department of Health to shut down the training school or any of its facilities. There are about 600 recruits receiving training at the college.\n\nPolice alerted the department on 17 Aug 2015 after the 1st few cases emerged. Department officers visited the premises and provided health advice.\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease is usually caused by enteroviruses and is common among children. It usually begins with a fever, poor appetite, tiredness and a sore throat. The usual peak season is from early summer to autumn; a smaller peak may also occur in winter. In children, the infection is more likely to be associated with severe medical complications and even death. But to most adults, the disease is mostly self-limiting and is resolved in 7-10 days.\n\nIt spreads mainly by contact with nose or throat discharges, saliva, fluid from vesicles or patients' stool, or contaminated objects, according to the centre. The centre advises that play facilities hit with the disease should be properly disinfected and should maintain good indoor ventilation. Notices should be posted at the entrance to advise people with infectious diseases not to enter.\n\n[Byline: Clifford Lo and Emily Tsang]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the UK's National Health Service 'Choices' website (http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-foot-and-mouth-disease/Pages/Introduction.aspx):\n\n'Hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral infection that can affect young children. It doesn't usually pose a serious threat to a child's health, but it can be be an unpleasant condition, particularly if it affects younger children.\n\nTypical symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease include:\n----------------------------------------------------\nCold-like symptoms, such as loss of appetite, cough and a moderately high temperature of around 38-39\u00b0C (100.4-102.2\u00b0F) a non-itchy red rash, made up of spots or small fluid-filled sacs (vesicles), which usually develops on the hands and feet, but may also occur on the knees, elbows, groin and buttocks; sometimes the rash can develop into painful blisters.\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease is a self-limiting condition, which means it will get better on its own without treatment. The symptoms will usually pass within seven days. However, speak to your GP or call NHS 111 if you're unsure whether your child has hand, foot and mouth disease. You should also contact your GP if your child isn't drinking any fluid or their symptoms last longer than seven days.\n\nTreating hand, foot and mouth disease.\n---------------------------------------------\nThere is currently no cure for hand, foot and mouth disease, so treatment involves making your child feel as comfortable as possible while waiting for the infection to take its course. Possible treatment options include: using paracetamol, ibuprofen and mouth gels to relieve the pain of mouth ulcer drinking plenty of fluids to help relieve a high temperature.\n\nEtiology\n---------\nHand, foot and mouth disease is caused by a group of viruses known as enteroviruses. The most common types of viruses that can cause the condition are:\n\nCoxsackievirus A16, A6 or A10\nEnteroviruses 71\nEnterovirus 71 carries a higher risk of causing serious complications.\n\nHow the infection spreads:\n-----------------\nA person with hand, foot and mouth disease is highly contagious until about a week after the symptoms begin. The infection can be spread if: (1) contaminated droplets are transferred from an infected person - for example, if an infected person coughs or sneezes, the droplets can be inhaled by another person or can contaminate surfaces, leading to the spread of infection; (2) fecal matter (stool) is transferred from an infected person - for example, if an infected person doesn't wash their hands properly after going to the toilet and then contaminates food or surfaces (the viruses can live for up to four weeks in a person's stools); or (3) you come into contact with the fluids of an infected person's blisters or saliva.\n\nBecause of the way the infection is spread, outbreaks of hand, foot and mouth disease can occur in places where groups of children need to have their nappies changed or use a potty, such as nurseries or childcare centres. You should keep your child away from school or nursery while they are unwell. However, there's no need to wait until the last blister has gone before your child can return to school or nursery, providing they are otherwise well. However, some schools and nurseries may reserve the right to refuse to take your child until the condition has cleared up completely.\n\nIt is rare, but possible, to get hand, foot and mouth disease more than once, although not during the same outbreak. As they get older, most children will develop immunity to the viruses that cause the condition.\n\nComplications\n----------\nIt's important to make sure that anyone with hand, foot and mouth disease keeps drinking fluids to avoid becoming dehydrated. Dehydration can often occur because the mouth ulcers can make drinking fluids painful.\n\nLife-threatening complications such as brain infections (encephalitis) have been reported during epidemics of hand, foot and mouth disease caused by the enterovirus 71. However, these complications are very rare and they have been limited to the Asia-Pacific region.\n\nAdults with hand, foot and mouth disease\n--------------------------\nAlthough hand, foot and mouth disease mainly affects children aged 10 or younger, adults can be affected. Adults with the condition are also contagious and should stay away from the workplace until it has completely cleared up.\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease gets better on its own without treatment and complications are rare in adults. However, the symptoms can cause severe discomfort.\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease is not the same as foot and mouth disease, which affects cattle, sheep and pigs. The two infections are unrelated, and you cannot catch hand, foot and mouth disease from animals.'\n\n\nLife-threatening complications such as brain infections (encephalitis) have been reported during epidemics of hand, foot and mouth disease caused by the enterovirus 71. However, these complications are very rare and they have been limited to the Asia-Pacific region. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/198.]", "summary": "The infection can be spread if: (1) contaminated droplets are transferred from an infected person - for example, if an infected person coughs or sneezes, the droplets can be inhaled by another person or can contaminate surfaces, leading to the spread of infection; (2) fecal matter (stool) is transferred from an infected person - for example, if an infected person doesn't wash their hands properly after going to the toilet and then contaminates food or surfaces (the viruses can live for up to four weeks in a person's stools); or (3) you come into contact with the fluids of an infected person's blisters or saliva.\n\nBecause of the way the infection is spread, outbreaks of hand, foot and mouth disease can occur in places where groups of children need to have their nappies changed or use a potty, such as nurseries or childcare centres. \n\nHand, foot and mouth disease is not the same as foot and mouth disease, which affects cattle, sheep and pigs. promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[From the UK's National Health Service 'Choices' website (http://www.nhs.uk/conditions/hand-foot-and-mouth-disease/Pages/Introduction.aspx):\n\n'Hand, foot and mouth disease is a viral infection that can affect young children. \n\nHand, foot and mouth disease has been rife in 2015, the centre warned, with 237 institutional outbreaks reported by 20 Aug. 7 cases, all of them children, were severe but none proved fatal. \n\nTypical symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease include:\n \n\nLife-threatening complications such as brain infections (encephalitis) have been reported during epidemics of hand, foot and mouth disease caused by the enterovirus 71. Some people, particularly young children, may have severe disease requiring hospitalization or even causing death. Travelers to these countries can protect themselves by practicing personal hygiene tips. Below is a typical alert, posted originally in ProMED-MBDS. - Mod.CP]\n\nDate: Tue 25 Aug 2015\nSource: The Visayan Daily Star [edited]\nhttp://www.visayandailystar.com/2015/August/25/med101.htm\n\n\nBacolod City [capital of Negros Occidental province] in the past few weeks has reported an increasing number of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) cases in both children and adults.\n\nEarlier this year [2015], the Department of Health reported that there was a 175.7 percent increase of HFMD cases compared to last year [2014]. The census showed that 23.7 percent of cases came from Cagayan Valley, followed by 20.1 percent from Calabarzon, then 15.5 percent from Northern Mindanao, 9.6 percent from Metro Manila, and 5.4 percent from Mimaropa.\n\nWhat is HFMD? It is an infectious viral infection that is caused by enteroviruses, usually by coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) and enterovirus 71 (EV71) and other picornaviruses. Children 1-4 years old are at higher risk of getting the disease, but even older children and adults can be infected.\n\nSymptoms begin with a high grade fever followed by non-specific symptoms of flu, such as malaise, sore throat, and decreased appetite. After one to 2 days, painful sores may start to appear in the mouth. This may be followed by the onset of a non-itchy flat red rash on the palms and soles which may lead to blister formation. These may also appear on the elbows, knees, and buttocks. In some cases, the symptoms are atypical, which makes diagnosis difficult. What is worse is that some people may be asymptomatic and yet may transmit the disease to others.\n\nThe culprit virus is found in throat and nose secretions, blister fluid of the skin rash, and even in the feces. Thus, it can easily be spread through the air by sneezing or coughing, by personal contact, contact with feces, and contact with objects that are contaminated by the virus, such as doorknobs, tables, and other surfaces.\n\nA person is considered highly contagious during the 1st week of illness. However, others may remain contagious for days or even weeks after the symptoms are gone.\n\nThere is no vaccine against HFMD. Prevention entails healthy, clean practices such as adequate hand washing with soap and water, especially after changing diapers or using the toilet; avoiding close contact (such as hugging, kissing, or sharing utensils) with an HFMD-infected person, and cleaning and disinfecting frequently-touched surfaces, such as doorknobs, tables, chairs, and even children's toys.\n\nAs with most viral infections, HFMD has no known cure. Treatment, therefore, is aimed at alleviating symptoms. Pain killers may be given for pain relief; anesthetic mouth spray may be used to numb affected areas of the throat; ill patients should be encouraged to drink lots of water even if their throats hurt.\n\nWe must start practicing what we learned with regards to maintaining our cleanliness. After all, to quote Sam Veda, 'One who maintains cleanliness keeps away diseases.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is usually a mild disease, but 'approximately 10-30 percent of hospitalized cases during EV71-associated HFMD epidemics in Asia have developed a spectrum of central nervous system (CNS) complications, including aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, and acute flaccid paralysis.\n\nThe most severely affected children can develop fulminant cardio-respiratory failure, which is often fatal and causes a high incidence of severe neurological and possible psycho-behavioral sequelae among survivors, despite intensive care support. The viruses are transmitted to humans through airborne droplets produced by coughing or sneezing and from feces through mucous membranes in the nose and mouth. There is no effective cure or vaccine. The virus is spread from person to person through direct contact with nose and throat discharges, blister fluid, and faeces. Therefore, coughing and sneezing can spread the virus from the infected person to healthy persons. When the virus enters the body, it multiplies at the contact site such as in the throat, surrounding lymphatic nodes, stomach, and intestines. Soon, blisters develop in the mouth and on the skin, commonly at the hands and feet, and sometimes at buttocks. The typical blisters are yellow with bright red borders. They usually appear in the mouth such as on the tongue, palate, velum, tonsils, or gums. Skin rashes also develop at the back of the hands and feet or the palms. They might or might not be itchy. These rashes start of as red rashes and quickly develop into raised red spots, some with blisters. Usually, the rashes will go away within a week.\n\nThere is no specific treatment for HFMD. Most common in young children, it presents as fever, oral lesions, and rash on the hands, feet, and buttocks. The oral lesions consist of rapidly-ulcerating vesicles on the buccal mucosa, tongue, palate, and gums. The rash consists of papulovesicular lesions on the palms, fingers and soles, which generally persist for 7 to 10 days, and maculopapular lesions on the buttocks.\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease is caused by viruses that belong to the _Enterovirus_ genus (group). This group of viruses includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses.\n\nCoxsackievirus A16 is the most common cause of hand-foot-mouth disease in the USA, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness.\n\nEnterovirus 71 [EV-71] has also been associated with hand-foot-mouth disease and outbreaks of this disease. EV-71 has been implicated in HFMD outbreaks in Southeast Asia over several years. EV-71 is a non-polio enterovirus. Complications associated with HFMD caused by the more pathogenic [than coxsackieviruses] EV-71 strain include encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, or hemorrhage and myocarditis. Most deaths in HFMD occur as a result of pulmonary edema or hemorrhage.\n\nAccording to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), there is no vaccine to protect against the viruses that cause hand-foot-mouth disease.\n\nA person can lower their risk of being infected by:\n- washing hands often with soap and water, especially after changing diapers and using the toilet;\n- cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces and soiled items, including toys;\n- avoiding close contact such as kissing, hugging, or sharing eating utensils or cups with people with hand-foot-mouth disease.\n\n[Byline: Robert Herriman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Unfortunately no attempts appear to have been made to identify the specific virus responsible for this enhanced outbreak of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) in the Philippines.\n\nHand-foot-and-mouth disease is usually caused by a group of RNA viruses called enteroviruses. The most commonly implicated enterovirus is coxsackievirus A16. However, coxsackieviruses A5, A9, A10, A16, B1, and B3 and human enterovirus 71 (HEV71) may be involved. Rarely a DNA virus such as herpes simplex viruses can cause the illness. Herpes simplex virus is often also over-looked as a potential cause of HFMD. The specific pathogen is rarely identified as a consequence of the mildness of the illness.\n\nCases are commonly spread via the faecal-oral route. Respiratory droplet transmission also may occur but is less likely. Typically, the virus enters the gastrointestinal tract via the buccal mucosa (lining of the mouth) or the ileum (part of the small intestine). Over the next 72 hours (accounting for the incubation period), a viremia is established via spread through nearby lymph nodes. The outcome of infection is generally benign and identification of the specific pathogen is rarely undertaken.\n\nMaps of the Philippines can be seen at http://www.charleskeng.com/images-map/philmap.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/158. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A person can lower their risk of being infected by:\n- washing hands often with soap and water, especially after changing diapers and using the toilet;\n- cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces and soiled items, including toys;\n- avoiding close contact such as kissing, hugging, or sharing eating utensils or cups with people with hand-foot-mouth disease. Hand, foot and mouth disease is not on the Ontario Reportable Disease list, so there's no way to know how many cases are in Sudbury, said Lisa Schell, the manager of clinical and family services with the health unit. Schell said the health unit has been receiving calls from concerned parents.\n\n'We do know that there are some children who have been diagnosed in our community,' she said. Once we know that there are children in the community with hand, foot and mouth disease, there's certainly probably others who are ill with it as well.'\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease is a virus-transmitted disease. Symptoms include a fever, poor appetite, lack of energy, discomfort, sore throat, headache, small painful mouth sores and a skin rash that looks like red spots, often with blisters on top. That rash usually appears on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, but can show up on other areas of the body, Schell said.\n\nThere is no specific treatment. There is no blood test to confirm [the diagnosis], but Schell suggested a visit to a health care provider if a child is showing symptoms. 'The diagnosis of hand, foot and mouth disease is based on the appearance of the rash,' she said. 'With hand, foot and mouth disease, we basically have to let it run its course. There's no specific treatment for the illness.'\n\nChildren do not need to be excluded [from school] if they are diagnosed with hand, foot and mouth disease, Schell said. 'If the child is unwell, let them lay low and treat them with bed rest and lots of fluids,' she said. 'Watch for signs of dehydration in case the child is not drinking or eating.'\n\nSerious complication includes dehydration, and Schell notes if a child with hand, foot and mouth disease has sores in their mouth, watch what they drink. 'It can be painful, especially if they're drinking highly acidic fruit juices,' she said. 'The good thing about hand, foot and mouth is that once a child has had the disease, they are immune to it subsequently,' she said.\n\nThe virus also tends to be more common in the summer and fall, Schell said. 'It's just the nature of the virus,' she explained. 'We usually see more individuals getting out and about.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmmail.org>\n\n[This is a rather inadequate account of an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) in Canada. Although comparatively uncommon in well-developed societies, hand, foot and mouth disease is common in underdeveloped or overpopulated regions of the world, and several different enteroviruses have been identified as responsible for outbreaks of hand, foot, and mouth disease, the most prevalent being several coxsackieviruses and, in particular, enterovirus 71, sometimes responsible for neurological effects.\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease usually begins with a low-grade fever and general fatigue. A rash of tiny, painful red spots will appear within a couple of days and will soon begin to blister and sometimes form ulcers. These spots may appear at several sites over the body. Lymph nodes in the neck may also become swollen. The virus can cause the throat to feel sore and painful. Rarely, dehydration may occur as the pain due to the blisters in the mouth can make drinking difficult.\n\nDaycare centres, parks, nursery schools, and other places where children play with each other are potential sites for the infection to be transmitted among children. HFMD is most common in the summer and early fall.\n\nHigh standards of personal and social hygiene are the best protection against hand, foot, and mouth disease.\n\nThe WHO Surveillance Summary includes information from countries where transmission of HFMD occurs and case counts are routinely reported. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/260.]", "summary": "Although comparatively uncommon in well-developed societies, hand, foot and mouth disease is common in underdeveloped or overpopulated regions of the world, and several different enteroviruses have been identified as responsible for outbreaks of hand, foot, and mouth disease, the most prevalent being several coxsackieviruses and, in particular, enterovirus 71, sometimes responsible for neurological effects. \n\nSerious complication includes dehydration, and Schell notes if a child with hand, foot and mouth disease has sores in their mouth, watch what they drink. They have developed fever, oral ulcers and rash on their hands or feet since 14 June 2014. All of those affected sought medical attention, while 3 children were admitted to Pamela Youde Nethersole Eastern Hospital for management, and 2 of them have been discharged. They are all currently in stable condition.\n\nThe rectal swab of an affected child tested positive for enterovirus (EV) upon laboratory testing by the CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch. Officers of the CHP have conducted a site visit and advised the staff of the residential child care centre on necessary infection control and preventive measures. The centre has been put under medical surveillance. Investigations are ongoing.\n\n'HFMD is common in children and is usually caused by EVs such as Coxsackie virus and EV71. It is clinically characterised by maculopapular rash or vesicular lesions occurring on the palms, soles and other parts of the body such as the buttocks and thighs. Vesicular lesions and ulcers may also be found in the oral cavity. Sometimes patients present mainly with painful ulcers at the back of the mouth, namely herpangina, without rash on the hands or feet,' a spokesman for the CHP explained.\n\nTo prevent HFMD, members of the public, and especially the management of institutions, should take heed of the following preventive measures:\n* Maintain good air circulation;\n* Wash hands before meals and after going to the toilet or handling diapers or other stool-soiled materials;\n* Keep hands clean and wash hands properly, especially when they are dirtied by respiratory secretions, such as after sneezing;\n* Cover the nose and mouth while sneezing or coughing and dispose of nasal and oral discharges properly;\n* Clean children's toys and other objects thoroughly and frequently with diluted household bleach (by adding 1 part of household bleach containing 5.25 per cent sodium hypochlorite to 49 parts of water), followed by rinsing or wiping with clean water;\n* Children who are ill should be kept out of school until their fever and rash have subsided and all the vesicles have dried and crusted;\n* Avoid going to overcrowded places; and\n* Parents should maintain close communication with schools to let them know the latest situation of the sick children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The WHO Surveillance Summary includes information from countries where transmission of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) occurs and case counts are routinely reported.\n\nNorthern Hemisphere/ China: As of 31 May, there were reported 630 391 cases of HFMD, including 26 deaths in China for 2015. From 1 to 31 May 2015, 304 863 cases of HFMD had been reported, a 42 percent decrease compared with the same period in 2014 (528 777). The number of HFMD cases reported monthly in 2015 is following the seasonal pattern displayed in 2012, 2013 and 2014 (Figure 1). It is likely that the figures for Hong Kong (SARI) follow the same seasonal pattern as elsewhere in China http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/hfmd_biweekly_20150616.pdf?ua=1.\n\nHFMD usually begins with a low-grade fever and general fatigue. A rash of tiny, painful red spots will appear within a couple of days and will soon begin to blister and sometimes form ulcers. These spots may appear:\n- inside the mouth (on the tongue, gums, or cheeks)\n- on the palms of the hands or on the fingers\n- on the soles of the feet or on the toes\n- on the buttocks\n\nThe rash is not generally itchy and, in some cases, may develop on other parts of the body. Lymph nodes in the neck may also become swollen. The virus can cause the throat to feel sore and painful. Rarely, dehydration may occur as the pain due to the blisters in the mouth can make drinking difficult. Infection by EV71 has been known to cause encephalitis or viral meningitis in rare cases.\n\nChildren and adolescents are the most commonly affected people. Adults are rarely infected, although pregnant women who have not been exposed to the virus before have a higher chance of becoming infected. Daycare centres, parks, nursery schools, and other places where children play with each other are potential sites for the infection to be transmitted among children. HFMD is most common in the summer and early fall.\n\nA pregnant woman who is infected may show mild or no signs of illness. If she is infected just before her delivery, the infection can be transmitted to the newborn, resulting in only a mild illness in the baby. Rarely, multiple-organ infections occur.\n\nDuring the acute phase, a person can infect others through secretions from the nose and throat. Discharge due to coughing and sneezing can cause the virus to be transmitted easily. Young children, who tend to drool, can also transmit the infection through their saliva.\n\nHand, foot, and mouth disease affects mainly children 5 years old and under, is caused by different types of enterovirus and in most forms is normally not severe. However, 1 type of hand, foot, and mouth disease, caused by the virus EV71, can have dramatic effects, including nerve damage, paralysis or death. EV71 also appears to be very pathogenic, and in recent years has caused large and worrying outbreaks in children in Asian countries, especially in China. No deaths were reported, according to the health department. HFMD is a common infectious disease caused by a group of enteroviruses, including Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) and Enterovirus 71 (EV71). The DOH said that infection by the latter was of 'particular concern' since it could cause severe disease in children, sometimes resulting in death.\n\nHFMD affects mainly children and is commonly spread through direct contact with secretions, such as saliva, from infected people. Symptoms include fever that may last 24 to 48 hours, painful mouth sores and rashes and blisters on the hands, feet and buttocks. The DOH said there was no particular treatment for HFMD and medications given were usually for the relief of symptoms, such as fever and sore throat.\n\nWarning that there was no specific way to prevent being infected with HFMD, the DOH advised the public to strictly observe good hygiene, such as frequent hand washing, to lessen the risk of catching the disease.\n\n[Byline: Jocelyn R. Uy]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Excerpted from PM Vijayaraghavan, S Chandy et al. Virological Investigation of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease in a Tertiary Care Center in South India. J Glob Infect Dis.4(3); July-September 2012 (http://www.jgid.org/article.asp?issn=0974-777X;year=2012;volume=4;issue=3;spage=153;epage=161;aulast=Vijayaraghavan):\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a mild, self-limiting, exanthematous disease of infants and children below 10 years of age. Human enterovirus 71 (HEV-71) and Coxsackievirus A16 (CV-A16) are common etiological agents causing HFMD epidemics. Other Enteroviruses (EV) causing sporadic HFMD cases include CV-A4 to CV-A7, CV-A9, CV-A10, CV-B1 to CV-B3, and CV- B5. The characteristic distribution of the vesicle gives the disease its name. HFMD usually spreads from person-to-person through contact with nose or throat discharges, feces or vesicular fluid.\n\nThe etiological agents of HFMD belong to the _Enterovirus_ genus, family Picornaviridae. They are small, non-enveloped, single-stranded, positive-sense RNA viruses. HEV-71-related HFMD epidemics in Singapore, Sarawak, and Taiwan have reported serious complications like encephalitis, myocarditis, and death. Comparatively, CV-A16 causes milder infections than HEV-71.\n\nEnterovirus infections are common in children under 4 years of age and peak incidence is seen in one-year-olds. Moreover, infants younger than 6 months of age had lower mortality compared to those 0.5 to under one year of age. Highly susceptible children congregate in childcare centers, kindergartens, and preschools.\n\nAlso see recent review:\nPons-Salort M, Parker EP, Grassly NC. The epidemiology of non-polio enteroviruses: recent advances and outstanding questions. Curr Opin Infect Dis. 2015 Jul 22. [Epub ahead of print] (http://journals.lww.com/co-infectiousdiseases/Abstract/publishahead/The_epidemiology_of_non_polio_enteroviruses__.99487.aspx).\n\nPURPOSE OF REVIEW: There are over 100 serotypes of human enteroviruses, which cause a spectrum of illnesses, including meningitis, encephalitis, paralysis, myocarditis and rash. Increasing incidence of hand-foot-and-mouth disease in the Asia-Pacific region and recent outbreaks of enterovirus-associated disease, such as severe respiratory illness in the United States in 2014, highlight the threat of these viruses to human health.\n\nRECENT FINDINGS: We describe recent outbreaks of human enteroviruses and summarize knowledge gaps regarding their burden, spectrum of diseases and epidemiology.\n\nSUMMARY: Reported outbreaks of respiratory, neurological, skin and eye diseases associated with human enteroviruses have increased in frequency and size in recent years. Improved molecular diagnostics and genetic sequence analysis are beginning to reveal the complex dynamics of individual serotypes and genotypes, and their contribution to these outbreaks. However, the biological mechanisms underlying their emergence and transmission dynamics remain elusive. They are likely to involve changes in the virus, such as fitness, antigenicity, virulence or tropism, and in the human population, such as levels of sanitation and of homotypic and heterotypic immunity. Improvements in surveillance, serological surveys and detailed genetic and antigenic characterization of viral populations would help to elucidate these mechanisms. This will be important for the design of outbreak control and vaccine development strategies. ... -more\n\nA map of the Philippines may be accessed at http://www.bing.com/maps/default.aspx?encType=1&where1=Philippines&cp=11.1126661300659~122.509475708008&qpvt=map+of+philippines&FORM=MIRE.\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/158. - Mod.LK]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nThe Cagayan Valley registered the largest number of cases, at 23.7 percent of cases, followed by Calabarzon, 20.1 percent; northern Mindanao, 15.5 percent; Metro Manila, 9.6 percent, and Mimaropa, 5.4 percent. However, doctors say this is not a cause for major concern, given that most cases are relatively mild strains of the virus. The figures saw an early rise from early April 2015, peaking at 1004 cases in the 1st week of May 2015 before easing off.\n\nA Ministry of Health (MOH) spokesperson, noting that HFMD is a common childhood disease that is endemic to Singapore, said on Tue 16 Jun 2015 that 'increases in cases can be expected from time to time.' The spokesperson added: 'The predominant circulating strains this year [2015] are coxsackieviruses type A, which typically cause mild disease. No severe cases or deaths due to HFMD have been reported in the past 3 years.'\n\nAs of 13 Jun 2015, 14 237 HFMD cases were reported to MOH. In comparison, 9684 cases were reported between January and 7 Jun last year [2014]. Of this year's [2015] cases, 72 per cent were patients aged below 7.\n\n'The key to controlling outbreaks of infectious diseases such as HFMD is the early detection and isolation of cases (children with HFMD should stay at home till they are well), and the maintenance of high levels of personal and environmental hygiene,' the spokesperson said.\n\nMeanwhile, general practitioners told the press they had seen slight increases in HFMD cases recently, compared with a year ago. Dr Sunil Joseph of Tayka Medical Family Clinic in Jurong said the cases he had attended to so far were 'mild cases, where the strain of the virus is not too virulent.'\n\nWhile several parents expressed concern over the increase in HFMD cases, they told journalists they were confident their children's schools could handle the matter effectively. A parent who has a daughter in kindergarten said: 'We are trusting the school to provide us with updates on suspected HFMD cases so we as parents can take precautions accordingly.'\n\nSeveral kindergartens and childcare centres noted isolated cases of HFMD on their premises. However, they added that they had protocols -- such as temperature and health checks -- in place, along with regular sanitation practices.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common infectious disease of infants and children. It is characterized by fever, painful sores in the mouth, and a rash with blisters on hands, feet and also buttocks. It is prevalent in many Asian countries. Outbreaks of HFMD occur every few years in different parts of the world, but in recent years, these have occurred more in Asia. Countries with recent large increases in the numbers of reported cases in Asia include: China, Japan, Hong Kong (China), Republic of Korea (South Korea), Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan and Viet Nam. HFMD outbreaks have been frequent in Singapore and neighbouring countries and are probably indicative of common features of rearing of children.\n\nViruses from the group called enteroviruses cause HFMD. There are many different types in the group, including polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses and other enteroviruses. HFMD is most commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16, which usually results in a mild, self-limiting disease with few complications. However, HFMD is also caused by other enteroviruses, including enterovirus 71 (EV71), which has been associated with serious complications and may be fatal.\n\nIt is difficult to make useful comparisons of epidemics affecting different societies. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Singapore can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/150.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common infectious disease of infants and children. \n\nA Ministry of Health (MOH) spokesperson, noting that HFMD is a common childhood disease that is endemic to Singapore, said on Tue 16 Jun 2015 that 'increases in cases can be expected from time to time.' \n\n'The key to controlling outbreaks of infectious diseases such as HFMD is the early detection and isolation of cases (children with HFMD should stay at home till they are well), and the maintenance of high levels of personal and environmental hygiene,' the spokesperson said. It is characterized by fever, painful sores in the mouth, and a rash with blisters on hands, feet and also buttocks. It is prevalent in many Asian countries. Outbreaks of HFMD occur every few years in different parts of the world, but in recent years these have occurred more in Asia. Countries with recent large increases in the number of reported cases in Asia include: China, Japan, Hong Kong (China), Republic of Korea (South Korea), Malaysia, Singapore, Thailand, Taiwan and Viet Nam. HFMD outbreaks have been frequent in Singapore and neighbouring countries and are probably indicative of common features of rearing of children.\n\nViruses from the group called enteroviruses cause HFMD. There are many different types in the group including polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses and other enteroviruses.\n\nHFMD is most commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16, which usually results in a mild self-limiting disease with few complications. However, HFMD is also caused by other enteroviruses, including enterovirus 71 (EV71), which has been associated with serious complications, and may be fatal. - Mod.CP]\n\n[Lesions clearly depicted at:\nhttp://newsnetwork.mayoclinic.org/files/2014/11/HandFootMouth_Cheney.jpg - Mod.JW\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/150.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Communicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common infectious disease of infants and children. \n\nLatest figures by the Ministry of Health showed that just last week, there were 609 cases, almost twice the number of cases compared to the same period last year [2014]. Over the past week, the Kadena Medical Clinic and US Naval Hospital Okinawa have reported several cases of HFMD in our beneficiary populations. Likewise, this disease has been reported in the local Japanese community.\n\nHFMD is a common viral disease caused by several different viruses. It is normally seen in children under 5 years old; however, the current strain that is circulating throughout our community is also causing illnesses in adults. Additionally, the initial signs and symptoms of HFMC can be very similar to those of measles. HFMD is spread by contact with nose and throat secretions (coughing, sneezing, etc.), blister fluid, and stool. The virus is also able to remain on objects (e.g., doorknobs, toys, surfaces, etc.) for several hours.\n\nSymptoms begin with a fever, poor appetite, and a mild feeling of being unwell. In 1-2 days, painful sores usually develop in the mouth. A rash will then show on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. The rash may also appear in other areas. For more information about HFMD, visit: http://www.cdc.gov/hand-foot-mouth/index.html.\n\nHealth complications related to HFMD are quite uncommon. However, children may refuse to eat and drink because of the painful sores in the mouth. Please monitor your child for symptoms of dehydration. If dehydration is seen, please seek medical assistance.\n\nThere is no vaccine to protect against HFMD. People can lower their risk of being infected by any of the enteroviruses associated with HFMD by\n- washing hands often with soap and water, especially after changing diapers and using the toilet. [Visit http://www.cdc.gov/handwashing/ for more information].\n- cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces and soiled items, including toys\n- avoiding close contact such as kissing, hugging, or sharing eating utensils or cups with people who [may be] infected with HFMD.\n\nIf you suspect that you or your child is ill with HFMD, you should not go to work, daycare, etc.\n\n--\nCommunicated by Jennifer Dixon\n<Dixon.jenny@gmail.com>\n\n[Although measles virus and hand-foot-and-mouth disease virus may present clinically as similar conditions, they are caused by quite unrelated viruses. Strains of measles viruses are closely related and can only be distinguished by sophisticated tests. However, hand, foot and mouth disease may be caused by several distinct species of entrovirus. Most importantly, epidemics of measles can be prevented or controlled by use of a stable and effective vaccine. - Mod.CP\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/25112.]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n- cleaning and disinfecting frequently touched surfaces and soiled items, including toys\n- avoiding close contact such as kissing, hugging, or sharing eating utensils or cups with people who [may be] infected with HFMD. \n\nIf you suspect that you or your child is ill with HFMD, you should not go to work, daycare, etc.\n\n--\n HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - JAPAN (OKINAWA)\n********************************************\n [Although measles virus and hand-foot-and-mouth disease virus may present clinically as similar conditions, they are caused by quite unrelated viruses. Kuching district had the highest cumulative cases at 787, followed by Miri (672) and Sibu (663), he disclosed. Until early March 2015, he said 631 cases of HFMD were recorded, while the cumulative figure for Sarawak stood at 3631 thus far.\n\n'The HFMD situation in Sarawak is stable and under control, and the department is mounting efforts to curb the spread of the disease. HFMD is said to be at the outbreak level in the state if there are 365 cases reported per week for the state,' Dr Zulkifli told The Borneo Post. He said this when asked about the total number of cases for a place to be declared an HFMD outbreak area. He attributed the larger population in Kuching, Miri and Sibu as among the causative factors for the higher numbers of cases recorded in these places.\n\nMeanwhile, he stressed it is imperative for teachers in nurseries and kindergartens to monitor entry at the gates to prevent sick pre-schoolers from entering the classroom. 'Teachers also need to check the children for symptoms of HFMD and have the classrooms cleaned daily.'\n\nAmong the symptoms of HFMD are fever, sore throat, mouth ulcers on the inside of the mouth or sides of the tongue, rash (flat or raised spots) or small blisters on palms of hands, soles of feet, and/or buttocks, lethargy and poor appetite. He reiterated that parents need to seek immediate medical attention for their child if she or he exhibits any of these symptoms.\n\nMeanwhile, the person-in-charge of a kindergarten here, Yii Yiew Yieng, said they had been advised by the department to take precautionary measures against HFMD since the start of 2015. Yii said that they carry out stringent checks on every preschooler before allowing them into the class and would notify parents if their children display HFMD symptoms. 'We then ask their parents to seek immediate medical attention for them,' she added.\n\nYii said they would intensify checks if they detect symptoms of HFMD among their pupils. 'Since 2000, our teachers have been taking stringent measures to keep the disease at bay. They will ask children to open their mouth, including checking palms for HFMD symptoms,' she added.\n\nMeanwhile, Dr Zulkifli said no preschools in the state were closed thus far this year [2015] due to HFMD.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nCheng-Siang Tan, PhD\nFaculty of Medicine and Health Sciences\nUniversity Malaysia Sarawak\n<kennytcs77@gmail.com>\n\n[Hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is a common infectious disease of infants and children. The symptoms commonly observed include fever, painful sores in the mouth, and a rash with blisters on hands, feet, and also buttocks. HFMD is most commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16, which usually results in a mild, self-limiting disease with a few complications. HFMD is also caused by other enteroviruses, including enterovirus 71 (EV71), which in large outbreaks in southeastern Asia has been associated with serious complications in certain groups and may cause deaths.\n\nHFMD mainly occurs among children under 10 years old. The usual period from infection to onset of symptoms is 3-7 days. The disease usually begins with fever, poor appetite, malaise, and frequently with a sore throat. One or 2 days after fever onset, painful sores develop in the mouth. They begin as small red spots that blister and then often become ulcers. They are usually located on the tongue, gums and inside of the cheeks. A non-itchy skin rash develops over 1-2 days with flat or raised red spots, some with blisters. The rash is usually located on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet and may also appear on the buttocks and/or genitalia. A person with HFMD may not have symptoms or may have only the rash or only mouth ulcers. In a small number of cases, children may experience a brief febrile illness, present with mixed neurological and respiratory symptoms, and succumb rapidly from the disease.\n\nHFMD virus is contagious, and infection is spread from person to person by direct contact with nose or throat discharges, saliva, fluid from blisters, or the stool of infected persons. Infected persons are most contagious during the 1st week of the illness, but the period of communicability can last for several weeks. HFMD is not transmitted from pets or other animals. HFMD should not be confused with the different disease in animals called foot-and-mouth disease.\n\nPresently, there is no specific treatment available for HFMD. Patients should drink plenty of water or other liquids and may require treatment of the symptoms. Health care providers are advised to treat patients according to their symptoms and to refrain from using steroids. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/147.]", "summary": "Among the symptoms of HFMD are fever, sore throat, mouth ulcers on the inside of the mouth or sides of the tongue, rash (flat or raised spots) or small blisters on palms of hands, soles of feet, and/or buttocks, lethargy and poor appetite. Doctors say the number of cases has almost doubled compared to last year [2013]. 'I've been seeing dozens of children in the last few weeks,' said Dr Vijay Yewale, president of Indian Academy of Pediatrics.\n\nThe infection, considered highly contagious, is relatively unharmful. The symptoms commonly observed include fever, painful sores in the mouth, and a rash with blisters on hands, feet and also buttocks. HFMD is most commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16, which usually results in a mild, self-limiting disease with a few complications. HFMD is also caused by enteroviruses, including enterovirus 71 (EV71), which in large outbreaks in southeastern Asia has been associated with serious complications in certain groups and may cause deaths. The virus and the absolute number of cases are not elucidated here.\n\nHFMD mainly occurs amongst children under 10 years old. The usual period from infection to onset of symptoms is 3-7 days. The disease usually begins with fever, poor appetite, malaise, and frequently with a sore throat. One or 2 days after fever onset, painful sores develop in the mouth. They begin as small red spots that blister and then often become ulcers. They are usually located on the tongue, gums and inside of the cheeks. A non-itchy skin rash develops over 1-2 days with flat or raised red spots, some with blisters. The rash is usually located on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet and may also appear on the buttocks and/or genitalia. A person with HFMD may not have symptoms or may have only the rash or only mouth ulcers. In a small number of cases, children may experience a brief febrile illness, present with mixed neurological and respiratory symptoms and succumb rapidly from the disease.\n\nHFMD virus is contagious, and infection is spread from person to person by direct contact with nose or throat discharges, saliva, fluid from blisters, or the stool of infected persons. Infected persons are most contagious during the 1st week of the illness, but the period of communicability can last for several weeks. HFMD is not transmitted from pets or other animals. HFMD should not be confused with the different disease in animals called foot-and-mouth disease.\n\nPresently, there is no specific treatment available for HFMD. Patients should drink plenty of water or other liquids and may require treatment of the symptoms. The figure is down by 31.2 percent compared to the same period last year [2014]. However, the development of the disease is very complicated as the virus is acute. Infected children have with similar symptoms such as high fever, sore throat, and fluid-filled blisters appeared on the hands, feet, and inside the mouth.\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease can occur year-round but the peak season is in the summer and fall months. The viruses that cause Hand-foot-mouth disease can be spread in respiratory droplets. Uyen Phuong]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is a common infectious disease of infants and children. The symptoms commonly observed include fever, painful sores in the mouth, and a rash with blisters on hands, feet, and also buttocks. HFMD is most commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16, which usually results in a mild, self-limiting disease with a few complications. HFMD is also caused by other enteroviruses, including enterovirus 71 (EV71), which in large outbreaks in southeastern Asia has been associated with serious complications in certain groups and may cause deaths.\n\nHFMD mainly occurs among children under 10 years old. The usual period from infection to onset of symptoms is 3-7 days. The disease usually begins with fever, poor appetite, malaise, and frequently with a sore throat. One or 2 days after fever onset, painful sores develop in the mouth. They begin as small red spots that blister and then often become ulcers. They are usually located on the tongue, gums and inside of the cheeks. A non-itchy skin rash develops over 1-2 days with flat or raised red spots, some with blisters. The rash is usually located on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet and may also appear on the buttocks and/or genitalia. A person with HFMD may not have symptoms or may have only the rash or only mouth ulcers. In a small number of cases, children may experience a brief febrile illness, present with mixed neurological and respiratory symptoms and succumb rapidly from the disease.\n\nHFMD virus is contagious, and infection is spread from person to person by direct contact with nose or throat discharges, saliva, fluid from blisters, or the stool of infected persons. Infected persons are most contagious during the 1st week of the illness, but the period of communicability can last for several weeks. HFMD is not transmitted from pets or other animals. HFMD should not be confused with the different disease in animals called foot-and-mouth disease.\n\nPresently, there is no specific treatment available for HFMD. Patients should drink plenty of water or other liquids and may require treatment of the symptoms. Health care providers are advised to treat patients according to their symptoms and to refrain from using steroids.\n\nBorrowed from Mod.ST's comment in the PRO/MBDS post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20150120.3102437: 'In the 29 Dec 2014 WHO hand-foot-mouth disease situation update, Viet Nam reports a decrease in the number of cases since week 39 (22-28 Sep 2014), but following the seasonal patterns. During week 51 (14-20 Dec 2014) there were 1412 new cases, a decrease of 56 cases (3.8 percent) compared to the previous week. As of 20 Dec 2014, cumulative cases reported in 2014: 79 485; cumulative deaths: 9 (http://www.wpro.who.int/emerging_diseases/hfmd_biweekly_29dec2014.pdf?ua=1)'. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152.]", "summary": "ST's comment in the PRO/MBDS post Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam 20150120.3102437: 'In the 29 Dec 2014 WHO hand-foot-mouth disease situation update, Viet Nam reports a decrease in the number of cases since week 39 (22-28 Sep 2014), but following the seasonal patterns. Herpangina, which is similar in nature to the hand-foot-mouth disease [HFMD], mostly affects children, causing them to develop sores or blisters in the mouth. They will also show symptoms of a fever and have difficulty eating and drinking. Often, the symptoms are mild and the disease can disappear within a week.\n\nThe number of herpangina cases is on the rise in Beijing, according to the Capital Institute of Pediatrics. The hospital received 987 cases of herpangina over the past week, said Chi Yang, the hospital's public relations official, on Thu 19 Jun 2014. But the disease is not caused by a new virus strain, said Huang Hui, a doctor at the hospital's department of infectious diseases, refuting an online post that linked the rise in cases to a new strain of the herpangina virus.\n\nBoth herpangina and hand-foot-and-mouth disease are caused by an infection of enteroviruses, Huang said. The summer and autumn seasons usually see a high incidence of both diseases among children from 1 to 7, Huang said.\n\nMeanwhile, the number of newly discovered cases of hand-foot-mouth disease in Beijing has been increasing every week since the end of April 2014, according to a weekly report of contagious diseases issued by the city's health authorities. There have been 2860 cases of hand-foot-mouth disease reported in the city over the past week, the health authorities said on Thu 19 Jun 2014.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Herpangina and HFMD can be different manifestations of the same strain of enterovirus and reported in this article published electronically several years ago in Pediatrics (Ruan F, Yang T, Ma H, et al: Risk factors for hand, foot, and mouth disease and herpangina and the preventive effect of hand-washing. Pediatrics. 2011; 127(4): e898-904; http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/content/early/2011/03/21/peds.2010-1497.full.pdf)\n\nAbstract\n--------\nBackground: Hygiene and social distancing are recommended control measures for hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) and herpangina. However, empirical data to support this recommendation are limited.\n\nMethods: During an outbreak of HFMD and herpangina due to infection by the human enterovirus 71, we defined a case as a vesicular papular rash on the hands, feet, buttocks, or oral mucosa and onset from 30 Apr to 26 Jun 2008. We selected 176 HFMD and herpangina case-children and a stratified random sample of 201 asymptomatic control-children; frequency matched according to residency status. We administered a questionnaire to the parents about their children's exposures and hygienic behaviors.\n\nResults: Risk factors for HFMD and herpangina included playing with neighborhood children (odds ratio [OR]: 11 [95 percent confidence interval (CI): 6.2-17]), visiting an outpatient clinic for another reason 1 week or less before onset (OR: 20 [95 percent CI: 5.0-88]), and community exposures to crowded places (OR: 7.3 [95 percent CI: 4.1-13]). By using a score summarizing responses to 4 hand-washing questions, we found that 50 percent of the case-children and 2.5 percent of control-children had a poor score of 1 to 3, whereas 12 percent of the case-children and 78 percent of control-children had a good score of 7 or higher (OR: 0.00069 [95 percent CI: 0.0022-0.022]) after we adjusted for residency, age, and community exposures by using logistic regression.\n\nConclusions: Hand-washing by preschool-aged children and their caregivers had a significant protective effect against community-acquired HFMD and herpangina from the human enterovirus 71 infection.\n\nA picture of the oral manifestations of herpangina can be seen at http://diseasespictures.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/10/Herpangina-6.jpg. The number of cases represented a 14 percent drop from the same period last year [2013]. However, there were areas that have seen an increase in affected cases in comparison to last year's [2013] issue, including Ho Chi Minh City and other southern provinces such as Ba Ria- Vung Tau, Ca Mau, Soc Trang, Binh Duong, and Bac Lieu.\n\nHFMD is an illness that causes sores in or on the mouth and on the hands, feet, and sometimes the buttocks and legs. The sores may be painful, but the illness usually doesn't last more than a week or so. The disease is common among children, but can also occur in adults. Although it can occur at any time of year, it's most common during the summer and fall.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MBDS\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As demonstrated in the abstract of an Australian report (McMinn P, Stratov I, Nagarajan L, Davis S: Neurological manifestations of enterovirus 71 infection in children during an outbreak of hand, foot, and mouth disease in Western Australia. Clin Infect Dis. 2001;32: 236-242), enterovirus 71, 1st described in 1974, can have a variety of potentially fatal neurological complications:\n\n'Enterovirus 71 (EV71) causes epidemics of hand, foot, and mouth disease associated with neurological complications in young children. We report an outbreak of EV71-associated neurological disease that occurred from February through September 1999 in Perth, Western Australia. 14 children with culture-proven, EV71-induced neurological disease were identified. 9 patients (64 percent) developed severe neurological disease; 4 of these patients developed long-term neurological sequelae. Neurological syndromes included aseptic meningitis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, acute transverse myelitis, acute cerebellar ataxia, opso-myoclonus syndrome, benign intracranial hypertension, and a febrile convulsion. Clinical and magnetic resonance imaging data indicated that immunopathology was a major factor in the pathogenesis of neurological disease in this outbreak. This finding is in contrast to reports of previous EV71 epidemics in which virus-induced damage to gray matter was the most frequent cause of neurological disease.'\n\nAlthough no commercial EV71 vaccine is yet available, a recent publication suggests a vaccine may be in the offing (Li R, Liu L, Mo Z, et al: An inactivated enterovirus 71 vaccine in healthy children. N Engl J Med 2014; 370:829-837). The abstract is shown below:\n\n'We conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 3 trial involving healthy children 6 to 71 months of age in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, China. 2 doses of an inactivated EV71 vaccine or placebo were administered intramuscularly, with a 4-week interval between doses, and children were monitored for up to 11 months. The primary end point was protection against hand, foot, and mouth disease caused by EV71.\n\n'A total of 12 000 children were randomly assigned to receive vaccine or placebo. Serum neutralizing antibodies were assessed in 549 children who received the vaccine. The seroconversion rate was 100 percent 4 weeks after the 2 vaccinations, with a geometric mean titer of 170.6. Over the course of 2 epidemic seasons, the vaccine efficacy was 97.4 percent (95 percent confidence interval [CI], 92.9 to 99.0) according to the intention-to-treat analysis and 97.3 percent (95 percent CI, 92.6 to 99.0) according to the per-protocol analysis. Adverse events, such as fever (which occurred in 41.6 percent of the participants who received vaccine vs. 35.2 percent of those who received placebo), were significantly more common in the week after vaccination among children who received the vaccine than among those who received placebo.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/152.]", "summary": "Adverse events, such as fever (which occurred in 41.6 percent of the participants who received vaccine vs. 35.2 percent of those who received placebo), were significantly more common in the week after vaccination among children who received the vaccine than among those who received placebo.' - Mod. 2001;32: 236-242), enterovirus 71, 1st described in 1974, can have a variety of potentially fatal neurological complications:\n\n'Enterovirus 71 (EV71) causes epidemics of hand, foot, and mouth disease associated with neurological complications in young children. \n\n\nLast week [week ending 1 Jun 2014], around 1900 children were hospitalized with hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) nationwide, up 4 percent from the week before, the Health Ministry's Administration of Preventive Medicine reported yesterday [2 Jun 2014]. Dr. Nguyen Huu Hung, deputy director of the HCMC Health Department's Preventive Health Center, issued the warning in a recent meeting with health centers from 24 districts of the city.\n\nAccording to the center, 3373 HFMD cases were reported in the city in 2014 as of 9 May 2014, up 28.3 percent since 2013. Of this number, 478 children received in-patient treatment, double the number of patients in March 2014, Dr. Trinh Huu Tung, head of the General Planning of the hospital, said. Meanwhile, during the 1st 4 months of this year [2014], only a little over 2000 children with HFMD were admitted to the institution for treatment, less than 20 cases per day, said Dr. Le Bich Lien, deputy director of the hospital. In fact, the number of children with HFMD has steadily increased since February 2014 and will continue to rise, Dr. Lien said.\n\nNationwide, the disease has spread to 62 of the country's 63 localities, affecting more than 17 400 people and killing 2 as of 13 May 2014, the Ministry of Health announced.\n\nIn Viet Nam, the most common strain is enterovirus 71 (EV-71), which causes sores in the mouth and blisters on the hands, feet, knees, and buttocks, according to the Health Ministry's Preventive Health Department.\n\nThe ministry has requested that authorities at all levels make the following information known to the public: the disease can be transmitted through digestive tracts; there are no vaccines or specific medicines to combat the disease; children under 5 years old are most vulnerable; and the main preventive measures are following hygienic practices in eating, drinking, and living.\n\nIn Viet Nam, HFMD occurs throughout the year in most provinces in the country, but the disease is more prevalent from March to May and from September to December every year. We report an outbreak of EV71-associated neurological disease that occurred from February through September 1999 in Perth, Western Australia. 14 children with culture-proven, EV71-induced neurological disease were identified. Nine patients (64 percent) developed severe neurological disease; 4 of these patients developed long-term neurological sequelae. Neurological syndromes included aseptic meningitis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, acute transverse myelitis, acute cerebellar ataxia, opso-myoclonus syndrome, benign intracranial hypertension, and a febrile convulsion. Clinical and magnetic resonance imaging data indicated that immunopathology was a major factor in the pathogenesis of neurological disease in this outbreak. This finding is in contrast to reports of previous EV71 epidemics in which virus-induced damage to gray matter was the most frequent cause of neurological disease.'\n\nAlthough no commercial EV71 vaccine is yet available, a recent publication suggests a vaccine may be in the offing (Li R, Liu L, Mo Z, et al: An inactivated Enterovirus 71 vaccine in healthy children. N Engl J Med 2014; 370:829-837). The abstract is shown below:\n\n'We conducted a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase 3 trial involving healthy children 6 to 71 months of age in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, China. This final review added an additional 2 cases between April to 5 Jul 2012, making the total number of children affected to be 59. Of these, 52 have died. The age of the cases range from 3 months to 11 years old, with the majority being under 3 years old. The overall male:female ratio is 1.3:1. Laboratory samples were not available for the majority of the cases as they died before appropriate samples could be taken.\n\nBased on the latest laboratory results, a significant proportion of the samples tested positive for enterovirus 71 (EV-71), which causes hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD). The EV-71 virus has been known to generally cause severe complications amongst some patients. Additionally, a number of other pathogens, including dengue and _Streptococcus suis_, were identified in some of the samples. The samples were found to be negative for H5N1 and other influenza viruses, SARS and Nipah viruses.\n\nFurther investigations into matching the clinical, laboratory and epidemiological information are ongoing and are likely to be concluded in a few days. WHO and partners, which include Institut Pasteur and the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, are assisting the Ministry of Health with this event. The government is also reinforcing awareness of good hygiene practices to the public, which include frequent washing of hands.\n\nSome facts on hand, foot and mouth disease: Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common infectious disease of infants and children. The symptoms commonly observed include fever, painful sores in the mouth, and a rash with blisters on hands, feet and also buttocks. HFMD is most commonly caused by coxsackievirus A16, which usually results in a mild, self-limiting disease with a few complications. HFMD is also caused by enteroviruses, including enterovirus 71 (EV71), which has been associated with serious complications in certain groups and may cause deaths.\n\nHFMD mainly occurs amongst children under 10 years old. The usual period from infection to onset of symptoms is 3-7 days. The disease usually begins with fever, poor appetite, malaise, and frequently with a sore throat. One or 2 days after fever onset, painful sores develop in the mouth. They begin as small red spots that blister and then often become ulcers. They are usually located on the tongue, gums and inside of the cheeks. A non-itchy skin rash develops over 1-2 days with flat or raised red spots, some with blisters. The rash is usually located on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet and may also appear on the buttocks and/or genitalia. A person with HFMD may not have symptoms or may have only the rash or only mouth ulcers. In a small number of cases, children may experience a brief febrile illness, present with mixed neurological and respiratory symptoms and succumb rapidly from the disease.\n\nHFMD virus is contagious, and infection is spread from person to person by direct contact with nose or throat discharges, saliva, fluid from blisters, or the stool of infected persons. Infected persons are most contagious during the 1st week of the illness, but the period of communicability can last for several weeks. HFMD is not transmitted from pets or other animals. HFMD should not be confused with the different disease in animals called foot-and-mouth disease.\n\nPresently, there is no specific treatment available for HFMD. Patients should drink plenty of water or other liquids and may require treatment of the symptoms. Health care providers are advised to treat patients according to their symptoms and to refrain from using steroids.' - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/145.]", "summary": "\n\nThe following is an outbreak disease report from WHO (Mon 9 Jul 2012, http://www.who.int/csr/don/2012_07_09/en/index.html) regarding an earlier, impressive outbreak of an enterovirus 71 associated outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease, a usually quite benign illness in young children:\n\n'As part of the continuing investigations into the undiagnosed illness, the Ministry of Health of the Kingdom of Cambodia is finalizing the review of all suspected hospitalised cases.
