Communicated by:\nProMED-mail\n< HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - MEXICO: (MEXICO CITY) REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Mexico City", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MEXICO CITY", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Colonia Lindavista", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "NC", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1093926", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1093926", "date": "2012-04-08 13:20:06", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (05)\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 5 Apr 2012\nSource: IRIN Asia [edited]\nhttp://www.irinnews.org/Report/95244/VIETNAM-Mild-disease-turns-deadly-for=\n\nViet nam: Mild disease turns deadly for children\n----------------------------------------\nBANGKOK: A dangerous strain of the typically non-lethal hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) [virus] has affected more than 21 000 persons -- mostly children younger than five -- killing 16 thus far in Viet Nam, according to the Ministry of Health.\n\n'Despite being a benign viral infection in developed countries, the strain EV71 [Human enterovirus 71] of HFMD is causing multiple deaths of children under five here in Asia. We are especially worried about South Viet Nnam, where lots of children are in informal [hygienically unregulated] cr\u00e8ches while their parents work,' Bhupinder Tomar, representative of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) in Viet Nam, told IRIN.\n\nHFMD\u2019s symptoms are fever, sores in the mouth and blisters on the hands and feet. The disease spreads by direct contact with fluids from infected persons and there is no specific treatment. Most of the viruses that cause HFMD are benign, but EV71 can be fatal. The new strain appeared in Viet Nam over the past year and since then it has become a serious public health issue for children, according to the World Health Organization.\n\nThe risk of catching HFMD is greatly reduced by improving hygiene, which IFRC is trying to promote through an existing public education campaign.\n\nIn 2011 there were 110 000 reported infections and 169 deaths linked to EV71, mostly in the south of the country. The disease is active year-round and peaks between April-May and then again in September-October. In March 2012 there were twice as many deaths and seven times as many infections as in the same period last year.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n\n[HFMD is a common, mild and self-limiting rash-associated illness in most children, with Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) or Enterovirus 71 (EV71) the predominant causative agents. Since first described in California in 1969, EV71 has been reported to be responsible for many large outbreaks all over the world, including outbreaks that occurred in South and East Asia from 1997 onwards. Generally, these outbreaks were accompanied by a small number of cases with severe neurologic disease such as acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, myocarditis, and fatal encephalitis. The EV71 viruses have been classified into three independent lineages, A, B, and C, based on the structural VP1 gene; each group has at least 15% divergence from the others. Consequently the epidemiology of EV71-associated HFMD in South and East Asia is proving to be very complex. For example a recent study of Enterovirus 71 strains from severe and mild disease patients in North-eastern China identified seven circulating EV71 viruses (see: Xiaomei Wang et al., PLoS ONE 7(3): e32405. doi:10.1371/journal.pone.0032405, 29 Mar 2012 http://www.plosone.org/article/info:doi/10.1371/journal.pone.0032405). These EV71 viruses contained genetic recombination events between four distinct EV71 strains. Most of the structural protein region (P1) of these viruses resembled that of the prototype EV71 C1 strain. The non-structural protein domains (P2 and P3) showed a high degree of similarity with Coxsackieviruses A4 and A5. The 5\u2032UTR (untranslated region) showed a high degree of similarity to Coxsackievirus A16. However, irrespective of genotype no correlation was observed between genotype and virulence. In the immediate future education and control of hygiene and sanitation may remain the best options for containment of HFMD, rather than vaccine development.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap of Vet Nam can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/008c. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n Source: IRIN Asia [edited]\nhttp://www.irinnews.org/Report/95244/VIETNAM-Mild-disease-turns-deadly-for=\n\nViet nam: Mild disease turns deadly for children\n A dangerous strain of the typically non-lethal hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) [virus] has affected more than 21 000 persons -- mostly children younger than five -- killing 16 thus far in Viet Nam, according to the Ministry of Health. HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (05)\n********************************************\n For example a recent study of Enterovirus 71 strains from severe and mild disease patients in North-eastern China identified seven circulating EV71 viruses (see: Xiaomei Wang et al. Despite being a benign viral infection in developed countries, the strain EV71 [Human enterovirus 71] of HFMD is causing multiple deaths of children under five here in Asia. The new strain appeared in Viet Nam over the past year and since then it has become a serious public health issue for children, according to the World Health Organization. Generally, these outbreaks were accompanied by a small number of cases with severe neurologic disease such as acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, myocarditis, and fatal encephalitis. \n\n--\n [HFMD is a common, mild and self-limiting rash-associated illness in most children, with Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) or Enterovirus 71 (EV71) the predominant causative agents. We are especially worried about South Viet Nnam, where lots of children are in informal [hygienically unregulated] cr\u00e8ches while their parents work,' Bhupinder Tomar, representative of the International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) in Viet Nam, told IRIN.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis"], "event_date": ["2012-03-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "1969-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-03-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "North - eastern", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Vet Nam", "country": "Laos"}, {"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1084829", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand-foot & mouth disease - USA: (multistate) Coxsackievirus A6", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1084829", "date": "2012-03-29 19:01:01", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA: (MULTISTATE), COXSACKIEVIRUS A6\n*******************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 29 Mar 2012\nSource: Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report (MMWR), Weekly, Notes from the Field, March 30, 2012 / 61(12);213-214 [edited]\nhttp://www.cdc.gov/mmwr/preview/mmwrhtml/mm6112a5.htm?s_cid=mm6112a5_e\n\n\nSevere Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease Associated with Coxsackievirus A6 -- Alabama, Connecticut, California, and Nevada, November 2011 to February 2012\n-----------------------------------\nHand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness caused by enteroviruses that predominantly affect children aged under 5 years. In the United States, outbreaks of HFMD typically occur during summer and autumn months. The most common cause of HFMD in the United States has been enterovirus serotype coxsackievirus A16. Most infections are asymptomatic; persons with signs and symptoms typically have a mild febrile illness with rash on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet, and sores in the mouth. HFMD also has been associated, often weeks after initial symptom onset, with nail dystrophies (e.g., Beau's lines or nail shedding).\n\nFrom 7 Nov 2011, to 29 Feb 2012, CDC received reports of 63 persons with signs and symptoms of HFMD or with fever and atypical rash in Alabama (38 cases), California (7), Connecticut (1), and Nevada (17). HFMD is not a reportable disease in the United States; the cases were identified as unusual by health-care providers or by a department of health that contacted CDC for diagnostic assistance. Clinical specimens were collected from patients in 34 of the 63 cases. Coxsackievirus A6 (CVA6) was detected in 25 (74 percent) of those 34 patients by reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction and partial sequencing of the VP1 gene at CDC or at the California Department of Public Health. No enteroviruses were detected in the other 9 patients.\n\nOf the 63 patients, 40 (63 percent) were aged under 2 years, and 15 (24 percent) were adults aged 18 years or older; 44 (70 percent) of the patients had exposure to a child care facility or school, and 8 (53 percent) of the 15 adults had contact with children in childcare where cases of HFMD [hand, foot and mouth disease] were reported, or provided medical care, or were related to a child with HFMD.\n\nRash and fever were more severe, and hospitalization was more common than with typical HFMD. Signs of HFMD included fever (48 patients [76 percent]); rash on the hands or feet, or in the mouth (42 [67 percent]); and rash on the arms or legs (29 [46 percent]), face (26 [41 percent]), buttocks (22 [35 percent]), and trunk (12 [19 percent]). Of 46 patients with rash variables reported, the rash typically was maculopapular; vesicles were reported in 32 (70 percent) patients and scabs in 30 (65 percent) patients. Shedding of nails [onychomadesis] occurred after initial infection in 2 (4 percent) patients. Of the 63 patients, 51 (81 percent) sought care from a clinician, and 12 (19 percent) were hospitalized. Reasons for hospitalization varied and included dehydration and/or severe pain. No deaths were reported.\n\nThe age ranges of patients, severity of illness, seasonality of disease, and identification of CVA6 [Coxsackievirus A6] in these cases were unusual for HFMD in the United States. CVA6 has been associated with more severe and extensive rash than HFMD caused by other enteroviruses (1). Since 2008, international outbreaks of CVA6 HFMD in children and adults have been described (1-4), but no outbreaks had been reported in the United States previously. Although all 25 of the CVA6 strains identified in the U.S. cases were genetically closely related (based on partial VP1 gene sequences) to CVA6 strains identified in recent international outbreaks, no epidemiologic evidence (e.g., travel history) has directly linked any of the U.S. cases to importation.\n\nHFMD is spread from person to person by contact with saliva, respiratory secretions, fluid in vesicles, and feces. Transmission of HFMD can be reduced by maintaining good hygiene, including handwashing and disinfection of surfaces in child care settings (5). CDC continues to receive reports of CVA6-associated HFMD. Persons who suspect a severe case of HFMD should contact their health-care provider. Local or state health departments may contact CDC for assistance with enterovirus laboratory diagnosis.\n\nReferences:\n1. Wei SH, Huang YP, Liu MC, et al. An outbreak of coxsackievirus A6 hand, foot, and mouth disease associated with onychomadesis in Taiwan, 2010. BMC Infect Dis 2011;11:346.\n2. Blomqvist S, Klemola P, Kaijalainen S, et al. Co-circulation of coxsackievirus A6 and A10 in hand, foot and mouth disease outbreak in Finland. J Clin Virol 2010;48:49-54.\n3. Fujimoto T, Iizuka S, Enomoto M, et al. Hand, foot and mouth disease caused by coxsackievirus A6, Japan, 2011. Emerg Infect Dis 2012;18:337-9.\n4. Wu Y, Yeo A, Phoon MC, et al. The largest outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in Singapore in 2008: the role of enterovirus 71 and coxsackievirus A strains. Int J Infect Dis 2010;14:e1076-81.\n5. Ruan F, Yang T, Ma H, et al. Risk factors for hand, foot, and mouth disease and herpangina and the preventative effect of hand-washing. Pediatrics 2011;127:e898-904.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is a fuller account of the outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease caused by Coxsackievirus A6 infection described initially in Alabama and now known to have involved the states of Connecticut, California, and Nevada. In east Asian countries in recent years, the disease has been associated with outbreaks of Enterovirus 71 infection and can be more severe, with a small proportion of children experiencing neurological complications, occasionally with fatal outcomes. The disease is a common viral illness that most often affects children but can occur among adults.\n\nMost infections cause little or no symptoms in children. The period from initial infection to the onset of signs and symptoms (incubation period) is from 3 to 7 days. Symptoms may include: fever; sore throat; a feeling of being unwell (malaise); painful, red, blister-like lesions on the tongue, gums and insides of the cheeks; a red rash without itching but sometimes with blistering on the palms, soles and sometimes the buttocks; irritability in infants and toddlers; loss of appetite.\n\n'We have seen some cases of HFMD within the school systems we monitor weekly,' stated Jamey Keen, Public Health Nurse at Southwest Nebraska Public Health Department. 'If you notice any of the symptoms, notify your physician.'\n\nThe virus is spread from person to person by contact with saliva, respiratory secretions, fluid in vesicles and feces. HFMD is not related to foot-and-mouth disease, which is an infectious viral disease found in farm animals. You can't contract HFMD from pets or other animals, and you can't transmit it to them.\n\nHFMD is usually a minor illness that goes away after a few days of the fever and symptoms. The most common complication of the disease is dehydration. The illness can cause sores in the mouth and throat, making swallowing painful and difficult. Watch closely to make sure your child frequently sips fluid during the course of the illness. If your child is taking in very little fluids, contact your family physician for further evaluation. Although rare, this disease can involve the brain, leading to more serious complications such as meningitis or encephalitis.\n\nHandwashing is the single most effective way to prevent infection, and good hand hygiene is important. Disinfecting common areas and surfaces in child care settings, whether public or private, as well as surfaces at home will help kill the virus that causes hand-foot-mouth disease. To disinfect surfaces, wash with soap and water first and then with a diluted solution of chlorine bleach, approximately 1/4th cup of bleach to one gallon of water. All common areas, including shared items such as toys, need to be disinfected, as the virus can live on these objects for days. Clean your baby's pacifiers often as well.\n\nBecause HFMD is highly contagious, people with the illness should limit their exposure to others while they have active signs and symptoms. Keep children out of child care or school until the fever is gone and mouth sores have healed. If you have the illness, stay home. A person who suspects a severe outbreak of HFMD should contact the Southwest Nebraska Public Health Department at (308) 345-4223 or their family physician for assistance.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness caused by enteroviruses that predominantly affect children aged under 5 years. Last year HFMD [hand, foot and mouth disease] peaked in April-May and again in August-September, but this year the disease has sharply increased in the 1st months, prompting the belief that a more complex and serious epidemic situation may be developing, he said.\n\nAccording to the ministry's statistics, high numbers of HFMD patients in the past 6 weeks have been recorded in 10 provinces and cities, namely Hai Phong, Dong Thap, Khanh Hoa, Kien Giang, Can, Tho, Ca Mau, Dak Lak, An Giang, Vinh Long and Hau Giang.\n\nSo far this year, 124 children in Ho Chi Minh City have suffered from the disease, an increase of 18 patients compared to the same period last year. The number of wards or communes having at least 2 patients has increased to 28 from 13 in the 6th week. With 4 patients, Binh Chanh District's Binh Hung commune has led the city in the number of HMFD sufferers so far.\n\nAs of mid February, the number of children with HMFD in Vinh Long was 128, an increase of 40 from a year earlier, and one of them has died.\n\nIn Can Tho, 600 children have been admitted to the Can Tho Pediatrics Hospital since the beginning of the year, and 3 of them have died. The local health authorities have cleaned the environment and sprayed antiseptic at affected areas and their surroundings. Can Tho authorities have also launched a campaign for environmental hygiene across the city, especially in schools, kindergartens and families with children under 5 years old.\n\nMeanwhile, patient overload has occurred in the Obstetrics-Pediatrics Center of the Da Nang General Hospital in the central city of Da Nang, where 140 children have been hospitalized despite the center having only 40 official sickbeds. These children were not only from the city but also from Quang Nam and Quang Ngai provinces.\n\nDr Nguyen Tam Lang, head of the Epidemiology and Entomology Department at the center, forecast that HFMD will have unforeseen developments this year and the disease will spread widely in central provinces.\n\nFrom 6 Jan to 12 Feb 2012, the city had 46 children with HFMD, while during February 2011, only 4 children were found to have contracted the disease, the doctor said. As of 19 Feb 2012 the number of HFMD patients had increased to 61, he added.\n\nThis week the ministry will send 5 working teams to the affected localities to assist local authorities in controlling, preventing and driving back the epidemic, said Deputy Health Minister Nguyen Thanh Long. The Preventive Health Department will also set up 12 additional teams to give support to local authorities, Duong said. Long requested local health authorities strengthen their efforts to combat the epidemic and that hospitals review their therapy regimens to make them more appropriate for each type of patient. The ministry will report the epidemic situation to the government and propose that it establish an interdisciplinary steering board to fight the epidemic nationwide, he said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This account of what promises to become a major outbreak of HFMD in the Central Provinces of Viet Nam is rather short on specific detail, other than lists of case numbers. This figure is 7.5 times higher than the same period last year, according to the Health Ministry's preventive medicine department.\n\nSouthern provinces account for the majority of patients, with 19 per 100 000 people infected, said Nguyen Van Binh, head of the department. The virus is transmitted through saliva, blister fluid and feces, but it is rare among adults, whose immune systems are generally strong enough to fight it off [i.e., are more likely to have partial immunity through previous exposure. - Mod.CP].\n\nThe disease is life-threatening in a small number of cases, owing to complications such as lung haemorrhages and meningitis. Last year, HFMD killed 166 people in Viet Nam, most of them children. The death toll was 10 times higher than the previous year as a more dangerous strain of the virus became more prevalent.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@prommedmail.org>\n\n[This report adds little to the previous report from Viet Nam on 21 Feb 2012, other than to reinforce the prediction that a major outbreak of HFMD is underway. The outbreak is still affecting mainly the southern provinces of the country.\n\nA considerable amount of information has been accumulated in recent years about the epidemiology of HFMD and the several different enteric viruses associated with this disease. It is likely that as in previous years in south and east Asia human enterovirus 71 (EV71) will be the predominant etiologic agent, but specific confirmatory information is still lacking.\n\nHFMD is spread from person to person by direct contact with the infectious viruses that cause this disease. These viruses are found in the nose and throat secretions (such as saliva, sputum, or nasal mucus), fluid in blisters, and stool of infected persons. The viruses may be spread when infected persons touch objects and surfaces that are then touched by others. Infected persons are most contagious during the 1st week of the illness. The viruses that cause HFMD can remain in the body for weeks after a person's symptoms have gone away. This means that infected people can still pass the infection to others even though they may appear well. Also, some people who are infected and shedding the virus, including most adults, may have no symptoms. HFMD not transmitted to or from pets or other animals, and is most prevalent where sanitation is poor.\n\nIt has been observed that infection with EV71 is occasionally associated with severe neurological disease such as acute encephalitis, acute flaccid paralysis, and cardiopulmonary failure. Recently specific cellular receptors and host factors that enhance EV71 infection and the development of more severe disease have been identified (Yamayoshi S, Fujii K, Koike S. Front Microbiol.; 3:32), 2012).\n\nA map of the provinces of Viet Nam can be accessed at:\nhttp://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \nCases of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) have surged, infecting nearly 12 400 children and killing 11 in the 1st 2 months of this year, authorities said Tuesday (13 Mar 2012). The symptoms include fever, sore throat, mouth ulcers and blisters on the hands and feet.\n\n[Byline: Poon Chian Hui]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The identity of the etiologic agent in the current outbreak has yet to been revealed. The following background information on HFMD in Singapore is reproduced from a recent publication in BMC Infect Dis. 2011; 11: 270. By: Li W Ang, Meng C Phoon, Yan Wu, Jeffery Cutter, Lyn James,and Vincent T Chow, http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2334/11/270.\n\n'Enterovirus 71 (EV71) and coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) have caused large epidemics of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) worldwide. Since EV71 was 1st identified in 1969 from an infant suffering from encephalitis in California, outbreaks associated with this virus have been documented, including in Australia in 1972, Japan in 1973 and 1978, Bulgaria in 1975 and Hungary in 1978. EV71 infection is occasionally associated with severe complications (such as encephalitis) and deaths in children. Since 1997, EV71-related HFMD epidemics in the Asia-Pacific region have been increasingly reported, including in Sarawak, Malaysia in 1997, 2000, 2003 and 2006; Brunei in 2006; Perth, Australia in 1999 [11]; Taiwan in 1998 and 2000; Japan in 2000 and 2003; and China in 2008.\n\n'In Singapore, HFMD was 1st recognized in an outbreak in June-July 1970, but the etiologic agent was hitherto unknown. CA16 was associated with 2 other outbreaks without serious complications or fatalities, involving 104 individuals between September 1972 and January 1973, and 742 individuals between September and December 1981. EV71 was 1st isolated from an infant with symptoms of HFMD in Singapore in 1984. Between September and October 2000, a large EV71-associated HFMD outbreak occurred in Singapore, resulting in 4 deaths. HFMD became notifiable under the Infectious Diseases Act from 1 Oct 2000. All preschool centers were closed from 1 Oct to 15 Oct 2000. By 28 Oct 2000, a total of 2827 cases were notified. The main pathologic findings in the fatal cases were encephalitis, interstitial pneumonitis, and myocarditis. Thereafter, EV71-associated HFMD epidemics occurred in 2006 and 2008, with the latter being the largest known HFMD outbreak in Singapore.\n\n'HFMD is endemic in Singapore, and more than 50 percent of cases occur in children below 5 years of age. Although the predominant circulating enteroviruses change periodically, the 2 major enteroviruses causing nationwide HFMD epidemics in Singapore have been CA16 and EV71.\n\n'An EV71 serologic survey in Singapore had been conducted on serum samples collected from 856 children aged 12 years or younger at a pediatric clinic at the National University Hospital (NUH) between July 1996 and December 1997. All children who were born at the hospital or brought for routine visits and vaccinations during this 18-month period were included, and they did not exhibit HFMD-related symptoms at the time of sample collection. Since then, there had not been any comprehensive survey to measure the EV71 seroprevalence between or after EV71-associated HFMD epidemics in Singapore.\n\n'Between August 2008 and July 2010, we conducted a seroprevalence survey to estimate the levels of EV71-specific neutralizing antibodies among children and adolescents aged between 1-17 years. This was the largest and 2nd nationally representative survey conducted to ascertain the latest age-specific seroprevalence of EV71 infection in Singapore. We compared our findings with the results of the 1996-1997 study to discern any significant changes over the past decade.\n\n'Our study revealed that EV71 infection is very common among Singapore children and adolescents, with 39 percent infected by the time they are in secondary school (i.e. 13-17 years of age). The previous 1996-1997 study was conducted before the 1st EV71-associated HFMD epidemic occurred in 2000. Our survey commenced in August 2008, several months after an HFMD epidemic started in Singapore around March 2008. This may have contributed in part to the EV71 seroprevalence found in our survey.\n\n'Around the same period in 2008, there were heightened levels of EV71 activity in the Asia-Pacific region, including Malaysia, mainland China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan [28]. In China, EV71-associated epidemics were documented in many provinces from March to August 2008, with about 490 000 HFMD cases, including 126 fatalities reported in 2008.'\n\n'Based on our findings, higher EV71-specific neutralizing antibody titers were observed in pre-school children aged 1-6 years than those in the other 2 older age groups, indicating that most of the infections had been acquired during early childhood. Seroprevalence surveys conducted periodically to measure the prevalence of EV71-neutralizing antibody in the pediatric population in Singapore will facilitate a more in-depth understanding of the epidemiologic trends and HFMD epidemics associated with EV71 infections.'\n\nInterested readers are recommended to read the full (open access) paper for a more detailed account of the analysis.\n\nThe HealthMap interactive map of Singapore can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1l5I. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "[Byline: Poon Chian Hui]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The identity of the etiologic agent in the current outbreak has yet to been revealed. \n\n'Between August 2008 and July 2010, we conducted a seroprevalence survey to estimate the levels of EV71-specific neutralizing antibodies among children and adolescents aged between 1-17 years. Can Tho Children's Hospital, the only children's hospital in the Mekong Delta, has been overloaded with hundreds of HFM-infected patients over the last few days. 2 to 3 children have had to share a bed. During the first 3 months of the year, the hospital received nearly 4500 children with the disease, 3 times higher than that of the same period last year.\n\nHalf of the patients were from other provinces in the Mekong Delta. More than 1000 people were hospitalised for treatment. 2 of them died. Le Hoang Son, director of the hospital, said 20 standby beds had been set up in anticipation of a likely increase until the end of June [2012]. Children contracting HFM in the earliest stages had been treated at home to ease the overload at the hospital. In many cases, HFM-infected children have been wrongly diagnosed as having pneumonia, dengue fever or meningitis by primary-care physicians. When they were later transferred to the hospital, the patients had already reached an advanced stage of the illness.\n\nMost hospitals in the provinces of Mekong Delta do not have proper equipment, including respirators, drop counters, syringe pumps and blood purification machines. Vo Huy Danh, director of An Giang Province's Preventive Medicine Centre, said that it had asked the provincial People's Committee to provide VND10 billion (USD 475 000) to purchase necessary equipment as well as chemicals for the prevention and treatment of the disease. This would reduce the number of fatalities as well as the number of patients transferred to hospitals in Can Tho and HCM City, Danh said.\n\nThe province has reported 5 deaths caused by HFM disease, the country's highest fatality rate. More than 700 children have contracted the disease, according to the province's Preventive Medicine Centre. More than 1000 cases, including 2 fatalities, have been recorded in Dong Thap Province this year [2012]. Ca Mau and Tien Giang provinces have each reported around 500 cases.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HFMD outbreak has now spread country-wide to embrace all of Viet Nam. The Mekong Delta (the 'Nine Dragon river delta') is the region in southwestern Viet Nam where the Mekong River approaches and empties into the sea through a network of tributaries. The Mekong delta region encompasses a large portion of southwestern Viet Nam of 39 000 square kilometres (15 000 square miles). The size of the area covered by water depends on the season. The Mekong Delta is Viet Nam's southernmost region, and contains 12 mostly small but populous provinces in the delta of the Mekong, plus the independent municipality of C\u00e1\u00ba\u00a7n.\n\nHFMD is a common, mild and self-limiting rash-associated illness in most children, with Coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) or Enterovirus 71 (EV71) the predominant causative agents. Since first described in California in 1969, EV71 has been reported to be responsible for many large outbreaks all over the world, including outbreaks that occurred in South and East Asia from 1997 onwards. Generally, these outbreaks were accompanied by a small number of cases with severe neurologic disease such as acute flaccid paralysis, pulmonary edema, myocarditis, and fatal encephalitis.\n\nAs discussed in the preceding post, the epidemiology of EV71 infection is likely to be very complex (see: Hand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (05) 20120408.1093926). The accumulated number of school classes forced to be suspended due to cluster infections reached 113 classes during this period, that is 3.22 times the 35 classes reported in the same period of 2011, the statistics show.\n\nThe city health department reminded the public that infants and toddlers aged under 5 are at the highest risk of severe EV infection. Children who develop symptoms of extreme sleepiness, unconsciousness, vomiting, persistent fever or seizures should be taken to local clinics or hospitals for medical treatment as soon as possible, the department said.\n\n[Byline: Huang Li-yun and Elizabeth Hsu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It seems likely that EV71 is the virus mainly responsible for the current outbreaks in Southeast and South Asia, although the causative agent is rarely specified.\n\nEV71 was 1st identified in 1969 from an infant suffering from encephalitis in California, and subsequent outbreaks associated with this virus have been described, including in Australia in 1972, Japan in 1973 and 1978, Bulgaria in 1975, and Hungary in 1978. EV71 infection is occasionally associated with severe complications (such as encephalitis) and deaths in children. Since 1997, EV71-related HFMD epidemics in the Asia-Pacific region have been increasingly reported, including in Sarawak, Malaysia in 1997, 2000, 2003 and 2006; Brunei in 2006; Perth, Australia in 1999 [11]; Taiwan in 1998 and 2000; Japan in 2000 and 2003; China in 2008, and currently in Viet Nam.\n\nEV71 phylogenetic analyses have revealed considerable genetic diversity. VP1 sequences [indicative of potential antigenic diversity] clustered into 3 genogroups, A, B and C, with genogroups B and C further divided into 5 subgenogroups, B1-B5 and C1-C5, respectively. All EV71 strains were clustered similarly in the 5'UTR and VP1 trees, except for one Taiwanese strain, which demonstrated different clustering in the 2 trees, suggesting a recombination event in the phylogeny.\n\nAnother recent overview describes the molecular epidemiology of human enterovirus 71 (HEV71) in the Asia-Pacific region from 1997 through 2002. Phylogenetic analysis of the VP4 and VP1 genes of recent HEV71 strains indicates that several genogroups of the virus have been circulating in the Asia-Pacific region since 1997. The 1st of these recent outbreaks, described in Sarawak (Malaysian Borneo) in 1997, was caused by genogroup B3. This outbreak was followed by large outbreaks in Taiwan in 1998, caused by genogroup C2, and in Perth (Western Australia) in 1999, where viruses belonging to genogroups B3 and C2 co-circulated. Singapore, Taiwan, and Sarawak had HEV71 epidemics in 2000, caused predominantly by viruses belonging to genogroup B4; however, large numbers of fatalities were observed only in Taiwan. HEV71 was identified during an epidemic of hand, foot and mouth disease in Korea; that epidemic was found to be due to viruses constituting a new genogroup, C3.\n\nSee:\n[1] J Gen Virol. 2010 Aug;91(Pt 8):1949-58. USA: (AL) Coxsackie A6 virus", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1039435", "date": "2012-02-11 18:23:45", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - USA: (ALABAMA) COXSACKIE A6 VIRUS\n**************************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 10 Feb 2012\nSource: Andalusia Star News [edited]\nhttp://www.andalusiastarnews.com/2012/02/10/docs-see-disease-outbreak/\n\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease in South Alabama\n----------------------------------------\nCovington County is experiencing an outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease, local pediatricians said Thursday (09 Feb 2012). Dr. Bhagwan Bang of South Alabama Pediatrics in Opp said other Alabama counties are reporting similar cases, as well. Hand foot mouth disease is a common viral illness that usually affects infants and children younger than 5 and can be contracted by not washing one's hands properly. Bang said the disease strain currently circulating locally has caused extensive and larger-than-normal lesions on the hands, feet and mouth. He said cases in adults have also been noted.\n\nHe said the same strain [virus species] -- Coxsackie A6 virus -- reportedly caused a 2008 epidemic in Finland, a 2004 and 2008 epidemic in Taiwan, and this year for the first time in the U.S.\n\n'Hand, foot and month disease usually starts with a fever, poor appetite, malaise and sore throat, painful sores in the mouth, on the palms of hands and soles of feet,' Bang said. 'It also appears on the knees, elbows and buttocks, and can also cause dehydration due to the inability to swallow fluid.' Bang said his office has seen several cases -- 2 of which were confirmed as the disease by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\n'This isn't something that should scare parents,' Bang said. 'They should just be aware of it and take precautions against it. The easiest way to stop the spread of this disease is by simply washing your hands after changing a dirty diaper, disinfecting a dirty surface and avoiding close contact with someone who is infected.'\n\nThose at Covington Pediatrics in Andalusia have seen similar cases, which they attribute to the unseasonably warm weather. The virus should not be confused with foot-and-mouth disease (sometimes called hoof-and-mouth disease), a disease of cattle, sheep and swine. The two diseases are caused by different viruses and are not related. Those concerned about symptoms should contact their health care provider.\n\n(By Stephanie Nelson)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from Health Map alefts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease occurs globally. In developed countries hand, foot and mouth disease is generally mild and often associated with outbreaks of Coxsackie A16 virus infection. In East Asian countries in recent years, the disease has been associated with outbreaks of Enterovirus 71 infection and can be more severe, with a small proportion of children experiencing neurological complications, occasionally with fatal outcome. The outbreak is concentrated in the southern part of the\ncountry, but cases have been reported from all regions.\n\nCities and provinces with the highest numbers of HFMD deaths are Ho\nChi Minh City, Dong Nai, Binh Duong, Long An, Ba Ria-Vung Tau, Bac\nLieu, Dong Tap, Tien Giang, and Quang Ngai.\n\nAs of mid-October 2011, Viet Nam had reported 80 000 cases of HFMD and\n137 deaths. As in other outbreaks of EV71-associated HFMD reported in\nSoutheast Asia since 1997, a small proportion of children with the\ndisease have developed severe, often fatal complications, including\nencephalitis.\n\nHFMD is a common illness that usually affects infants and young\nchildren. However, older children and adults can also become infected.\nHFMD can be caused by several different viruses. Symptoms of HFMD\ninclude fever, painful blister-like sores in the mouth, and a skin\nrash. HFMD is spread from person to person by direct contact with the\nviruses that cause this disease. These viruses can be found in saliva,\nnasal secretions, blister fluid, and feces of the infected persons.\nThe viruses also may be spread when an infected person touches objects\nand surfaces that are then touched by others.\n\nYou can protect yourself from HFMD by practicing healthy personal\nhygiene. Wash your hands often with soap and water, especially before\nyou eat, after you cough or sneeze, and after you go to the bathroom\nor change a baby's diaper. If soap and water are not available, use an\nalcohol-based hand gel (with at least 60 percent alcohol). Consider\npacking alcohol-based hand gel in your carry-on luggage to ensure you\nhave it when needed [However, you won't get through airport security\nwith it in the UK and many other countries. - Mod.CP]. Disinfect dirty\nsurfaces and soiled items. Avoid close contact such as kissing,\nhugging, or sharing eating utensils or cups with people with HFMD.\n\nThere is currently no vaccine to protect against the viruses that\ncause HFMD. The personal hygiene measures described above are the best\nprotection. There is no specific treatment for HFMD. However, some\nthings can be done to relieve symptoms, such as taking\nover-the-counter medications to relieve pain and fever (Caution:\nAspirin should not be given to children), and using mouthwashes or\nsprays that numb mouth pain. If a person develops mouth sores, staying\nhydrated is important. An ill person who cannot swallow enough liquids\nto stay hydrated should see a doctor. Fluids may need to be given\nintravenously.\n\nThe current outbreak in Viet Nam has been attributed to EV71. HFMD is\none of many infections that cause mouth sores. If laboratory diagnosis\nis required, throat swabs or stool specimens may be tested for\nenteroviruses.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[As of the end of October 2011, HFMD in Viet Nam was considered still\nto be under control according to Health Minister Nguyen Thi Kim Tien,\ndespite a rising number of new HFMD cases. Nguyen Van Binh, director of\nMOH Preventive Medicines Department, said the disease is under control\nwhile there are about 2000 newly affected cases per week, or 8000-10\n000 cases per month.\n\nHowever, in September [2011] alone, the country had more than 26 000\nnewly affected HFMD patients with 31 dead, and in the 1st half of\nOctober, the figures were reported at 10 000 and 16, respectively,\nsaid the report. So far, southern Ho Chi Minh City and central Quang\nNgai province are the most hit localities.\n\nThe MOH will announce the epidemic nationally when there are at least\n2 localities reporting that the disease is out of their control. The\nepidemic announcement will be made under 2 circumstances: 1st, when\nthe number of affected patients is more than those estimated by the\ncentrally-run medical agencies; 2ndly, when the disease develops\nout-of-control or when there appears some new agent that causes high\nfatal rate while there is not yet medicines for treatment, explained\nBinh.\n\nThe HFMD, caused by Human enterovirus 71 (EV71), has such symptoms as\nfever, throat pain and vesicle on the hand palms and foot soles. The\npatient can recover after about one week. However, sometimes the\ndisease is out of the doctor's control because it develops fast and\nleads to death, just within 24-72 hours when 1st symptoms are found.\n\nPatients are normally children under 3 years of age, but by the end of\nSeptember there were 8 adults having tests with EV virus, who had\ntaken care of the affected children, reported the Viet Nam's central\nNha Trang Pasteur Institute.\n\nMedical experts warned the disease would become more complicated in\nthe coming months due to the lack of preventive vaccines and specific\nmedicine for treatment. The disease is contaminated [transmitted ?]\nthrough the digestive system or direct contact, hence the rate of\ninfection is high, especially now when there are adults affected by\nHFMD but they have no apparent symptoms.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMed-mail correspondent Mary Marshall\n\n[From these figures it seems inevitable that the Vietnamese\nauthorities will have to declare that HFMD has acquired 'epidemic'\nstatus throughout Viet Nam.\n\nCB Tran and colleagues have recently published an analysis of the\nepidemiology of hand, foot and mouth disease in Viet Nam (PLoS One.\n2011;6(7):e21116. Epub 2011 Jul 12). They conclude that\nEV71-associated hand, foot and mouth disease has emerged as a serious\npublic health problem in South East Asia over the last decade. To\nbetter understand the prevalence of EV71 infection, these authors\ndetermined EV71 seroprevalence and sero-incidence amongst healthy\ninfants and children in Ho Chi Minh City. In a cohort of 200 newborns,\n55 per cent of cord blood samples contained EV71 neutralizing\nantibodies and these decayed to undetectable levels by 6 months of age\nin 98 per cent of infants. The EV71 neutralizing antibody\nseroconversion rate was 5.6 per cent in the 1st year and 14 per cent\nin the second year of life. In children 5-15 yrs of age,\nseroprevalence of EV71 neutralizing antibodies was 84 per cent and in\ncord blood it was 55 per cent. Taken together, these data suggest the\nEV71 rate of infection is high and highlights the need for more\nresearch into its epidemiology and pathogenesis in high disease burden\ncountries.\n\nA map showing the locations of Hanoi, HCM and the 61 provinces of Viet\nNam can be accessed at\nhttp://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "The\nepidemic announcement will be made under 2 circumstances: 1st, when\nthe number of affected patients is more than those estimated by the\ncentrally-run medical agencies; 2ndly, when the disease develops\nout-of-control or when there appears some new agent that causes high\nfatal rate while there is not yet medicines for treatment, explained\nBinh. Since 1\nJan 2011 to 4 Sep 2011, 98 deaths and 42 673 cases of HFMD have been\nconfirmed across the country. Three quarters of the deaths have been\nin children aged 3 years or less.\n\nViet Nam has implemented precautionary measures in an effort to reduce\nthe spread of HFMD. The Prime Minister of Viet Nam has instructed all\nprovincial authorities and relevant ministries to strengthen\nprevention and control measures against HFMD. In addition, formal\nguidelines for surveillance, prevention and treatment of the disease\nhave been sent to all health care facilities. 'The number of HFMD\ncases might increase in the coming months when preschools and\nkindergartens resume,' said Minister of Health, Ms. Nguyen Thi Kim\nTien.\n\nHFMD is a common viral illness among infants and children under the\nage of 10 years but can also occur in adults. The virus causes fever\nand sores in the throat and blisters on the hands and feet. The\ndisease is usually mild and patients generally recover in 7-10 days.\nThe disease is caused by a group of viruses known as Enterovirus\n[Family _Picornaviridae_, Genus _Enterovurus_]. One of these is EV71\n[Species _Human enterovirus A 71_] which on occasion can cause severe\ncomplications, including neurological, cardiovascular and respiratory\nproblems. In Viet Nam, the epidemiology of HFMD is complex but EV71 is\nresponsible for nearly half of the infections in those who have tested\npositive for HFMD.\n\nTypically, HFMD sporadically occurs across Viet Nam but remains most\nconcentrated in the Southern and Central provinces. Higher rates of\ninfection occur from March to May and September to December.\n\nThe Ministry of Health has begun conducting 84 training courses on\nsurveillance, prevention and control of HFMD that include preventive\nmedicine staff at provincial, district and communal level as well as\npre-school teachers. There is also an ongoing nation-wide public\nawareness campaign on television and other media to highlight these\npreventative measures.\n\nThe World Health Organization (WHO) along with the United States\nCenter for Disease Control (CDC) is supporting the Ministry of\nHealth's General Department of Preventive Medicine (GDPM) efforts to\ncontrol the disease. 'WHO and CDC are working closely with MOH to\ndetermine the cause of the unusual increase in cases and deaths, and\ninvestigate the epidemiological characteristics of HFMD in Viet Nam,'\nActing WHO Representative, Dr. Graham Harrison said.\n\nThe virus causing HFMD is spread from person to person through direct\ncontact with virus contained in nose and throat secretions, saliva,\nblister fluids, stools of infected persons and asymptomatic carriers.\nThe virus is most often spread by virus-contaminated hands and through\ncontact with contaminated surfaces. Infected persons are most\ncontagious during the 1st week of the illness. The viruses that cause\nHFMD can remain in the body for several weeks after a patient's\nsymptoms have gone away. This means that the infected person can still\npass the infection to other people even though they may appear to be\nwell.\n\nCurrently, there is no vaccine or specific medication against HFMD.\nHowever, the risk of infection is lowered significantly with high\nstandards of personal and environmental hygiene. The Ministry of\nHealth recommends the following precautionary measures:\n- Frequent hand washing with soap and water, especially after changing\ndiapers, before preparing food, before eating, and before feeding\nchildren, and after using the toilet;\n- Cover mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing;\n- Thoroughly clean contaminated surfaces and soiled items 1st with\nsoap and water and then with common disinfectant in homes, in child\ncare centers, kindergartens and schools, and maintain clean\nsurroundings;\n- Avoid sending children to child care centers, kindergartens or\nschools if they are suffering from HFMD;\n- Follow safe food and water practices. Children should eat\nwell-cooked food and drink boiled water. Do not share feeding\nutensils;\n- Avoid close contact (kissing, hugging etc.) with infected people;\n- Monitor children's health for early detection of symptoms and take\nthose who have persistent fever and blisters on hands, feet or mouth\nto the nearest health facility for treatment as soon as possible;\n- Ensure that kindergartens and pre-schools provide hand-washing\nfacilities, with soap and water, for young children, and have an\nappropriate system for managing human waste.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nLaura Ngo-Fontaine\nRisk Communication Officer -- WHO Viet Nam\n<media.vtn@wpro.who.int>\n\n[A map of Viet Nam and its various provinces can be accessed at:\nhttp://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html.\n\nIt would be relevant to learn the identity of the other enteroviruses\nfound to be present during the course of this outbreak, and their\nrelationship to severity of disease. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Health recommends the following precautionary measures:\n- Frequent hand washing with soap and water, especially after changing\ndiapers, before preparing food, before eating, and before feeding\nchildren, and after using the toilet;\n- Cover mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing;\n- Thoroughly clean contaminated surfaces and soiled items 1st with\nsoap and water and then with common disinfectant in homes, in child\ncare centers, kindergartens and schools, and maintain clean\nsurroundings;\n- Avoid sending children to child care centers, kindergartens or\nschools if they are suffering from HFMD;\n- Follow safe food and water practices. The death toll for HFMD has climbed to 81 among 32 588\ncases reported in 52 cities and provinces, according to the Viet Nam\nAdministration of Preventive Medicine.\n\nTran Thanh Duong, the agency's deputy chief, told the Viet Nam News\nAgency that fatalities have been reported in 17 cities and provinces,\nwith Ho Chi Minh City having the highest toll at 22, followed by the\nprovinces of Dong Nai, Binh Duong, Long An and Ba Ria-Vung Tau. Infection is spread from\nperson to person by direct contact with infectious virus. Infectious\nvirus is found in the nose and throat secretions, saliva, blister\nfluid, and stool of infected persons. The virus is most often spread\nby persons with unwashed, virus-contaminated hands and by contact with\nvirus-contaminated surfaces. Infected persons are most contagious\nduring the 1st week of the illness.\n\nOutbreaks of HFMDV infection are ubiquitous and only reported in\nProMED-mail when there are fatal outcomes or where the identity of the\netiologic agent has been confirmed by laboratory analysis.\n\nHFMD occurs mainly in children under 10 years old but can also occur\nin adults. Children are more likely to be at risk for infection and\nillness because they are less likely than adults to have antibodies to\nprotect them. The illness is caused by a number of enteroviruses, with\nhuman coxsackievirus A16 and human enterovirus 71 as the main\ncausative agents.\n\nHistorically, human enterovirus 71 has been associated with more\nsevere outcomes and fatalities. The severity of the current outbreak\nin Viet Nam has been attributed to prevalence of human enterovirus 71.\nHowever, strains of human enterovirus 71 are genetically diverse and\nnot always associated with severe outcomes, which may be the reason\nwhy no deaths have been reported during the course of the current\noutbreak in Malaysia (See: 'Genetic diversity of enterovirus 71\nisolated from cases of hand, foot and mouth disease in the 1997, 2000\nand 2005 outbreaks, Peninsular Malaysia. The disease has killed 137 people, mostly children, out of\n77 895 infections in the 63 cities and provinces across the country\n[i.e., the whole of Viet Nam - Mod.CP] this year.\n\nA report by the Viet Nam Administration of Preventive Medicine showed\n2900 new HFMD cases were recorded last week [16-22 Oct 2011], up 400\ncases from the previous week. Nguyen Van Binh, chief of the\nadministration, said the number of HFMD fatalities and infections\nwould continue to rise.\n\nLocal media have repeatedly asked why the Health Ministry has not\ndeclared the HFMD an epidemic so that more money and effort can be\npoured into prevention of the disease. Minister Tien reiterated a\nregulation on Tuesday [25 Oct 2011] that the ministry can announce a\nnational epidemic only after at least 2 provinces do so locally. 'In\nfact, HFMD is occurring in South Korea, Japan and China but none of\nthose countries have declared a national epidemic either,' she said.\n'No announcement made does not mean we are neglecting of the lives of\nthe children. We are trying our best to prevent the disease from\nspreading with the help of World Health Organization [WHO] experts in\nViet Nam.'\n\nInfection is typically mild and causes mouth sores and blisters on\nhands and feet. No vaccine or specific treatment exists, but most\nchildren typically recover quickly without problems.\n\nAccording to WHO updates on 11 Oct 2011, Viet Nam ranked 3rd in the\nnumber of HFMD infections among 7 countries and territories in the\nWestern Pacific region, after China and Japan. WHO said China, Japan,\nMacao (China) and South Korea were seeing a declining trend in the\nnumber of reported HFMD cases while Singapore continued to see\nlow-level activity. In comparison, China reported 1 217 768 HFMD\ncases, including 399 deaths, between January and September this year.\nIn Japan, 306 944 cases have been reported as of 2 Oct 2011, and In\nSingapore, 14 146 cases have been reported as of 1 Oct 2011.\n\nBig cities are facing the danger of HFMD outbreaks as more and more\nHFMD cases from other provinces rush to hospitals in big cities. In Ho\nChi Minh City [HCM], although the number of HFMD infections has not\nincreased since peak months (May-August), the number of child patients\nat Children's Hospital 1 has seen no decrease. The hospital's\nInfectious Diseases Department is always overloaded, with an average\n150 child patients a day, mostly from other provinces. Dr. Truong Huu\nKhanh, chief of the Infectious Diseases Department, said there were\ndays when more than 80 percent of child patients admitted to the\nhospital were from other provinces. 'The provinces with the most\npatients include Ben Tre, Tien Giang, Long An, Tay Ninh, Binh Phuoc,\nBinh Duong and Ba Ria-Vung Tau,' he said.\n\nAt HCMC Children's Hospital 2, an estimated 110-130 HFMD cases are\nbeing reported a day, with 50-60 percent of patients coming from other\nprovinces.\n\n'The workload for doctors in big cities is so big that they can make\nmistakes, which are sometimes paid for with the patients' lives,' said\na doctor who spoke on condition of anonymity. According to doctors,\nHFMD patients rush to big cities because provincial hospitals do not\nhave enough medical staff and equipment to treat serious cases.\nProvincial hospitals also don't cover drug fees for HFMD patients\nunder age 6, while HCMC does. According to Khanh, 10 percent of HFMD\nchild patients at the Children's Hospital 1 must be treated with\ngammaglobulin.\n\nDr. Nguyen Dac Tho, deputy director of the HCMC Center for Preventive\nMedicine, warned that the rising number of HFMD patients from other\nprovinces rushing to city-based hospitals could help spread the\ndisease. Dr. Tran Phu Manh Sieu, the center's director, said the risk\nof the disease spreading to new communities was very high. 'HFMD child\npatients may spread the virus to other patients, and adults and\nchildren who share the hospitals' canteens and toilets may contract\nthe virus. Families of child patients from other provinces who rush to\nHCMC may spread the viruses to their relatives too.'\n\n[Byline: Lien Chau-Thanh Tung]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap alerts\n<promed@promedmil.org>\n\n[Since the previous report dated Mon 17 Oct 2011 there have been 6425\nnew cases and 7 more deaths. Nguyen\nVan Binh, head of the Ministry of Health's Department of Preventive\nMedicine, was quoted by the Thanh Nien newspaper as saying most of the\ncases have been reported in the country's south.\n\nEnterovirus 71, or EV-71, is the dominant strain [virus] circulating\nin Viet Nam. It can result in a more serious form of the common\nchildhood disease leading to paralysis, brain swelling [encephalitis]\nor death.\n\nThis year's outbreak is a sharp [increase] from recent years. Since\n2008, about 10 000 to 15 000 cases were reported per year with about\n20 to 30 children dying annually.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children. The disease causes fever and blister-like\neruptions in the mouth and/or a skin rash. The disease usually begins\nwith a fever, poor appetite, malaise, and often with a sore throat.\nOne or 2 days after fever onset, painful sores usually develop in the\nmouth. They begin as small red spots that blister and then often\nbecome ulcers. The sores are usually located on the tongue, gums, and\ninside of the cheeks. A non-itchy skin rash develops over 1 to 2 days.\nThe rash has flat or raised red spots, sometimes with blisters. The\nrash is usually located on the palms of the hands and soles of the\nfeet; it may also appear on the buttocks and/or genitalia. A person\nwith HFMD may have only the rash or only the mouth sores.\n\nHFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_ which\nincludes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and\nenteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most common cause of\nHFMD in the North America, and other coxsackieviruses have been\nassociated with the illness elsewhere. In recent years Human\nenterovirus 71 have been associated with outbreaks of HFMD in\nSouth-East Asia responsible for more serious disease accompanied by\nencephalitis in some children. The above report reveals that this more\nserous form of HFMD, and associated encephalitis, is increasing in\nprevalence in Viet Nam.\n\nVery recently Tran CB, Nguyen HT, Phan HT, Tran NV, Wills B, Farrar J,\nSantangelo JD, Simmons CP. have published a study of 'The\nseroprevalence and seroincidence of enterovirus 71 infection in\ninfants and children in Ho Chi Minh city, Viet Nam' (PLoS One.\n2011;6(7):e21116. Epub 2011 Jul 12.\nhttp://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0021116).\nThey reported that: 'Enterovirus 71 (EV71)-associated hand, foot and\nmouth disease has emerged as a serious public health problem in South\nEast Asia over the last decade. To better understand the prevalence of\nEV71 infection, we determined EV71 seroprevalence and seroincidence\namongst healthy infants and children in Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam. In\na cohort of 200 newborns, 55 percent of cord blood samples contained\nEV71 neutralizing antibodies and these decayed to undetectable levels\nby 6 months of age in 98 percent of infants. The EV71 neutralizing\nantibody seroconversion rate was 5.6 percent in the 1st year and 14\npercent in the 2nd year of life. In children 5-15 yrs of age,\nseroprevalence of EV71 neutralizing antibodies was 84 percent and in\ncord blood it was 55 percent. Taken together, these data suggest EV71\nforce of infection is high and highlights the need for more research\ninto its epidemiologyand pathogenesis in high disease burden\ncountries.'\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Viet Nam is available\nat:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/008c. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (06)\n********************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n \n\nVery recently Tran CB, Nguyen HT, Phan HT, Tran NV, Wills B, Farrar J,\nSantangelo JD, Simmons CP. have published a study of 'The\nseroprevalence and seroincidence of enterovirus 71 infection in\ninfants and children in Ho Chi Minh city, Viet Nam' (PLoS One. \nA health official says a surging outbreak of hand, foot and mouth\ndisease (HFMD) in Viet Nam has killed 70 people so far this year\n In recent years Human\nenterovirus 71 have been associated with outbreaks of HFMD in\nSouth-East Asia responsible for more serious disease accompanied by\nencephalitis in some children. In temperate\nclimates, cases occur more often in summer and early autumn. HFMD\ncaused by coxsackievirus A16 infection is generally a mild disease,\nwith nearly all patients recovering in 7 to 10 days without medical\ntreatment.\n\nSince 1997, however, outbreaks of HFMD caused by enterovirus 71 have\nbeen reported in Asia and Australia. HFMD caused by enterovirus 71 has\nshown a higher incidence of neurologic involvement, and fatal cases of\nencephalitis have occurred during outbreaks. However, such serious\noutcomes are still very rare.\n\nHFMD infection is spread from person to person by direct contact.\nInfectious virus is found in the nose and throat secretions, saliva,\nblister fluid and stool of infected persons. The virus is most often\nspread by persons with unwashed, virus-contaminated hands and by\ncontact with virus-contaminated surfaces. Infected persons are most\ncontagious during the 1st week of the illness, but may remain a source\nof infection for others after symptoms have resolved. Samples from 174 HFMD cases\nwere obtained from Children's Hospitals No. 1 and No. 2 in Ho Chi Minh\nCity (HCMC) and from several southern provinces, including Dong Thap,\nDong Nai, Binh Duong and Tien Giang provinces and were tested in the\nLaboratory of Enteric Viruses of the Pasteur Institute in HCMC. Data\nfrom RT-PCR assays showed the presence of human enterovirus 71 (HEV\n71) in 43/174 (25 percent) of cases and other enteroviruses in 91/174\n(52 percent) of cases. HEV 71 was identified in 5 fatal cases of HFMD\nfrom specimens that included CSF and throat swabs.\n\nIn 9 cases, HEV 71 was isolated in cell culture, and the sub-genotype\nwas identified by nucleotide sequencing. These data showed that 8\npatients (including 2 fatal cases from Ho Chi Minh City) were infected\nwith HEV 71 sub-genotype C4, and a single HFMD case from Dong Thap\nprovince was infected with HEV71 sub-genotype C5. According to\nsurveillance data obtained from the Pasteur Institute in Ho Chi Minh\nCity, HEV 71 C4 and C5 strains have been prevalent in southern Viet\nNam since 2003.\n\n(This report has been approved by Dr Tran Ngoc Huu, MPHM, Ph.D,\nDirector, Pasteur Institute, Ho Chi Minh City, Viet Nam.)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr Nguyen Thi Thanh Thao,\nEnteroviruses Lab.,\nImmunology and Microbiology Dept.,\nHo Chi Minh Institute,\n167 Pasteur str., 3 Dist.,\nHo Chi Minh City,\nViet Nam\n<tthao1103@yahoo.com>\n\n[ProMED-mail welcomes receipt of this authoritative report.\n\nIt is clear that, as elsewhere, the epidemiology of HFMD in Viet Nam\nis complex and that human enterovirus 71 plays a major role in the\ncausation of this disease. As commented previously, a great diversity\nof human enterovirus 71 strains circulate globally, and no particular\ngenogroup has been specifically associated with severe disease.\nDifferent human enteroviruses co-circulate in the community annually.\n\nAccording to a recent review (Lee, T.C. et al., Pediatr Infect Dis J.\n2009 Oct;28(10):904-10), the emergence in recent years of the human\nenterovirus 71 epidemic in the Asia Pacific region has been associated\nwith the circulation of 5 genetic lineages (genotypes B3, B4, C1, C2,\nC4) that appear to be undergoing rapid evolutionary changes. Dr Truong Huu Khanh, head\nof the infectious and neurological diseases ward at the Paediatric\nHospital No.1, said the number of children being hospitalised every\nday has almost doubled the average 20 in the recent past. On Thursday\n[7 Apr 2011] alone, 35 were admitted, he said, 5 in serious condition\nand requiring a respirator. Dr\nNguyen Dac Tho, deputy head of the city Preventive Medicine Centre,\nsaid from an average of 30 per day in the last 2 weeks, the number has\nincreased to 80. 'It's easily spread in\nyounger children, preschool children, school-aged children, and in day\ncares. We're seeing an increase in the area currently,' Ranata\nHatcher, a pediatric nurse practitioner, said.\n\nThe Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said the illness\nusually starts after a fever, then rashes can appear on arms and legs,\neven ulcers can appear in your child's mouth, causing him or her pain\nwhen eating or drinking foods. Hatcher said, 'It's spread through\nsaliva, eating, and drinking after each other. That's why it's so\nprevalent in preschools and day cares.'\n\nAnd preventing it is as easy as cleaning toys with bleach and washing\nyour hands. 'We recommend you rub your hands together, cleaning under\nyour fingernails, between your fingers, backs of the hands. If you\nteach them the ABC's while they're washing their hands, that's about\nthe time frame you need to efficiently kill all the germs,' Hatcher\nsaid.\n\nParents shouldn't be afraid; the disease has nothing to do with\nanimals. 'HFMD is specific to humans. Foot-and-mouth disease is\nsomething that you see in animals, you cannot catch hand-foot-mouth\ndisease from an animal,' Hatcher said.\n\nHatcher said not being clean is the no. 1 cause for the spread of\nhand- foot-mouth disease. If your child is showing signs of\ndehydration, a symptom of the illness, you might want to call your\ndoctor.\n\n[Byline: Tony Russell]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nHealthMap Alerts via ProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus _Enterovirus_.\nThis genus of viruses includes the polioviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nechoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most\ncommon cause of HFMD in the United States in recent years, but other\ncoxsackieviruses have been associated with the illness. Other\nenteroviruses, such as enterovirus 71, have also been associated with\noutbreaks of HFMD, principally in Asia.\n\nIndividual cases and outbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide. In temperate\nclimates cases occur more often in summer and early autumn. HFMD\ncaused by coxsackievirus A16 infection is generally a mild disease,\nwith nearly all patients recovering in 7 to 10 days without medical\ntreatment. Since 1997, however, outbreaks of HFMD caused by\nenterovirus 71 have been reported in Asia and Australia. HFMD caused\nby enterovirus 71 has shown a higher incidence of neurologic\ninvolvement and fatal cases of encephalitis have occurred during\noutbreaks. However, such serious outcomes are still very rare.\n\nHFMD infection is spread from person to person by direct contact.\nInfectious virus is found in the nose and throat secretions, saliva,\nblister fluid and stool of infected persons. The virus is most often\nspread by persons with unwashed, virus-contaminated hands and by\ncontact with virus-contaminated surfaces. Infected persons are most\ncontagious during the 1st week of the illness, but may remain a source\nof infection for others after symptoms have resolved.\n\nComplications from virus infections that cause HFMD are uncommon;\n'aseptic' meningitis can occur rarely with HFMD causing fever,\nheadache, stiff neck, or back pain. Some patients may require\nhospitalization for a short time. Other more serious conditions, such\nas encephalitis, are very rare although encephalitis can be fatal.\nThere have been reports of fingernail and toenail loss occurring\nmostly in children within 4 weeks of having HFMD (see: ProMED-mail\npostings Onychomadesis, coxsackievirus - USA: (MI), RFI 20080729.2317;\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus 20080709.2099; and\nOnychomadesis - Spain: (Valencia), coxsackievirus (02) 20080711.2120).\nAt this time, it is not known whether the reported nail loss is or is\nnot a result of the infection. Already 11 children have died. A total of 70\npercent of the patients are under 3 years old.\n\nThe reason for the increase was the appearance of a new enterovirus\n71 type B2, said Vice director of the department Le Truong Giang.\nHygiene levels in homes and schools were also an issue, he said.\n\nDoctors at Paediatrics Hospital No 1 said that in the last week of\nMay, more than 100 children per day were being hospitalised with the\ndisease. In Paediatrics Hospital No 2, 5450 children were tested for\nthe disease last month [May 2011], and 795 of them were hospitalised,\ndouble the number in April [2011].\n\nThe municipal People's Committee on Tuesday [31 May 2011] sent an\nurgent letter to health, education and training, information and\ncommunication departments, and district people's committees, urging\nthem to take preventive measures. Doctors warned that residents should\nwash children's hands regularly and clean children's toys and homes\nwith antiseptic solution once a week. If children show symptoms of a\nhigh temperature, difficulty breathing and rashes on their feet, hands\nand mouth, they should be taken to hospital immediately.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS\n<promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[The newswires report increased numbers of HFMD and deaths related to\nHFMD in Ho Chi Minh City and the central province of Quang Ngai.\nEnterovirus 71 type B2 was blamed for the increased number of cases\nand deaths related to HFMD (see prior PRO/MBDS posting Hand, foot &\nmouth disease - Viet Nam (03): Ho Chi Minh City 20110602.1690).
