HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - VIET NAM (02): (QUANG NGAI, HO CHI MINH\nCITY)\n", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "5450-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-05-29 00:00:00", "2021-05-25 00:00:00", "2021-04-25 00:00:00", "2011-05-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00", "2010-03-25 00:00:00", "2011-05-31 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2011-05-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Quang Ngai", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ho Chi Minh City", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Quang", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "731679", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - Croatia: (ZG) childcare centre", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=731679", "date": "2011-05-27 16:43:45", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CROATIA: (ZAGREB) CHILDCARE CENTRE\n******************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 27 May 2011\nSource: Eurosurveillance edition 2011; 16(21) [summ., edited]\nhttp://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19875\n\n\nOutbreak of hand-foot-mouth disease caused by coxsackie A16 virus in\na childcare centre in Croatia, February to March 2011\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\n[Authors: Ljubin-Sternak S, Slavic-Vrzic V, Vilibic-aavlek T, et al]\n\nSummary\n-------\nWe describe an outbreak of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) in a\nchildcare centre in a district of Zagreb county, north west Croatia. A\ntotal of 11 cases of HFMD occurred in the childcare centre and another\n9 were reported from nearby areas in the district. Coxsackie A16 virus\n[CA16] was diagnosed in 13 clinical specimens obtained from 11\nsymptomatic and asymptomatic children. All cases resolved without\ncomplications.\n\nOutbreak description\n--------------------\nOn 2 Mar 2011, the Department of Epidemiology of Zagreb County\nInstitute of Public Health was contacted by a health professional from\na childcare centre in Bregana, Samobor district, reporting 4 children\nwith vesicular stomatitis and rash (hand-foot-mouth disease, HFMD) in\nthe weeks before. The centre cares for 160 children at 2 locations and\ncomprises 8 classes (7 classes in the main building complex and one\nclass in a house nearby). 3 cases were from one class at the 1st\nlocation and a 4th case was from the nearby house.\n\nOn the same day that the cases were reported, the epidemiologist\nfound another 2 children with the same symptoms in the same class of\nthe main building complex. The epidemiologist immediately reported the\ncases to the Reference Epidemiology Centre at the Croatian National\nInstitute of Public Health. The day after, mouth swabs and stools were\ncollected for viral culture from all children in the 2 affected\nclasses. After active case finding (parent questionnaire,\npaediatrician reports), another 5 cases were found in other classes of\nthe same childcare centre (11 cases in total). In this investigation,\nonly symptomatic individuals were considered as cases, irrespective of\nlaboratory-confirmation. All cases presented with a mild clinical\npicture of disease, with no complications, and only 4 of the 11\nchildren attending the childcare centre stayed at home until they\nrecovered. The affected classes were neither closed, nor were infected\nchildren separated. The management of the childcare centre was rather\ninstructed to carry out an extensive cleaning and disinfection of all\nsurfaces, toys, furnishings, toilets, and other objects, while parents\nwere given written materials on disease transmission and how to avoid\nit. No further cases occurred in the childcare centre after 14 Mar\n2011.\n\nThe epidemiologist also identified 9 cases, outside the childcare\ncentre, retrospectively by active case finding. These cases were also\npreschool children, aged 1 to 4 years, living in the Samobor district,\nwhich comprises about 43 000 inhabitants. The 9 cases were all\ndiagnosed by 4 primary care paediatricians taking care of most of the\nchildren in the area. After the outbreak in the childcare centre was\nrecognised, the epidemiologist in charge of the investigation checked\nwith them all the records and asked to report further cases. None of\nthe cases outside the childcare centre were laboratory-investigated.\n\nHFMD is a syndrome characterised by vesicular stomatitis and\ncutaneous lesions of the distal extremities and it is usually caused\nby CA16 or enterovirus 71 (E71). These viruses are genetically closely\nrelated and are both serotypes of the human enterovirus A (HEV-A)\nspecies, _Picornaviridae_ family. HFMD has a worldwide occurrence.\nOutbreaks occur frequently among groups of children in childcare\ncentres and schools. Transmission is by faecal-oral route and by\nexposure to throat discharges or fluid from blisters. In the absence\nof cutaneous lesions, oral lesions of HFMD may be mistaken for\naphthous ulcers or herpes simplex gingivostomatitis. Although\ndescribed, neurologic complications of HFMD caused by CA16 are rare\nwhen compared to the disease caused by E71. Diagnosis of HFMD is\nusually based on the clinical picture alone. Laboratory diagnosis is\nusually performed by virus isolation of cell culture from throat swabs\nand stool specimens.\n\nEnterovirus infections are notifiable diseases in Croatia. Usually,\nthere are few reports of sporadic cases of HFMD each year, diagnosed\nbased on the clinical picture alone. There are also several different\nserotypes of enteroviruses isolated in Croatia each year but\nlaboratory confirmed cases caused by CA16 virus have not been\nregistered until now.\n\nDiscussion\n----------\nCA16 and E71 are prevalent in many parts of the world, especially in\nsouth-east Asia, but also in European countries. In Croatia CA16\ninfections have not been documented until now, although these occur in\nneighbouring countries. The traditional technique for detecting and\ncharacterising enteroviruses, also used in this laboratory, relies on\nviral isolation in cell culture followed by neutralisation using\nreference antisera. However, no single cell line exists that is\ncapable of growing all human enteroviruses. In 2004, RD(A) cells were\nintroduced into the routine laboratory diagnostic algorithm for\nenterovirus culture together with previously used GMK and L20B cells.\nThis has resulted in the detection of HEV-A viruses including CA16 and\nE71, which grow poorly, if at all, in the other 2 cell lines used in\nour laboratory. Immediate collection of clinical specimens by the\nepidemiologist during the investigation of this outbreak also\ncontributed to the successful isolation of CA16.\n\nCA16 and E71 are associated with sporadic cases and outbreaks of\nHFMD, and rare cases of acute neurological diseases. The HFMD outbreak\nreported here confirmed the previously observed characteristics of\nCA16 infection. An outbreak occurred in a childcare centre in children\naged 1.5 to 5.5 years, who seem to be the most susceptible age group\nfor CA16 infection. A seroprevalence study in Germany showed that 2/3\nof children aged 1 to 4 years do not posses neutralising antibodies to\nCA16. HFMD is a highly contagious disease, but the manifestation rate\nof infection is low. A large number of exposed children in this\noutbreak were infected as by laboratory confirmation (11/35). Most of\nthe infected children were asymptomatic (8/11). The illness is usually\nmild without complications, as confirmed during this outbreak. The\nnumber of positive stool specimens versus throat swabs in symptomatic\nas well as asymptomatic children in this report confirmed that stool\nis the most appropriate clinical specimen for enteroviruses in which\nthey survive for a long period.\n\nIn conclusion, a prompt reaction of the Epidemiology Service and the\nthorough investigation that followed, allowed the successful\nimplementation of control measures, which prevented further spreading\nof the HFMD outbreak in the childcare centre. CA16 appeared to have\nbeen circulating in the Samobor area from February [2011], but as\nsymptoms are mild or absent in most cases, many parents may not have\nsought medical help for their children.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Readers are recommended to read the full text via the source URL\nabove to view the data and literature references.\n\nCoxsackie viruses are separable into 2 groups, A and B, based on\ntheir effects on newborn mice (coxsackie A results in muscle injury,\nparalysis, and death; coxsackie B results in organ damage but less\nsevere outcomes). Type A viruses cause herpangina (painful blisters in\nthe mouth, throat, hands, feet, or in all these areas).\nHand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is the common name of this viral\ninfection. Coxsackie A 16 causes the majority of HFMD infections in\nEurope and the Americas. It usually occurs in children (age 10 and\nunder), but adults can also develop the condition. Type A also causes\nconjunctivitis (inflammation of the eyelids and white area of the\neye). Type B viruses cause epidemic pleurodynia (fever, lung, and\nabdominal pain with headache that lasts about 2 to 12 days and\nresolves). Pleurodynia is also termed Bornholm disease.\n\nBoth types of viruses (A and B) can cause meningitis, myocarditis,\nand pericarditis, but these occur infrequently from coxsackie\ninfections. Infection usually is spread by fecal-oral contamination,\nalthough occasionally the virus is spread by droplets expelled by\ninfected individuals. Items like utensils, diaper-changing tables, and\ntoys that come in contact with body fluids that contain the virus may\nalso transmit them to other individuals. Although people of any age\ncan get infected, the majority of patients identified with coxsackie\ninfection are children (see MedicineNet.com\nhttp://www.medicinenet.com/coxsackie_virus/article.htm).\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Croatia can be accessed\nat http://healthmap.org/r/0TZG. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CROATIA: (ZAGREB) CHILDCARE CENTRE\n******************************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\n On 2 Mar 2011, the Department of Epidemiology of Zagreb County\nInstitute of Public Health was contacted by a health professional from\na childcare centre in Bregana, Samobor district, reporting 4 children\nwith vesicular stomatitis and rash (hand-foot-mouth disease, HFMD) in\nthe weeks before. The\nnumber of positive stool specimens versus throat swabs in symptomatic\nas well as asymptomatic children in this report confirmed that stool\nis the most appropriate clinical specimen for enteroviruses in which\nthey survive for a long period. The management of the childcare centre was rather\ninstructed to carry out an extensive cleaning and disinfection of all\nsurfaces, toys, furnishings, toilets, and other objects, while parents\nwere given written materials on disease transmission and how to avoid\nit. All cases presented with a mild clinical\npicture of disease, with no complications, and only 4 of the 11\nchildren attending the childcare centre stayed at home until they\nrecovered. \n\nCoxsackie viruses are separable into 2 groups, A and B, based on\ntheir effects on newborn mice (coxsackie A results in muscle injury,\nparalysis, and death; coxsackie B results in organ damage but less\nsevere outcomes). CA16 appeared to have\nbeen circulating in the Samobor area from February [2011], but as\nsymptoms are mild or absent in most cases, many parents may not have\nsought medical help for their children. In conclusion, a prompt reaction of the Epidemiology Service and the\nthorough investigation that followed, allowed the successful\nimplementation of control measures, which prevented further spreading\nof the HFMD outbreak in the childcare centre. There are also several different\nserotypes of enteroviruses isolated in Croatia each year but\nlaboratory confirmed cases caused by CA16 virus have not been\nregistered until now. Although people of any age\ncan get infected, the majority of patients identified with coxsackie\ninfection are children (see MedicineNet.com\nhttp://www.medicinenet.com/coxsackie_virus/article.htm). The traditional technique for detecting and\ncharacterising enteroviruses, also used in this laboratory, relies on\nviral isolation in cell culture followed by neutralisation using\nreference antisera. After active case finding (parent questionnaire,\npaediatrician reports), another 5 cases were found in other classes of\nthe same childcare centre (11 cases in total). \n\n\nOutbreak of hand-foot-mouth disease caused by coxsackie A16 virus in\na childcare centre in Croatia, February to March 2011\n An outbreak occurred in a childcare centre in children\naged 1.5 to 5.5 years, who seem to be the most susceptible age group\nfor CA16 infection. A\ntotal of 11 cases of HFMD occurred in the childcare centre and another\n9 were reported from nearby areas in the district. After the outbreak in the childcare centre was\nrecognised, the epidemiologist in charge of the investigation checked\nwith them all the records and asked to report further cases. The centre cares for 160 children at 2 locations and\ncomprises 8 classes (7 classes in the main building complex and one\nclass in a house nearby). On the same day that the cases were reported, the epidemiologist\nfound another 2 children with the same symptoms in the same class of\nthe main building complex. These cases were also\npreschool children, aged 1 to 4 years, living in the Samobor district,\nwhich comprises about 43 000 inhabitants. The 9 cases were all\ndiagnosed by 4 primary care paediatricians taking care of most of the\nchildren in the area. The day after, mouth swabs and stools were\ncollected for viral culture from all children in the 2 affected\nclasses. Usually,\nthere are few reports of sporadic cases of HFMD each year, diagnosed\nbased on the clinical picture alone. The epidemiologist immediately reported the\ncases to the Reference Epidemiology Centre at the Croatian National\nInstitute of Public Health. Laboratory diagnosis is\nusually performed by virus isolation of cell culture from throat swabs\nand stool specimens. \n\nHFMD is a syndrome characterised by vesicular stomatitis and\ncutaneous lesions of the distal extremities and it is usually caused\nby CA16 or enterovirus 71 (E71). \n\nBoth types of viruses (A and B) can cause meningitis, myocarditis,\nand pericarditis, but these occur infrequently from coxsackie\ninfections. In Shanghai there has been a\n40 percent increase in cases compared to 2009 with 13 371 cases, 67\nsevere cases and 2 deaths reported cumulatively in 2010. The majority\nof cases in China are being reported from rural communities.\n\nConsequently, currently available data indicate that there is an\nincreased activity of HFMD in the region, with a higher incidence and\nan earlier start of the epidemic season. Also, surveillance data from\nJapan suggests that there is an increased proportion of HFMD cases\ncaused by enterovirus 71 (EV71) infection compared to previous years.\n\nThe reasons for the current unusual epidemiological picture of HFMD\n(and specifically EV71 in Japan) are not well understood. The methods\nused in Asian countries for surveillance of HFMD, as well as the\nprotocols for laboratory confirmation and testing do vary between\ncountries. Furthermore it is not known to what extent different\ncountries have recently adapted and/or strengthened their surveillance\nfor HFMD which could mean that the current observed increase is simply\ndue to a surveillance artefact. In order to fully understand the\ncurrent epidemiological picture of HFMD in the Asian region it would\nbe important to know the proportion of HFMD cases that are positive\nfor EV71 as well as the type of EV71 virus that is the dominant\ncirculating strain.\n\nEV71 infections in Europe have been successively caused by viruses of\nsub-genogroups B0, B1 and B2. A genogroup shift occurred in 1987,\nafter which viruses of subgenogroups C1 and C2 were detected\nexclusively. This is distinct from the situation in the Asian Pacific\nregion, where EV71 subgenogroups B3-B5 and C4-C5 have caused large\noutbreaks since 1997 (see van der Sanden et al, J Gen Virol 2010 Aug;\n91(Pt 8): 1949-58\n<http://vir.sgmjournals.org/cgi/content/abstract/91/8/1949>).\n\nThere are existing gaps in the knowledge about HFMD that [if they\ncould be filled] would contribute to a better understanding of the\nsituation, including:\n\n1. Seasonality: even though most Asian countries have annual epidemics\nof HFMD, it is not well understood what factors are triggering the\nepidemics to start earlier (as confirmed by Japan in the present year).\n\n2. Cyclical nature of the disease: some countries have suggested a\ncyclical nature of the outbreaks every 2-3 years. The last large\noutbreaks of HFMD in SE Asia occurred in 2008, and therefore the\noutbreaks this year (2010) could confirm such a cyclical pattern.\n\nFor a map of the provinces of Viet Nam see\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f0/VietnameseProvincesMap.png>. The ministry vowed to further enhance medical\nresponses, particularly in vast countryside areas, to curb the raging epidemic.\n\nAs of Tue 22 Jun 2010 the common viral epidemic among children has\nsickened nearly 987 779 on the Chinese mainland. Of that total, 537\ndied. The majority of those who have gotten ill are younger than 3\nyears of age, said Wang Zijun, deputy director of the emergency\nresponse office under the Chinese Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention (CDC), at a press conference.\n\nThe epidemic control situation is grave in the country as the number\nof deaths caused by the disease stood at only 186 in the same period\nlast year, Wang said. 'Rural doctors, who are less experienced than\ntheir urban counterparts in treating the infection, are finding it\ndifficult to make timely diagnoses of the infection, with no lab\nscreening capacity at grassroots-level facilities,' said Lu Lianhe,\nveteran infectious disease doctor of the Beijing Ditan Hospital. A\nlate diagnosis might delay effective treatment for the disease,\nwhich, in rare cases, can cause deadly complications like\nencephalitis, he said.\n\nUsually, the infected person recovers without medication in 7 to 10\ndays, experts said. Relatively poor awareness of public hygiene and\nmedical care among the rural population is also to blame for the\nhigher fatality rate there, Wang said, urging parents there to\npractice better hygiene.\n\nAmong the fatal cases, about 92 percent were caused by enterovirus 71\n(EV71), which, like other strains [species of enteroviruses] such as\nthe polioviruses, coxsackieviruses and echoviruses, can cause the\n[same symptoms], Wang said. To address that issue, the CDC planned to\nintroduce a quick test kit for EV71 among rural doctors to help\nfacilitate early detection, according to Wang. 'Early detection and\ntreatment are the key to averting death,' he said. Also, the Ministry\nhas been busy training all rural doctors in the nation for better\nHFMD response, said Yang Jinrui, deputy director of the Ministry's\ninformation office.\n\nThe task will be completed by the end of June [2010], according to\nYang. Previously, treatment guidelines for HFMD had been distributed\nto all medical facilities across the country. In truth, apart from an\nunbalanced outbreak response between rural and urban areas in China,\nthe long-existing gap in health conditions of minors is also\nwidening, experts warned. The prevalence of stunted growth among\nrural children younger than 5 is 17.3 percent, nearly 4 times that of\nurban children, official statistics show. 'And the gap shows no signs\nof shrinking,' said Song Wenxiu, divisional director of the National\nWorking Committee on Children and Women under the State Council.\nAlso, they are more susceptible to incidents such as the fake milk\npowder, she said.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD) is a common viral illness of infants and children. The disease\ncauses fever and blister-like eruptions in the mouth and/or a skin\nrash. In recent years, coxsackievirus A16, enterovirus 71, and the\ncoxsackievirus B viruses have been implicated most often. Less-common\ncauses include echovirus, parechovirus 1, adenovirus, and herpes\nsimplex virus (HSV).\n\nInfection is spread from person to person by direct contact with\ninfectious virus. The\nvirus is most often spread by persons with unwashed, virus-\ncontaminated hands and by contact with virus-contaminated surfaces.\nInfected persons are most contagious during the 1st week of the\nillness. We have noted that areas of hoof\nbecome separated in animals with FMDV infection, and that viral RNA\nis detectable up to 5 weeks post infection by QRTPCR (quantitative\nreal time polymerase chain reaction) assay. Virus isolation and\nstandard gel-based PCR (polymerase chain reaction) assay were all\nnegative from 7 days onward... Using a RT-qPCR (reverse\ntranscription-quantitative polymerase chain reaction), which has a\nmuch shorter target amplicon (about 100 nucleotides), to detect\nenterovirus sequences in nail specimens would be most likely to yield\na positive result if FMDV is anything to go by?\n\n--\nRyan Waters\nInstitute of Animal Health\nPirbright, Surrey\nUK\n<ryan.waters@bbsrc.ac.uk>\n\n[This is an interesting observation that should be followed up by the\nFinnish and Spanish groups who have raised the issue of a possible\nconnection between onychomadesis (loss of nails) and prior\nhand-foot-mouth disease in children. Foot-and-mouth disease virus\naffecting cattle and a variety of other animals, but not humans, and\nthe various enteroviruses associated with hand-foot-mouth disease in\nchildren, are all epitheliotropic enteroviruses. However,\ntaxonomically the viruses are unrelated. Foot-and-mouth disease virus\nis classified in the genus _Aphthovirus_, whereas all the\nnon-poliomyelitis enteroviruses associated with hand-foot-mouth\ndisease in children are classified in the genus _Enterovirus_.\n\nThe lapse of time between the signs and symptoms of hand-foot-mouth\ndisease and the subsequent occurrence of nail loss or damage has\nfrustrated attempts to confirm a specific linkage. It may be that the\napplication of more sensitive PCR technology, as demonstrated in the\ncase of foot-and-mouth disease in cattle, may confirm a linkage if\nsuch exists. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Virus isolation and\nstandard gel-based PCR (polymerase chain reaction) assay were all\nnegative from 7 days onward... The following is the reference and abstract of this paper.\n\nOnychomadesis after a hand, foot, and mouth disease outbreak in Spain, 2009\nBy: M Cabrerizo 1, T De Miguel 1, A Armada 2, R Martia Nez-Risco 2, A\nPousa 3, and G Trllero 1\n1. Virology Department, National Centre for Microbiology, Instituto\nde Salud Carlos III, Madrid, Spain\n2. Servicio de Alertas Epidemiologicas del Departamento Territorial\nde Sanidad, La Coruna, Spain\n3. Servicio de Epidemiologia de la Direccion General de Salud Publica\ny Planificacion, Santiago de Compostela, Spain\n\nReference\n---------\nEpidemiol. Infect. Cambridge University Press 2010\ndoi:10.1017/S0950268810002219\n(<http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=7907228>).\n\nSummary\n-------\nFew reports exist regarding the association between onychomadesis and\nan enterovirus infection presenting clinically as hand-foot-mouth\ndisease (HFMD). In February 2009, an outbreak of HFMD occurred in a\nSpanish nursery school, followed by onychomadesis 36 to 69 days\nlater. 12 of 17 children with HFMD developed nail shedding;\nenterovirus was detected in stool samples from eight (47 percent) of\nthe 17. However, in only 3 of the children could an enterovirus\nserotype coxsackievirus B1 be identified. The epidemiological results\nof this study confirm onychomadesis as a complication in HFMD. In\nfuture outbreaks, molecular characterization of enterovirus from\nappropriate clinical samples should be studied.\n\n--\nProfessor Norman Noah\nSenior Editor\nEpidemiology and Infection\nProfessor of Public Health\nDept of Epidemiology and Population Health\nLondon School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine\nKeppel Street\nLondon WC1E 7HT\nUK\n<Norman.Noah@lshtm.ac.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Professor Noah for drawing attention to this\nnewly published research which further documents an association\nbetween onychomadesis and prior enterovirus (in this case\ncoxsackievirus B1) infection. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Senior Editor\nEpidemiology and Infection\nProfessor of Public Health\nDept of Epidemiology and Population Health\nLondon School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine\nKeppel Street\n London WC1E 7HT\nUK\n<Norman.Noah@lshtm.ac.uk>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Professor Noah for drawing attention to this\nnewly published research which further documents an association\nbetween onychomadesis and prior enterovirus (in this case\ncoxsackievirus B1) infection. - Mod. An infant was the 1st fatality in\nBeijing this year, reported Beijing Youth Daily.\n\nThe Beijing Municipal Bureau of Health said 582 HFMD cases were\nreported last week [week of 5 Apr 2010], a 36.62 percent increase\nfrom the week before last [week of 29 Mar 2010]. And the Ministry of\nHealth added on Tuesday [13 Apr 2010] that 94 people had died\nnationwide of the disease, as of 11 Apr 2010.\n\nBut the bureau also pointed out that looking at the overall picture\nwas important. There were 2250 reported cases this year [2010] in\nBeijing by Wednesday [13 Apr 2010], a drop of 15.54 percent from the\nsame period last year [2009].\n\n'When we say there is no need to panic, it does not mean we should\nnot be cautious. HFMD is now approaching its peak infection rate,\nwhich we predict will be between May and July,' said Ma Yanming,\ndeputy director of the bureau. The health bureau launched a '2010\nBeijing HFMD monitoring program' on Tuesday [13 Apr 2010] to tighten\nprevention against the disease. Primary schools and kindergartens in\nBeijing are being asked to be on the alert. The monitoring program\nstates that if a serious case or one that results in death appears in\nany class, or 2 cases occur within one week in a single class, the\nschool should suspend classes for at least 10 days. 'Morning\ncheck-ups', which refer to a temperature test on children as they\nenter school, have also been implemented by most kindergartens and\nprimary schools, Ma said.\n\nSterilization of toys, classrooms, and tableware are being emphasized\nin kindergartens. 'We understand parents' concerns, but there is no\nneed to worry,' said Wang Yanli, school physician at Xiaoguanbeili\nprimary school in Chaoyang district. 'Since cases of death are\nusually caused by serious complications, such as encephalitis\n(swelling of the brain), a good physical constitution and sound\nimmune system will serve as the best form of protection for children.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Overall the 2010 outbreak of HFMD may be no worse than in the\nprevious year. The onset of the rainy season also coincides with the start\nof the 1st school semester, which also makes it easy for the virus to\nspread, she said.\n\nMs Nittaya urged parents to keep an eye on all children, especially\nthose under 3 years old and infants. Indications of the disease\ninclude fever, loss of appetite, lethargy, coughing, a sore throat,\nvomiting and diarrhea. The disease is most often identified by mouth\nulcers and rashes on the hands and feet.\n\nParents whose children exhibit any of these conditions are urged to\nseek medical treatment as soon as possible and not to allow their\nchildren to go to school, said the release. Teachers were also urged\nto be vigilant against an outbreak. School administrators should\nsuspend any classes with 2 or more children found to have HFMD, and\nany schools with 5 or more children diagnosed with the disease should\nbe closed temporarily.\n\n[Byline: Sitthipong Nongkaew]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This newspaper article reproduces a poster used to raise awareness\nof hand, foot and mouth disease in a rather oblique manner.\n\nOwing to the ubiquity and regularity of outbreaks of HFMD in\nSoutheast Asia at this time of year, ProMED-mail does not routinely\nreport individual outbreaks of HFMD. Currently, HFMD is widespread\nthroughout most provinces of China. The onset of milder weather\nfacilitates transmission of the infection, and strict attention to\npersonal hygiene is the only protection against infection.\n\nHFMD is a common illness of infants and children caused by viruses\nthat belong to the genus _Enterovirus_. This genus of viruses\nincludes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and\nenteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most common cause of\nHFMD, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated with this\nillness. In recent outbreaks in Asia and Australasia, enterovirus 71\nhas more often been associated with HFMD and linked with rare\nneurological complications of infection. In the outbreak of HFMD in\nViet Nam (Ho Chi Minh City) in March 2010 (see the 1st of the\nProMED-mail archived references below), several children suffered\nserious neurological complications, so it is probable that\nenterovirus 71 is the etiologic agent circulating in Thailand at\npresent.\n\nPhuket is an island in the south of Thailand, and Phuket city is the\nmain population centre in the southeast of the island. According to local TV Channel News\nAsia, 496 cases were recorded in the week ending [20 Mar 2010], just 4\nshort of the warning [alert] level of 500. The Singapore government\nsaid that currently no child care centre has been closed due to HFMD.\nHFMD usually infects children and infants. Symptoms include fever,\nulcers in the throat and rashes on the hands and feet. HFMD is spread\nfrom person to person by direct contact through nasal discharge,\nsaliva, feces and fluid from the rash of an infected person.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS <promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] China (Henan)\nDate: Mon 22 Mar 2010\nSource: Xinhua News [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english2010/china/2010-03/23/c_13220801.htm>\n\n\n2 children have died of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD), and\nanother 1717 cases have been reported since January [2010] in\nPingdingshan City in central China's Henan Province, local authorities\nsaid Monday [22 Mar 2010]. The peak period for the disease is from May\nto July, but [the peak period] fell in March this year [2010], said\nHou Jiliu, Director of the Disease Prevention and Control Center of\nPingdingshan City. The city reported a daily high of 120 cases on [11\nMar 2010], and there are currently 30 to 50 cases reported every day,\nhe said. Some kindergartens have been closed in Ruzhou City, which is\nunder the administration of Pingdingshan, officials said. Pingdingshan\nhas spent more than 3 million yuan (USD 439 500) buying treatment\nequipment to fight the epidemic disease. Schools and kindergartens\nhave been ordered to conduct health checks twice a day.\n\nHFMD is a common illness that mainly affects children under the age of\n10. It usually starts with a slight fever followed by blisters and\nulcers in the mouth and rashes on the hands and feet. It is spread\nthrough contact with the saliva or feces of the infected.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS <promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] Viet Nam\nDate: Thu 18 Mar 2010\nSource: Radio The Voice of Viet Nam (VOV) News [edited]\n<http://english.vovnews.vn/Home/Rise-in-hand-foot-mouth-cases/20103/113646.vov>\n\n\nThe number of children contracting hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD)\nis on the rise even though the peak season is still one month away,\nChildren Hospitals Nos 1 and 2 in Ho Chi Minh City have announced. Dr\nTruong Huu Khanh, head of the Infection and Neurology Department at\nChildren's Hospital No 1, said that nearly 20 children were\nhospitalized due to HFMD in the past 3 days [in March 2010], which\nbrings the total number of infected children to 39. According to\nKhanh, 28 of the cases involve serious nerve complications that\nrequire special treatment. More than 60 percent of the patients live\nin the city, while the rest come from neighbouring areas.\n\nDr Tran Van Thao, deputy head of Children Hospital No 2, said the\nhospital received 32 children with HFMD, an increase of 50 percent\nduring the last week [in March 2010]. An 18-month-old baby was\nreported to have been in critical condition and died 20 hours after\nbeing hospitalized. The peak season of the illness is between April\nand May. However, early hot weather has led to a sudden onset of\nillness among children. EV71 [enterovirus 71] is known to cause high\nfever with blisters appearing on the mouth, palms, or on the soles of\nthe feet. Doctors have warned that it's easy to misdiagnose the\ndisease as scabies. Parents should take their children to hospital\nimmediately if they are showing symptoms to avoid complications, such\nas heart failure, lung swelling, or brain damage. Currently, there are\nno vaccines or specific remedies to cure the disease, according to the\ndoctor.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS <promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children. HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the\ngenus _Enterovirus_. This genus of viruses includes polioviruses,\ncoxsackieviruses, echoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16\nhas been the most common cause of HFMD, but other coxsackieviruses\nhave been associated with the illness. In recent outbreaks in Asia and\nAustralasia, enterovirus 71 has more often been associated with HFMD\nand linked with rare neurological complications of infection. The\nvirus responsible for the current outbreaks in South East Asia has not\nyet been identified, but the occurrence of neurological cases in Viet\nNam suggests that enterovirus 71 may be present.\n\nHFMD occurs mainly in children under 10 years old but can also occur\nin adults. Children are more likely to be at risk for infection and\nillness because they are less likely than adults to have antibodies to\nprotect them. Such antibodies develop in the body during a person's\n1st exposure to the enteroviruses that cause HFMD.\n\nIn temperate climates, cases occur more often in summer and early\nautumn. The early onset of the current outbreaks of HFMD in South East\nAsian countries may be a consequence of an earlier onset of warmer\nweather, which may facilitate transmission of the virus. Strict\nattention to personal hygiene is the only protection against infection.\n\nA map of Singapore can be accessed at:\n<http://www.google.co.uk/search?source=ig&hl=en&rlz=1G1GGLQ_ENGB269&=&q=Map+of+singapore&btnG=Google+Search&meta=lr%3D&aq=f&aqi=g10&aql=&oq=&gs_rfai=>, and the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Singapore is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00da>.\n\nA map of the provinces of China can be accessed at:\n<http://www.sacu.org/provmap.html>, and the HealthMap/ProMED-mail\ninteractive map of China is available at: <http://healthmap.org/r/00Wr>.\n\nA map of the provinces of Viet Nam can be accessed at:\n<http://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html>, and the\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map is available at:\n<http://healthmap.org/r/008O>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Currently, there are\nno vaccines or specific remedies to cure the disease, according to the\ndoctor.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nPRO/MBDS <promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common viral illness of\ninfants and children. The virus is\nunrelated to the foot and mouth disease that affects livestock.\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease typically strikes infants and children\nand is characterized by fever, mouth sores and a rash with blisters.\nIt is spread by direct contact with nose and throat discharges,\nsaliva, fluid from blisters, or the stool of infected people.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot & mouth disease (HFMD) is caused by several different\nviruses classified in the genus _Enterovirus_ of the family\n_Picornaviridae_. According to official data as of 15 Apr\n2010, 13 small children have died of this disease, and 643 children have\nbeen affected by it. Quanzhou County is the hardest-hit area in the region.\n\n'A child can look perfectly healthy one minute and totally different the\nnext, and will begin to deteriorate faster than a 100-metre race. This\ndiffers from our past experience with HFMD greatly,' a medical worker from\nthe Quanzhou County People's Hospital told the Beijing News. It was\ndiscovered that the virus mostly attacks small children under 3 years, and\nkills them in half an hour to 7 hours.\n\nAccording to China Youth Daily, in December 2009, a 21 month old child from\nKumatian Village of Jiaojiang Township in Quanzhou County suddenly\ndeveloped a rash on his body, followed by high fever a month later and\ndiarrhea that lasted a whole day. But the family did not take it too\nseriously. On 25 Jan 2010, the toddler's face suddenly turned blue and a\nrash appeared behind his knees as well as on his tongue. The family\nimmediately sent him to the Quanzhou County Maternal and Child Care Service\nCenter, but he died despite 3 hours of emergency treatment.\n\nThe Beijing News reported several cases of death of small children due to\nthe mutated virus. On 10 Mar 2010, a toddler boy from Daxijiang Township\ndied in the Quanzhou County People's Hospital with blood and some foam\ncoming out of his mouth. The outbreak of his symptoms had only begun 3 days\nbefore. 'Constant fever quickly resulted in failure of his vital organs,\nsuch as his heart and lungs,' recalled a doctor who had participated in the\nemergency treatment. The child's death made every doctor in the hospital\nwonder what virus could have claimed his life so quickly.\n\nOn 4 Mar 2010, a 7 month old boy died in the County Hospital with suspected\nHFMD. On 6 Apr 2010, a toddler boy from Longyan Village of Quanzhou County\ndied of the same disease. It was not until the Guangxi Autonomous Region\nDisease Control Center had sent an inspection report that people began to\nrealize the killer virus was EV71 [enterovirus 71], a mutated form of the\nHFMD virus. [Enterovirus 71 is one of several types of enterovirus that may\nbe associated with outbreaks of HFMD. It is not a 'mutated form'. The\nenterovirus principally associated with hand, foot and mouth diseases are\ncoxsackievirus A16 and enterovirus 71; taxonomically viruses are members of\nthe same virus species _Human enterovirus A_. - Mod.CP]\n\nOn 10 Apr 2010, a 2 year old male toddler died in the Quanzhou County\nPeople's Hospital. Prior to his death, he had a fever, blood, and foam\ncoming from his mouth, and fading breath.\n\nWang Qun, head of the outpatient department in the Affiliated Hospital of\nGuilin Medical School, said, 'EV71 attacks vital organs such as the heart\nand lungs as soon as it enters the human body. The outbreak is fast, and\nthe death rate for critically ill patients can be as high as 80 per cent,'\naccording to a Beijing News report.\n\nIn the past, HFMD patients developed noticeable rashes on the hands, feet\nand mouth areas. The symptoms were mild and the death rate was low.\nPatients with EV71 infection hardly develop any rashes on the body, [this]\noutbreak is acute, and the death rate is high. The head of Quanzhou County\nDisease Control Center, Fang Tianxi, told The Beijing News, 'EV 71 has\nnever been seen in Quanzhou Country before. It has caught the disease\ncontrol departments off guard.'\n\nA management [spokesperson] from the Quanzhou County Maternal and Child\nCare Service Center told The Epoch Times that it is now the peak season for\nHFMD, and things are much worse this year than in previous years. He said\nthe insidious virus is easily passed among children without being noticed.\nMild symptoms of this disease look a lot like those of a simple cold.\nHowever, if a child develops a fever of 38.5 degrees Celsius (101.3 F) and\nabove, the child should be taken to see a doctor. At present, there is only\none hospital dedicated to treating HFMD in Quanzhou County.\n\n[byline: Fang Xiao]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD is caused by several different viruses classified in the genus _Human\nenterovirus A_ of the family _Picornaviridae_. By: E Haneke. At: Dermatology Practice 'Dermaticum,'\nFreiburg, Germany; Department of Dermatology, Inselspital, University\nof Bern, Bern, Switzerland; Dermatology Centre 'Epidermis;' Instituto\nCUF, Porto, Portugal; Department of Dermatology, Academic Hospital,\nUniversity of Ghent, Ghent, Belgium\n\nOnychomadesis is the spontaneous separation of the nail plate from\nthe matrix, a kind of proximal onycholysis, and is a common\nphenomenon due to arrest of nail formation for a certain period.\nShort-term slowing down of nail formation leads to Beau's lines,\nwhile long-term stop of nail growth will cause onychomadesis and even\nnail shedding.\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a relatively common viral\ninfection often seen as small epidemics in autumn or spring [In fact,\nin south-east Asian countries, epidemics of HFMDV characteristically\ninvolve large numbers of infants, are socially disruptive, and\nresponsible for a number of fatalities. - Mod.CP]. It is\ncharacterised by oval blisters around the nails, on palms and soles\nwith the long axis of the vesicles running along the dermatoglyphs,\nand by aphthoid small ulcerations of the oral mucosa. Small children\nare mostly infected, but probably many parents are non-symptomatic\ncarriers as the condition usually runs a very mild course.\n\nA relationship between HFMD and onychomadesis has been proposed\nalready 10 years ago [1,2], but only recently Finnish and Spanish\nauthors observed a sufficient number of children developing\nonychomadesis approximately 6 weeks after they had suffered from HFMD\n[3-6] that makes this appear more than a chance association. An\narticle by Guimbao and coworkers published in today's [16 Sep 2010]\nissue of Eurosurveillance [see (2) below] describes an outbreak of\nonychomadesis in Saragossa (Spain) in July 2008 [7]. The authors\nnoticed that a large proportion of the patients had had HFMD a few\nweeks before and initiated a retrospective cohort study that\nindicated a link between the 2 diseases. They conclude that\nonychomadesis may be a late complication of HFMD.\n\nFrom these authors' and the previous ones' observations, there is no\ndoubt that there is a temporal link between HFMD and onychomadesis.\n\nThe question is now: Is the virus, more specifically the enterovirus\ncausing HFMD, really the cause of onychomadesis? While the number of\nonchomadesis cases in these young patients suggests it, could it have\nbeen caused rather by the inflammation so close to the nail matrix?\nOr could it have been due -- of course much less likely -- to\nintensive hygienic measures taken after HFMD broke out in the\nnurseries? It is well known that maceration favours Candida\ninfections and allergic contact dermatitis, which can also cause\nonychomadesis [8]. The timing of viral determination from stools and\npharynx samples taken one to 3 weeks after the diagnosis of\nonychomadesis and thus between 7-9 weeks after the disease, appears\nto be very late considering that HFMD is a self-limited condition\nhealing spontaneously within a week. In order to solve the problem,\nmore viruses that could potentially be associated with the 2\nconditions will need to be analysed, with viral analyses of nail\nspecimens!\n(e.g. swabs from under the proximal nail fold) performed in the\nearly course of the disease.\n\nHowever, onychomadesis per se is certainly not infectious; instead,\nit may be the consequence of an infectious disease often localised\nvery close to the nail. Another explanation would be that HFMD has a\nmore severe impact on the general condition of the small children so\nthat it causes a nail growth arrest for a period sufficiently long to\nresult in onychomadesis.\n\nReferences\n\n[1] Clementz GC, Mancini AJ. Nail matrix arrest following hand-foot-\nmouth disease: a report of five children. Pediatr Dermatol.\n2000;17(1): 7-11.\n\n[2] Bernier V, Labreze C, Bury F, Taieb A. Nail matrix arrest in the\ncourse of hand, foot and mouth disease. Eur J Pediatr. 2001;160(11):\n649-51.\n\n[3] Osterback R, Vuorinen T, Linna M, Susi P, Hyypia T, Waris M.\nCoxsackievirus A6 and hand, foot, and mouth disease, Finland. Emerg\nInfect Dis. 2009;15(9):1485-8.\n\n[4] Redondo Granado MJ, Torres Hinojal MC, Izquierdo Lopez B. Brote\nde onicomadesis posvirica en Valladolid. [Post viral onychomadesis\noutbreak in Valladolid]. Spanish. An Pediatr (Barc). 2009;71(5):436-9.\n\n[5] Blomqvist S, Klemola P, Kaijalainen S, Paananen A, Simonen ML,\nVuorinen T, et al. Co-circulation of coxsackieviruses A6 and A10 in\nhand, foot and mouth disease outbreak in Finland. J Clin Virol.\n2010;48(1):49-54.\n\n[6] Davia JL, Bel PH, Ninet VZ, Bosch IF, Salazar A, Gobernado M.\nOnychomadesis outbreak in Valencia, Spain associated with hand, foot,\nand mouth disease caused by enteroviruses. Pediatr Dermatol. 2010 Jun\n9. [Epub ahead of print]\n\n[7] Guimbao J, Rodrigo P, Alberto MJ, Omenaca M. Onychomadesis\noutbreak linked to hand, foot, and mouth disease, Spain, July 2008.\nEuro Surveill. 2010;15(37):pii=19663. Available from:\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19663>.\n\n[8] Tosti A, Piraccini BM. Paronychia. In: Amin S, Maibach HI.\nContact Urticaria Syndrome. Boca Raton, Florida: CRC Press; 1997.\np.267-78.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Thu 16 Sep 2010\nSource: Eurosurveillance, Volume 15, Issue 37 [summarised & edited]\n<http://www.eurosurveillance.org/ViewArticle.aspx?ArticleId=19663>\n\n\nOnychomadesis outbreak linked to hand, foot, and mouth disease,\nSpain, July 2008\n---------------------\nSummary: In July 2008, an onychomadesis outbreak in a nursery setting\nwas reported in Saragossa (Spain). Some of the cases had previously\nsuffered from hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD). In order to study\nthe outbreak and to determine the relation between the 2 diseases, 2\nepidemiological studies were conducted: a descriptive study focused\non cases and a retrospective cohort study. Samples from stool,\npharynx and nails were obtained from cases for microbiological\nanalysis. During the study period, 27 children fulfilled the case\ndefinition. The average age was 1.8 years. A case shed on average 4\nnails (minimum one, maximum 12). 24 of the 27 cases had previously\npresented with HFMD which started an average of 40 days before the\nonset of onychomadesis (relative risk: 14). Unidentified non-polio\nenterovirus (n=10), coxsackie B1 (n=4) and coxsackie B2 virus (n=3)\nwere isolated in 28 specimens obtained from 14 cases. The analysis\nshowed a strong association between HMFD and onycho!\nmadesis. Microbiological results have not been conclusive;\nconsequently, more studies are necessary to determine the causal\nagent of infectious onychomadesis.\n\n[Interested readers should consult the full article via the above\nURL. - Mod.CP]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[HFMD epidemics have primarily been associated with different\nenteroviruses, such as coxsackievirus A6, A10, and A16, echovirus 4,\nenterovirus 71, and unidentified non-poliovirus enteroviruses. Those\ncaused by enterovirus 71 have occurred more frequently in Southeast\nAsia in recent years, but onychomadesis has not been reported as a\ncomplication of HFMD in these epidemic.\n\nThe diversity of enteroviruses associated with HFMD and the time\nlapse between the acute disease and the appearance of onychomadesis\nmake it difficult to confirm an association. However, it may be that\nHFMD is more than an acute, self-limiting febrile disease, and\nfurther analysis is warranted. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "At: Dermatology Practice 'Dermaticum,'\nFreiburg, Germany; Department of Dermatology, Inselspital, University\nof Bern, Bern, Switzerland; Dermatology Centre 'Epidermis;' Instituto\nCUF, Porto, Portugal; Department of Dermatology, Academic Hospital,\nUniversity of Ghent, Ghent, Belgium\n\nOnychomadesis is the spontaneous separation of the nail plate from\nthe matrix, a kind of proximal onycholysis, and is a common\nphenomenon due to arrest of nail formation for a certain period. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\n The timing of viral determination from stools and\npharynx samples taken one to 3 weeks after the diagnosis of\nonychomadesis and thus between 7-9 weeks after the disease, appears\nto be very late considering that HFMD is a self-limited condition\nhealing spontaneously within a week. The disease causes fever and blister-like\neruptions in the mouth and/or a skin rash. Illness usually begins\nwith a fever, poor appetite, discomfort, and often with a sore\nthroat. One or 2 days after fever onset, painful sores usually\ndevelop in the mouth. They begin as small red spots that blister and\nthen often become ulcers. The sores are usually located on the\ntongue, gums, and inside of the cheeks. A non-itchy skin rash\ndevelops over 1-2 days. The rash has flat or raised red spots,\nsometimes with blisters. The rash is usually located on the palms of\nthe hands and soles of the feet; it may also appear on the buttocks\nand/or genitalia.\n\nHFMD can be caused by a number of entroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 is\nthe most common cause of HFMD, but enterovirus 71 is currently\ncausing widespread outbreaks of HFMD in Southeast Asia (see\nProMED-mail references below).\n\nHFMD occurs mainly in children under 10 years old but can also occur\nin adults. Children are more likely to be at risk for infection and\nillness because they are less likely than adults to have antibodies\nto protect them.\n\nSt Andrew can be located using the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive\nmap of Jamaica at: <http://healthmap.org/r/00Vh>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 9 Oct 2009\n Under the guidance of the Ministry of Health,\nwe have been advised that it is best to approach the issue in this\nmanner to minimise, to the extent that we reasonably can, the\npossibility of our children spreading the infectious disease,' he\nsaid. A 12\nmonth old girl died of a brain inflammation on Tuesday last week [5 May\n2009] after being infected with enterovirus 71 (EV-71), a strong\n[virulent?] intestinal virus, said Jun Byung-yul, a senior official of the\nKorea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nCaused by intestinal viruses coxsackie A virus and enterovirus 71, the\nhuman syndrome [hand, foot, and mouth disease] is a common childhood\ndisease that mainly affects children under the age of 5 during the summer\nand early autumn months. Early symptoms of the disease are similar to those\nof ordinary flu such as a fever and a sore throat. Even though there is no\nspecific vaccine for the disease, most patients recover in a week without\nmedical treatment. However, in severe cases, patients can suffer from\nneurological complications such as brain inflammation and meningitis,\nsometimes leading to death.\n\nThere have been some cases where children infected with the coxsackie A\nvirus have had complications in Korea. But it is the 1st time for the\nenterovirus 71, which has killed more than 80 children in China since last\nmonth [April 2009], to be found in the country.\n\n'Because the girl had never been to China and other South East Asian\ncountries where the virus has thrived in recent years, we think the virus\nhas already been localized in this country after being transferred from\nChina,' Jun said. It is possible the virus is [responsible for] some deaths\nof children who died of brain inflammation or meningitis [in South Korea]\nin recent years, Jun said.\n\nDespite the worsening situation in and out of the country, health\nauthorities said they do not know the exact number of children infected\nwith the EV-17 because the disease is not a legally designated infectious\ndisease monitored by the government. According to recent government\nfigures, which were offered by 186 sample pediatrics in the latest 19\nweeks, the number of patients seems to be increasing. However, the outbreak\nis not large enough to be considered an epidemic, health officials said.\n\n'Some fatal cases in China are considered because children in some regions\nwere malnourished and couldn't be supported by the better medical system,'\nJun said. 'We will launch a monitoring system on the outbreak situation of\nthe disease in cooperation with related medical organization, especially in\nSuwon, Gyeonggi Province, where the nation's 1st fatal case was found,' he\nadded.\n\nExperts say intestinal viruses usually thrive in warm weather, causing\nhand, foot and mouth disease in April and other complications in May until\nthe rainy season starts in June. 'The disease passes easily among children\nthrough blisters on their hands, feet, and buttocks. So child care centers\nand kindergartens need to take greater care in cleaning surfaces of\nchildren's stuff,' said Kim Dong-soo, a podiatrist at Severance Children's\nHospital. 'There's no special way to prevent the infection. Children and\ntheir parents themselves should follow hygiene rules such as drinking\nboiled water only, brushing teeth whenever necessary and avoiding\ncontacting with too many people,' Kim advised.\n\nMeanwhile, the government's [delayed] announcement of the fatal case, which\noccurred 10 days earlier, was criticized by the media and the public.\n'There was some miscommunication among health officials in reporting the\ncase to upper authorities. I apologize for confusing people about the\ncase,' said Jun, who is in charge of disease prevention and control\nincluding the latest H1N1 influenza.\n\n[byline: Lee Ji-yoon]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This appears to be the 1st fatal case of hand, foot and mouth disease\namong children in South Korea so far this year (2009). HFMD is common among infants and\nchildren, and most of the recently reported cases have occurred in\nchildren.\n\nThe disease is very contagious and is spread through contact with the\nbody fluids of an infected person, such as droplets from coughs and\nsneezes, saliva, blister fluid, or stool.\n\nChina\n-----\nOn 10 Apr 2009, China's Ministry of Health Information Office reported\nthat 54 713 cases of HFMD had been detected through the end of March\n2009. Most of these cases were in rural areas. The provinces and\nregions most affected by this outbreak are the central provinces of\nHenan, Jiangsu, Guangxi, Anhui, Guangdong, Hebei, Hunan, Zhejiang,\nHubei, and the eastern province of Shandong. As of 30 Mar 2009, the\nChinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention (China CDC)\nconfirmed that at least 19 children have died from HFMD this year\n[2009].\n\nThe Chinese government has enhanced its surveillance, prevention, and\ncontrol activities, along with training of local medical staff to\nidentify and report cases promptly.\n\nHong Kong S.A.R.\n----------------\nAs of 27 Mar 2009, the Center for Health Protection of Hong Kong has\nconfirmed one case of HFMD. Nine other children who were exposed at\nthe nursery where the ill child attended also developed HFMD symptoms.\nThis is the 7th case reported to the Center for Health Protection of\nHong Kong this year [2009].\n\nSingapore\n---------\nAs of 11 Apr 2009, Singapore's Ministry of Health has reported 5471\ncases of HFMD infections this year [2009]. Typically, Singapore\nexperiences annual peaks of HFMD from March to May.\n\nTaiwan\n------\nAs of 31 Mar 2009, the Taiwan Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention (Taiwan CDC) has reported 9 cases of HFMD with severe\ncomplications, all in children under 5 years of age. Two cases each\nwere located in the northern and central area of Taiwan, and 5\nadditional cases were located in the southern area of Taiwan.\n\nIn response to the growing number of reports of HFMD, other countries\nin the Western Pacific have increased surveillance for HFMD. When\navailable, further information on this evolving situation will be\nposted as an update to this notice.\n\nAdvice for Travelers\n--------------------\nNo vaccine is available to prevent HFMD. There is no specific\ntreatment for people who are sick with this disease other than\ntreating symptoms, such as fever. If you are sick and have fever while\nyou are traveling, be aware that some countries treat fever with a\nclass of medicine called pyrazolone that is banned in the United\nStates due to harmful side effects. This medicine may even be\navailable over-the-counter. CDC does not recommend using this class of\nmedicine to treat fever.\n\nIn general, because in some countries there is a risk that medications\nyou buy will be counterfeit, CDC recommends that you bring with you\nall the medications that you think you will need during your trip. You\nshould consider taking fever medicine with you to treat any symptoms\nif you plan to travel to any of these countries. Travelers can take\nsteps to prevent getting HFMD by practicing good personal hygiene. If\nyou are traveling, especially to areas where HFMD has been reported,\nfollow these tips for good health:\n\n- Wash your hands often with soap and water, especially before you\neat, after you cough or sneeze, and after you go to the bathroom. If\nsoap and water are not available, use an alcohol-based hand gel (with\nat least 60 percent alcohol). Consider packing alcohol-based hand gel\nin your luggage to ensure you have it when needed.\n- Do not share eating utensils, such as forks, spoons, and cups.\n\nAdults should help child travelers to follow these recommendations.\nInfants, children, and adolescents are more susceptible to HFMD.\n\nHFMD is an illness caused by certain enterovirus strains, including\nEV71 [enterovirus 71], which are common worldwide. Outbreaks of HFMD\ncaused by EV71 are common and have been reported by countries\nthroughout the Asia-Pacific region in recent years. EV71 can be spread\nfrom person to person by direct contact with nose and throat\nsecretions (e.g., by coughing or sneezing), saliva, fluid from\nblisters, or the stool of infected persons. People who are sick with\nHFMD often experience symptoms such as fever, sores in the mouth, and\na rash, occasionally with blisters. HFMD caused by EV71 may sometimes\nlead to serious complications, including swelling of the brain\n(encephalitis). Most cases of HFMD occur in children under 10 years of\nage, but adults can also become infected.\n\nFor more information, see the CDC Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease Fact sheet:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/hfhf.htm>.\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 3 Jun 2009\n If\nyou are traveling, especially to areas where HFMD has been reported,\nfollow these tips for good health:\n\n- Wash your hands often with soap and water, especially before you\neat, after you cough or sneeze, and after you go to the bathroom. Severe forms of [the illness]\ncan be deadly if not properly treated.\n\n18 children have died from the disease in central Henan province and\nat least 15 in eastern Shandong province this year [2009], the\nofficial Xinhua news agency reported.\n\nHenan, a rural province crowded with poor farmers, is the center of\nChina's latest outbreak of the disease, which killed 40 children\nnationwide last year [2008], spreading alarm among parents. The\ndeaths in Henan were among nearly 20 000 cases of the disease\nconfirmed in the province, including 5965 in hospital, as of Monday [6\nApr 2009], the Xinhua News Agency stated.\n\nA provincial official warned that worse may come. 'As the weather\nwarms, cases of hand, foot and mouth disease in Henan may rise\nfurther,' a vice governor of Henan, Song Xuantao, told Xinhua. 'The\nsituation facing prevention and treatment is very grim.'\n\nIn late March 2009, Minquan County in Henan said one child had died of\nthe disease. Minquan has now confirmed that 8 children have died from\nthe disease, the Xinhua report said. They were among the 18 dead\nreported by Henan.\n\nThe report from Shandong said 11 500 children had been diagnosed with\nthe disease and 7100 had already recovered. It is caused by enteroviruses\n[predominantly enterovirus 71 and coxsackievirus A16 - Mod.CP]. The\nclinical presentations include fever and vesicular rash of the hand,\nfoot, and mouth. Some children may have complications such as\nmyocarditis, pulmonary edema, and aseptic meningitis. To control the\ndisease, China has stated that when cases of HFMD are found,\nofficials must report online within 24 hours. However, our reporters\nhave found that a hospital in Ming-Chuan county is fabricating\npatient records to hide the true extent of HFMD.\n\nRecently, our reporter went to the Ming-Chuan County People's\nHospital in Henan Province. The 2nd floor of the in-patient\ndepartment seemed extraordinarily crowded. There were more than 60\nbeds with children aged from a few months to 4-5 years. Thousands of children in east and central China have been sickened\nwith hand-foot-mouth disease [HFMD], a highly contagious illness\n The disease, which is common in China, took an unusually high toll in\nthe 1st few months of 2008, infecting nearly 25 000 people nationwide\nand killing around 40, according to government figures.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2008-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2009-03-25 00:00:00", "2021-03-24 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-30 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Heze", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Beijing", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Shandong", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "170269", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=170269", "date": "2009-04-01 22:00:52", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (05)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Wed 1 Apr 2009\nSource: Nature News, Nature 458, 554-555 (2009) [edited]\n<http://www.nature.com/news/2009/090401/full/458554a.html>\n\n\nViral outbreak in China tests government efforts\n------------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in\nChina, which since January [2009] has killed 19\nchildren and made nearly 42 000 ill, has\nresearchers calling for a better surveillance\nsystem to detect the disease and for action to\nspeed up vaccine development. 'The situation of\npreventing and containing hand, foot and mouth\ndisease is very serious at the moment,' Deng\nHaihua, spokesman for China's health ministry,\nsaid last week. More cases are expected, as the\ndisease normally peaks between May and July. In\nthe absence of a drug treatment, the ministry is\nfocusing on prevention and containment.\n\nThe outbreak is the latest in a series to have\nhit China in recent years, caused by a\nfast-spreading virus called enterovirus 71. 'The\npersistence of enterovirus 71 outbreaks in China\nis a wake-up call,' says Jane Cardosa, a\nvirologist at the University Malaysia Sarawak in\nKota Samarahan. In 1997, Sarawak saw the 1st\noutbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease in the\nAsia-Pacific region. The disease causes flu-like\nsymptoms, along with rashes on the hands and\nfeet, and mouth ulcers. It can be caused by many\ntypes of human enterovirus belonging to the\nfamily _Picornaviridae_, which are mainly\ntransmitted through fecal or oral routes.\nAlthough normally mild, the disease can be\nlife-threatening: some viruses, particularly\nenterovirus 71, can cause inflammation of the\nbrain stem, resulting in heart failure and fluid accumulation in the lungs.\n\nIn 1997 in Sarawak, more than 2600 cases of the\ndisease were reported and 29 people died. The\nnext year in Taiwan, there were 129 000 reported\ncases and 78 deaths. In mainland China, the 1st\nreported case was in Shenzhen, Guangdong\nprovince, in 1999. At 1st, outbreaks were local\nand there were no reported fatalities. But since\n2004, the outbreaks have become more severe and\nwidespread, says Xu Wenbo, an infectious-disease\nexpert at the Beijing-based China Center for Disease Control and Prevention.\n\nIn May 2008, the country's health ministry added\nhand, foot and mouth to its category 'C' of\nnotifiable diseases, meaning that all diagnosed\ncases must be reported through a national\nWeb-based system for disease surveillance, and\ntook measures to streamline reporting\nrequirements. The Ministry also vowed to take a\ntough stance against cover-ups and last month\n[fired] 4 health officials in Henan province for\nconcealing the number of infections and deaths.\n\nThis year, enterovirus 71 has caused nearly all\nof the laboratory-confirmed cases in 2 hot-spots,\nthe provinces of Henan and Shandong.\n\nXu suspects that the disease's increasing\nvirulence may be due to a genetic change in the\ncirculating virus strain. Before 2004 the\npredominant strain was called C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common (see:\nY. Zhang et al. J. Clin. Virol. 44, 262\u00ad267;\n2009). What caused this switch isn't clear, says\nXu, as little is known about the genetics and\ntransmission trends of the fast-mutating virus.\nMost studies have been clinical, aimed at, for\nexample, identifying the strains behind a given\noutbreak and the disease's clinical features,\nespecially when there are neurological\ncomplications. Many researchers say it is time to\nstep up efforts to understand the basic biology\nof enterovirus 71 to speed vaccine development.\n\nIn a major push financed by the Chinese Health\nMinistry and the Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention, Xu and his colleagues measured the\ninfection rate in adults and children during last\nyear's outbreak and analysed stool samples and\nthroat swabs taken from more than 18 000\npatients. Preliminary results suggest that the\ninfection rate is alarmingly high, meaning that\nthere are large populations of virus carriers who\ndo not show any symptoms of the disease.\n\nExperts are divided as to how worried the world\nshould be about the virus. Tom Solomon, a\nneurologist at the University of Liverpool, UK,\nargues that enterovirus 71 infection is\nunderappreciated on a global scale and may pose a\nbigger risk to public health than is currently\nthought. But Hans Troedsson, the World Health\nOrganization's representative in China, says\n'there is no cause for alarm.' The public-health\nimpact of hand, foot and mouth disease, including\ncases caused by enterovirus 71, is no more\nserious than other common childhood diseases, he\nsays. Troedsson thinks that the recent apparent\nincrease in enterovirus 71 infection might be due\nto higher reporting rates rather than an increase\nin disease prevalence. 'We will closely monitor\nthe situation and decide policies accordingly,' he says.\n\n[Byline: Jane Qiu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This article provides a useful statement of the current situation and\nan indication of the extent of the epidemic. The strain of\nenterovirus 71 associated with this outbreak differs from that\nprevalent in earlier outbreaks when the disease was less prevalent.\nBefore 2004, the predominant strain was designated C4b; since then, a\ndifferent strain, C4a, has been most common. Whether this is related\nto the apparently greater severity of the disease since 2004 has still\nto be established. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "In May 2008, the country's health ministry added\nhand, foot and mouth to its category 'C' of\nnotifiable diseases, meaning that all diagnosed\ncases must be reported through a national\nWeb-based system for disease surveillance, and\ntook measures to streamline reporting\nrequirements. This, he said, was based on the\ncycle of HFMD outbreaks, which have occurred every 3 years in the\nstate [Sarawak]. The disease\ncauses fever and blister-like eruptions in the mouth and/or a skin\nrash. Individual cases and outbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide. In\ntemperate climates, cases occur more often in summer and early\nautumn. HFMD is caused by viruses that belong to the genus\n_Enterovirus_, which includes polioviruses, coxsackieviruses,\nechoviruses, and enteroviruses. Coxsackievirus A16 has been the most\ncommon cause of HFMD, but other coxsackieviruses have been associated\nwith the illness. Since 1997, outbreaks of HFMD caused by enterovirus\n71 have been reported throughout Asia and in Australia.\n\nWhereas HFMD caused by coxsackievirus A16 infection is a mild\ndisease, with nearly all patients recovering in 7 to 10 days without\nmedical treatment, HFMD caused by enterovirus 71 has shown a higher\nincidence of neurologic involvement. Fatal cases of encephalitis\ncaused by enterovirus 71 have occurred during outbreaks.\n\nHFMD occurs mainly in children under 10 years of age but can also\noccur in adults. Children are more likely to be at risk of infection\nand illness because they lack protective antibodies. Infection\nprovides in immunity to the specific virus causing the disease, but a\n2nd infection may occur following exposure to a different enterovirus.\n\nPrevention depends on strict attention to hygiene. The\nministry recorded 41 846 cases of hand-foot-mouth disease in 30\nprovinces and regions, excluding Tibet, in the past 3 months,\nministry spokesman Deng Haihua said.\n\nAbout 94 percent of the patients were children under 5 years old, 75\npercent were affected by the virus EV71 [enterovirus 71], and 94\nsuffered severe symptoms, Deng told a press conference in Beijing. Enteroviruses infecting humans are found worldwide and\nhumans are the only known natural hosts. Young children are most\nsusceptible to infection. In less developed areas, children may\nbecome infected during early infancy, while in more socio-economically\nadvanced areas, 1st infection may not occur until adolescence. Males\nmore often develop clinically recognizable diseases than females.\nTransmission is usually faeco-oral, or by the respiratory route\nwhen there is an associated respiratory illness.\n\nEnterovirus 71 (family _Picornaviridae_, genus _Enterovirus_, species\n_Human enterovirus A_) was first isolated in 1969. Since then it has\nbeen associated with sporadic outbreaks in various parts of the\nworld, including China, Brazil, Europe, Australia, Malaysia, Taiwan,\nand the USA. Enterovirus 71 infection may present itself much like\nother enterovirus infections, with symptoms ranging from asymptomatic\nto the presentation of rashes, diarrhea, colds, meningitis,\nencephalitis, hand foot & mouth disease, myocarditis, or some\ncombination of these syndromes. On the other hand, enterovirus 71 may\ncause many unusual syndromes such as acute flaccid paralysis (similar\nto paralytic poliomyelitis), bulbar and brain encephalitis,\nGuillain-Barre syndrome, and rapidly fatal pulmonary edema and\nhemorrhage.\n\nThe epidemiological pattern varies by geographical region and\nclimate, but the incidence of infection is higher in the summer and\nautumn months in temperate climates, while remaining prevalent\nyear-round in tropical climates (for more information see\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs174/en/index.html>.\n\nA map of the provinces of China showing the location of Henan and\nShandong in the eastern part of the country is available at\n<http://www.muztagh.com/map-of-china/>\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed/en?v=36.5,103.9,4>. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 27 Mar 2009\n Enterovirus 71 infection may present itself much like\nother enterovirus infections, with symptoms ranging from asymptomatic\nto the presentation of rashes, diarrhea, colds, meningitis,\nencephalitis, hand foot & mouth disease, myocarditis, or some\ncombination of these syndromes. \n\nThe epidemiological pattern varies by geographical region and\nclimate, but the incidence of infection is higher in the summer and\nautumn months in temperate climates, while remaining prevalent\nyear-round in tropical climates (for more information see\n<http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs174/en/index.html>. Asia (26): China (Fujian)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=120757", "date": "2008-10-20 19:00:37", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (26): CHINA (FUJIAN)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 20 Oct 2008\nSource: Reuters AlertNet [edited]\n<http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/PEK261074.htm>\n\n\nThree children have died in eastern China from hand, foot and mouth\ndisease in the country's 2nd outbreak of the potent toddler virus\nthis year [2008], state media reported on Monday [20 Oct 2008].\n\nHealth officials warned that the disease was epidemic in some parts\nof the coastal Fujian province, with 113 cases reported since the\nstart of October 2008, the official Xinhua news agency stated. The 3\nvictims were all less than one year old and from the same place,\nJian'ou City, it added. A flare-up of the virus [infection] in\nsouthern China killed at least 42 people in April and May 2008, and\n27 500 further cases, largely affecting toddlers, were reported.\n\nHand, foot and mouth disease is a common childhood illness, but the\noutbreaks in China have been linked with enterovirus 71 (EV71), which\ncan cause a severe form of the disease characterised by high fever,\nparalysis and meningitis.\n\nThere is no vaccine for the disease, and, normally, patients recover\nwithin a week to 10 days. Enteroviruses spread mostly through contact\nwith infected blisters or feces.\n\n[Byline: Simon Rabinovitch and Valerie Lee]\n\n--\nCommunicator by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[A map of the provinces of China is available at:\n<http://www.muztagh.com/map-of-china/index.html>;\nthe coastal province of Fujian lies in the latitude of Taiwan. The\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=36.5,103.9,4>,\nand the interior city of Jianou can be located via\n<http://www.maplandia.com/china/fujian/jianou/>.\n\nIn the most recent ProMED-mail report concerning hand, foot and mouth\ndisease (HFMD) in China, dated 25 Jul 2008 (see archive report\nbelow), it was indicated that the outbreak which had moved from\nsouthern and central China further north was in decline. Today's\nreport from Fujian province suggests that there has been a resurgence\nof HFMD accompanied by an appreciable number of fatalities.\nEnterovirus 71 has been identified as the etiologic agent, the virus\nresponsible for the Asia-wide outbreak of HFMD during the past year. - Mod.CP]\n\n[It should be noted that 2008 is the 1st year in which reporting of\nHFMD is mandatory, hence, while the numbers of reported cases may\nappear to be exceptionally large, there are no official reports from\nearlier years to make comparisons. Last\nweek, 553 people came down with the normally mild childhood disease\nthat usually causes fever and rashes on the hands, feet and buttocks.\nThat is just 12 fewer than the Health Ministry's official 'epidemic level.'\n\nThe tally last week was up from 415 over the previous 7 days, and\nhealth officials warn the numbers are likely to rise between now and\nOctober, traditionally a peak period for HFMD. This peak, though,\nusually affects fewer people than the 1st one from March to May, said\nDr. Lyn James, director of the Health Ministry's communicable\ndiseases division. The reasons for the peaks are not known.\n\nStill, the latest surge has already proven deadly. On 6 Aug 2008,\nSingapore registered its 1st death from HFMD [see: Hand, foot & mouth\ndisease - Asia (23): Singapore 20080808.2447] since a severe\noutbreak from 2000 to 2001 killed 7 children. Like most of those\nvictims, the 3-year-old child died from a severe form of HFMD caused by\na virus called EV71 [human enterovirus 71]. This virus has been of\nparticular concern to countries in Asia, which have been battling\noutbreaks of HFMD in recent years. This year, it has killed 44 in\nChina, 10 in Taiwan and 11 in Viet Nam.\n\nThe Health Ministry and the Regional Emerging Disease Intervention\n(Redi) Centre organised a 2-day regional forum on HFMD, which was\nattended by more than 80 scientists and public health officers from\n12 countries. At the forum's last day yesterday [25 Aug 2008], local\nvaccine company SingVax, Chinese vaccine company Sinovac Biotech and\nTaiwan's Centres for Disease Control gave updates on their progress\nin developing the world's first HFMD vaccine. Both SingVax and\nTaiwan's CDC said they have seen good results in the laboratories and\nhope to start clinical trials next year [2009].\n\nIn the absence of a vaccine, parents should ensure their children\nwash their hands, because the disease is often spread through saliva\nand faecal matter. They should also take their children to the doctor\nat the 1st sign of symptoms, and keep them away from schools and\ncrowded places, Dr. James said.\n\nMeanwhile, the school that the deceased child attended, Elias\nKindergarten in Woodlands, reopened earlier this week after a 10-day\nclosure to clean up. EV71 has been associated with acute febrile\nillness, myocarditis, aseptic meningitis, acute flaccid paralysis,\nand encephalitis as well as with HFMD. Children under 5 years of age\nare particulalry susceptible to these conditions and may develop\npermanent neurological damage or, rarely, may succumb to these\ndisorders.
