And 3610 children who\nfell ill with the diseases were under the age of 5. Medical\nexaminations found enterovirus 71 (EV71) was responsible.\n\nLocal health officials refused to provide more details regarding the\n3 deaths. HFMD can be caused by a host of intestinal viruses, but\nEV71 and the coxsackievirus A16 (Cox A16) are the most common. It\nusually starts with a slight fever followed by blisters and ulcers in\nthe mouth and rashes on the hands and feet. Those sickened by EV71\noften show serious symptoms. It can also lead to meningitis,\nencephalitis, pulmonary edema and paralysis in some children. There\nis no vaccine.\n\nThere was a HFMD outbreak in parts of south China in the spring. In\nFuyang, the worst hit area, 22 children died of intestinal virus\n[infection] clinically diagnosed as EV71 infection, among tens of\nthousands of non-fatal infections.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It appears from this delayed report that HFMD may have affected the\nnortheastern province of Jilin somewhat later than in south and\ncentral China. Asia (21): Mongolia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=95297", "date": "2008-07-15 16:00:27", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (21): MONGOLIA\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Mon 14 Jul 2008\nSource: UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA),\nReliefWeb, Int Fed of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies report\n[abbreviated and edited]\n<http://www.reliefweb.int/rw/rwb.nsf/db900SID/ASAZ-7GKCKN?OpenDocument>\n\n\nMongolia: hand-foot-mouth disease update No. 1: 10 Jun-8 Jul 2008\n-----------------------------------------------------------------\nSummary\n-------\nHygiene promotion activities have commenced and already volunteers and\nstaff of the Mongolian Red Cross Society have been mobilized to deliver\nimportant messages to the public about the prevention of this disease.\nActivities to support capacity building at the branches for the ongoing\nprevention of hand-foot-mouth disease will start in late July [2008].\n\nThe situation\n-------------\nSince 8 May 2008 a serious outbreak of hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) due\nto enterovirus 71 (EV71) has affected thousands of children and families\nthroughout Mongolia. As of 7 Jul 2008, a total of 2618 people have been\ndiagnosed with this virus. 83 per cent of the reported enteroviral diseases\noccurred in children who were younger than 10 years and 10 per cent of\nthose infected were younger than one year.\n\nAlthough many have recovered on their own and no fatal cases have been\nreported to date, as of 7 Jul 2008, 24.5 per cent of all those diagnosed\nwith enterovirus 71 had complications that required hospitalizations.\nSeveral patients had severe complications such as aseptic meningitis,\nencephalitis, myocarditis, and poliomyelitis-like paralysis, which may lead\nto disability or even death. It is known that pulmonary edema or\nhaemorrhage, which is a common complication, can kill a child within one\nday, therefore health workers all over the country have been working\naround-the-clock providing intensive care to patients in critical\ncondition. Largely owing credit to these efforts, no casualties have been\nreported to date. As of 7 Jul 2008, 162 individuals remain hospitalized and\n599 people have been discharged from hospitals.\n\nTotal number of cases of HFMD (8 May-7 Jul 2008)\n------------------------------------------------\nAccording to the Ministry of Health of Mongolia this is the largest spread\nof enterovirus recorded so far in Mongolia and since the 1st case in 8 May\n2008, it has affected 90 per cent of all territories within Mongolia. Next\nto Ulaanbaatar, the most affected areas are in the Eastern region\n(Sukhbaatar, Khentii, Dornod provinces), the Orkhon-Selenge region (Selenge\nprovince), the Gobi or Southern region (Dornogobi province), and the\nKhangai region (Uvurhangai province).\n\nAs Naadam, Mongolia's most popular festival [comprising outdoor events such\nas equestrianism, wrestling, archery, et alia] approaches, the authorities\nfear that it may bring another spike in the epidemic of HFMD, and are thus\nconducting activities to increase the communities' outbreak control and\npreparedness. While schools and kindergartens resumed their normal\noperations in most places, the youth summer camps have been suspended until\nmid-July [2008].\n\nConcurrent with this major outbreak, many of the affected provinces are\ncoping with the devastating consequences of the snow fall disaster that\nstruck most of Mongolia in early May [2008] in which 52 people died and 150\n000 livestock animals perished. In Taiwan, only cases of enterovirus infection\nwith severe complications are required to be reported. We estimate\nfrom sentinel surveillance data and national health insurance\ndatabase that there are at least 200 000 children in Taiwan infected\nwith enterovirus this year [2008]. Thus, there may be no significant\ndifference in mortality rate between Singapore and Taiwan.\n\nAs of Mon 7 Jul 2008, a total of 311 laboratory-confirmed enterovirus\ninfection with severe complications (including 10 deaths) among\ninfants and young children have been reported in Taiwan this year,\nreflecting a sharp increase over the same period since 1998. Of the\n311 cases confirmed so far this year, 291 (93.5 percent) were tested\npositive for enterovirus 71 (EV71), which can cause severe\ncomplications or even deaths. The predominant genogroup is B5. The\nmajority of the cases (270 cases) have been discharged, while 31\ncases are still hospitalized (21 in intensive care).\n\nThe currently ongoing epidemic started in week 11, peaked in week 25\nand is subsiding gradually. To enhance control of the epidemic,\nTaiwan has activated its Central Epidemics Command Center for\nEnterovirus to coordinate control measures at various levels of the\ngovernments, and to enhance cases surveillance and transferring since\n10 Jun 2008 (week 24).\n\nThe surveillance systems for enterovirus infections we adopted in\nTaiwan include 4 parts:\na. National Notifiable Disease Surveillance: only the suspected\ncases with severe complications are mandatory to be reported to\nTaiwan CDC. ( This is where the case number shown in news media derived from. )\nb. Sentinel Surveillance: any outpatient visits with hand, foot,\nand mouth disease or herpangina will be counted for the calculation\nof the consultation rate per week. There are around 600 clinics\nconsisting of this sentinel surveillance system. This system is\nuseful for tracking the trend of the epidemic.\nc. Real-time Outbreak and Disease Surveillance (RODS): this is a\nsyndromic surveillance system collecting ICD-9 data from over 150\nmajor emergency departments automatically. We use specific ICD-9 code\nsets to represent enterovirus infections. This system can help us to\ntrack the trend of the epidemic in real time.\nd. Laboratory Surveillance: there are 13 contract laboratories\ncollecting samples from parts of the sentinel surveillance practices\nand the 13 participating medical centers. This system helps us to\nknow the circulating genotypes of the enterovirus infection.\n\nFor latest information regarding 2008 Taiwan enterovirus epidemic,\nplease check the following websites:\n\n'Weekly Report of Enterovirus Infection'\n<http://www.cdc.gov.tw/lp.asp?CtNode=2054&CtUnit=1123&BaseDSD=7&mp=5>\n\n'Enterovirus infection with severe complications' (in Traditional Chinese)\n<http://nidss.cdc.gov.tw/singledisease.aspx?pt=s&dc=1&dt=3&disease=0749>\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nJen-Hsiang Chuang, M.D. Ph.D.\nDirector, National Health Command Center\nTaiwan Centers for Disease Control\n<ihrfocalpoint@cdc.gov.tw>\n\n[ProMED-mail appreciates this clarification of an apparent\ndiscrepancy between the hand, foot and mouth disease mortality data\nfrom Singapore and Taiwan. The number of cases reported everyday dropped from a peak of\n1160 on 1 May to 153 on 21 May [2008], and no further deaths had\noccurred over the past 12 days, the department said in a circular. Asia (19): CDC notice", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=92605", "date": "2008-07-04 17:00:25", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT AND MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA (19): CDC NOTICE\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 3 Jul 2008\nSource: US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), outbreak\nnotice [edited]\n<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/contentHandFootMouthAsia.aspx>\n\n\nOutbreak notice: hand-foot-mouth disease in Asia\n------------------------------------------------\nSince March 2008, a growing number of cases of hand-foot-mouth\ndisease (HFMD) have been reported in parts of Asia, mainly affecting\nchildren. HFMD is common among infants and children. It is very\ncontagious and is spread through direct contact with the nose and\nthroat secretions, saliva, blister fluid, or stool of an infected\nperson. A large number of cases in the current outbreaks of HFMD in\nAsia are reportedly caused by enterovirus 71 (EV71). However, other\nstrains of enterovirus can also cause HFMD.\n\nIn addition to the countries listed below, other countries in the\nWestern Pacific have also increased surveillance for HFMD. [The\navailable statistics as of Thu 3 Jul 2008 are listed below]\n\nChina\n-----\nOn 16 Jun 2008, the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention\n(China CDC) posted a notice confirming that the HFMD outbreak peaked\non 14 May 2008, and is now in decline. According to Ministry of\nHealth spokesman Mao Qun'an, although over 176 000 cases were\nreported last month [June 2008], the number of daily reported cases\ndecreased from 11 501 during the outbreak's peak to 3922 by 5 Jun\n2008.\n\nThe provinces which have been most affected by this outbreak are\nGuangdong, Zhejiang, Hebei, Shandong, and Hunan. A joint report from\nChina CDC and the Office of the World Health Organization (WHO) in\nChina, released 19 May 2008, states that cases have also occurred in\nother provinces, including Anhui, Hebei, Hubei, Henan, Jiangsu,\nJiangxi, Shaanxi, Sichuan, and Yunnan, and in the municipalities of\nBeijing and Chongqing. As of 16 Jun 2008, over 370 cases have also\nbeen reported in Macau SAR, according to China CDC.\n\nOf the HFMD cases reported in China, most were in children 5 years of\nage and younger, and of those tested in laboratories, the majority\nwere caused by EV71.\n\nThe Chinese government has enhanced its surveillance, prevention, and\ncontrol activities, including implementing a public awareness\ncampaign and monitoring water quality.\n\nChina (Hong Kong SAR)\n---------------------\nAs of 2 Jul 2008, a total of 100 cases of HFMD have been reported in\nHong Kong, with 66 (66 percent) of the cases caused by EV71.\n\nSingapore\n---------\nAs of 2 Jul 2008, the Ministry of Health in Singapore has reported a\ntotal of 15 776 cases. Since the end of May [2008] the number of\ncases reported each week has been decreasing. Of these, none had\nserious complications and none were fatal. As of 3 Jun 2008, 32\npercent of cases tested this year in the Ministry's sentinel\nsurveillance system were positive for EV71. The Ministry is working\nclosely with preschools and child-care centers to help limit the\nspread of HFMD and stresses the importance of good personal and\nenvironmental hygiene, especially for children.\n\nTaiwan\n------\nOn 30 Jun 2008, the Central News Agency reported that the Taiwan\nCenters for Disease Control (Taiwan CDC) had confirmed a total of 272\ncases this year [2008], including 9 deaths. Due to the decreasing\nnumbers of cases reported each week, Taiwan CDC is reporting that the\noutbreak is waning. The importance of good hygiene and prompt medical\nattention for children showing severe symptoms has been encouraged.\n\nPrevention measures for travelers\n---------------------------------\nNo vaccine is available to prevent HFMD. There is no specific\ntreatment for people who are sick with this disease other than\ntreating symptoms, such as fever.\n\nTravelers can take steps to prevent getting HFMD by practicing good\npersonal hygiene and following safe food and water practices. If you\nare traveling in general, and especially to areas where HFMD has been\nreported, follow these tips to help make healthy choices:\n\n- Wash your hands frequently with soap and water for 20 seconds,\nespecially before you eat, after you cough or sneeze, and after you\ngo to the toilet. If soap and water are not available, use an\nalcohol-based hand gel (with at least 60 percent alcohol). Consider\npacking alcohol-based hand gel in your luggage to ensure you have it\nwhen needed.\n- Eat foods that are fully cooked and served hot.\n- Drink beverages that have been properly bottled and sealed (water,\ncarbonated drinks, or sports drinks).\n- Do not put ice in drinks.\n- Eat only fruits and vegetables that you can wash (with boiled or\nbottled water) and peel yourself.\n- Do not share eating utensils, such as forks, spoons, and cups.\n\nAdults should help child travelers to follow these recommendations.\nInfants, children, and adolescents are more susceptible to infection\nand illness because they are less likely than adults to have cells\nthat fight infection from previous exposures to the enteroviruses\nthat cause HFMD.\n\nInfection results in immunity to the specific virus that caused HFMD.\nA 2nd episode of HFMD may occur following infection with a different\nmember of the enterovirus group.\n\nAdditional information\n----------------------\nHFMD is an illness caused by certain strains of enterovirus,\nincluding EV71, which are common worldwide. Outbreaks of HFMD caused\nby EV71 are not uncommon and have been reported by countries\nthroughout the Asia-Pacific region in recent years. EV71 can be\nspread from person to person by direct contact with nose and throat\nsecretions (such as, by coughing or sneezing), saliva, fluid from\nblisters, or the stool of infected persons. People sick with HFMD\noften experience symptoms such as fever, sores in the mouth, and a\nrash, occasionally with blisters. HFMD caused by EV71 may sometimes\nlead to serious complications, including swelling of the brain\n(encephalitis). Most cases of HFMD occur in children under 10 years\nof age, but adults can also become infected.\n\nFor more information, see\n- Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (CDC Fact Sheet, available at\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/hfhf.htm>.)\n- Traveling with Children: Resources (CDC Travelers' Health website at\n<http://wwwn.cdc.gov/travel/contentChildTravel.aspx>.)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[There are some remarkable differences in mortality that require\nexplanation; for example, 15 776 cases and no fatalities in Singapore\nand by contrast 272 cases and 9 deaths in Taiwan. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 3 Jul 2008\n According to Ministry of\nHealth spokesman Mao Qun'an, although over 176 000 cases were\nreported last month [June 2008], the number of daily reported cases\ndecreased from 11 501 during the outbreak's peak to 3922 by 5 Jun\n2008. Deng Xiaohong, spokeswoman of the Beijing Health Bureau, said the\nchild, a 13 month old boy from northern Changping District, had died on the\nway to a hospital last Sunday [11 May 2008]. She said the child had tested\npositive for enterovirus 71 (EV71), a virus that causes the majority of\nHFMD deaths in China.\n\nThe spokeswoman also confirmed that another child from north China's Hebei\nProvince had died of HFMD in a Beijing hospital, but she did not reveal\nwhen the child died. 'Under the disease counting regulations of the\nMinistry of Health, the child from Hebei was not counted in Beijing's\ndisease toll,' said Deng Hebei Province, which neighbors Beijing, had not\npreviously reported any child death from HFMD.\n\nBeijing counting of HFMD infection ran up to 3606 as of 12 May 2008, up\nfrom 1492 cases reported on May 4. The health bureau did not update the\nfigure by Wednesday morning. Deng said that Beijing's Chaoyang District has\nso far the city's largest number of infections, followed by southern\nFengtai and northern Changping districts. The bureau's figures showed that\nas of Wednesday, a total of 70 children remained in Beijing's hospitals for\nthe epidemic treatment. Among them, 55 were locals and 15 were from elsewhere.\n\nThe spokeswoman said the child deaths should not be seen as a signal for\nthe worsening disease control situation in the national capital. 'Both\ndeaths should be attributed to the delay in getting hospital treatment by\nthe children's families. We again urged parents to send their children to\nstandard hospitals immediately after they find children to have likely\nsymptoms related to the disease,' said Deng.\n\nMany of Beijing residents are reluctant to send their children to\nhospitals, which have also enrolled HFMD patients from other parts of the\ncountry, said a doctor in Ditan Hospital, the largest hospital specialized\nin contagious diseases in China. 'Some parents refused to heed doctors'\nadvice to leave their children in hospital. They complained that we have\nalso taken in patients from outside Beijing, for example from Fuyang City,\nwhere the disease first broke out,' said Cai Gaochang, a doctor with the\ninformation department of the hospital. The national capital has the best\nhospitals and doctors in the country. Patients from around the country opt\nfor Beijing for treating complicated diseases.\n\nBeijing's health authority has reinforced the viral epidemic control effort\nin kindergartens. The Caoqiao Kindergarten in Fengtai District was ordered\nto suspend classes this week for a thorough disinfection, after 2 children\nwere found to be infected with the virus. A teacher said that more than 200\nchildren in the kindergarten have gone through disease prevention checks to\nexclude the possibility of HFMD infection. At least 2 Beijing kindergartens\nwere suspended last week after children showed symptoms of the disease.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail (promed@promedmail.org)\n\n[These 2 cases can be presumed to increase the total number of deaths in\nthe outbreak in China to 36. If the disease develops, it can\nlead to death.\n\nMeanwhile, 3 cases of enterovirus cases previously confirmed as EV71\ninfections were excluded from the list after further diagnoses, and none of\nthe local enterovirus cases was serious so far, according to the statement.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<romed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of China can be used to locate\nthe Macao SAR: <http://healthmap.org/promed?v=36.5,103.9,4>. - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[2] Mongolia\nDate: Thu 15 May 2008\nSource: UB Post online [edited]\n<http://ubpost.mongolnews.mn/index.php?\noption=com_content&task=view&id=1813&Itemid=36>\n\n\nHundreds of children infected in disease outbreak\n-------------------------------------------------\nThe government has confirmed that over 450 children throughout Mongolia\nhave been diagnosed as having the potentially deadly hand, foot and mouth\ndisease (HFMD), in a rampant outbreak of the highly contagious disease. The\ndisease, confirmed as being in at least 5 provinces as well as the capital\ncity, is testing the government's emergency capabilities and forcing the\nclosure of schools and some businesses.\n\nThe 1st case of the disease was reported last Thursday [8 May 2008] in\nUlaanbaatar, with numbers increasing dramatically each day. Only 10 of the\n21 aimags [provinces] have been able to confirm they do not have any cases\nof the disease. While the disease is quite common and can be contained,\nauthorities are concerned it could lead to deaths like in China, where 42\nchildren have died and nearly 25 000 people have been infected.\n\nAs a result, the government has taken precautionary measures that included\nquarantining elementary schools for an indefinite period from Monday [12\nMay 2008], closing some businesses frequented by children and cancelling\nseveral public events. While children are overwhelmingly those infected,\nsome adults have been diagnosed with HFMD since the start of the week.\n\nAs well as Ulaanbaatar, the disease is confirmed in Orkhon Dundgobi,\nMandalgobi, Sukhbaatar, Khentii and Bulgan aimags [provinces]. Hospitals in\nseveral other aimags have reported having patients with symptoms of HFMD,\nalthough the disease has not yet been verified.\n\nThe 1st case was reported on Thursday [8 May 2008] in Ulaanbaatar. Since\nthen the General Authority for Emergency Management (GAEM) has seen a rapid\nescalation. Deputy prime minister M Enkhbold is heading an emergency\ncommittee to take measures to prevent the spread of the epidemic, which\nyesterday agreed to a proposal for Tugrug 305 million in response aid\n[about USD 262 000].\n\n'74 per cent of the affected children are aged 4 years old,' Enkhbold said.\n'The National Emergency Management Agency held meetings last weekend and\nmade some decisions and have established some procedures. 'In order to\nfollow these, the Government of Mongolia budgeted Tugrug 57.7 [USD 0.05. Is\nthis per person or in millions? - Mod.SH] to the training, advertising,\nmedicine and appropriate cleaning equipment which is useful for prevention\nfrom this disease.' The advertising budget the government has allocated\nwill be on television and radio soon and will educate the public on the\ndangers of the disease.\n\nNo one has been killed by the disease to date, and at least 29 children\nhave fully recovered. While hundreds of the suspected patients have been\nhospitalized, many others with lighter symptoms have been quarantined at home.\n\nOfficials said the 250 beds it had dedicated to HFMD in the National Center\nfor Studies of Infectious Diseases are full. An overwhelming number of\ninfected patients will recover from the disease within a few weeks. Some of\nthe businesses the government deemed as having a high-exposure risk\nincluded small kiosks, some grocery stores, fitness centers and computer\ngaming centers. It is generally expected these businesses will not be\ncompensated for having to close.\n\n[byline: Stephen Tucker]\n\n[A map of the provinces of Mongolia is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/mongolia/mongolia-political-map.html>. - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[3] Viet Nam\nDate: Thu 15 May 2008\nSource: VietNamNet Bridge online [edited]\n<http://english.vietnamnet.vn/social/2008/05/783227/>\n\n\nDeath toll by hand, foot & mouth disease doubles [that of] petechial fever\n--------------------------------------------------------------------------\nSouthern Viet Nam has 500 hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) patients\nhospitalised. According to the HCM City Pasteur Institute, the region has\nrecorded 10 deaths by the disease so far this year [2008], nearly 2 times\nmore than the number claimed by petechial fever.\n\nDr Luong Chan Quang of the HCM City Pasteur Institute warned that it is\ndifficult to diagnose HFMD in children because not all patients have\ntypical symptoms -- water spots on their bodies. Patients who experience\nmental complications or encephalitis may suffer after-effects though they\n[recover].\n\nQuang said that 7 of the 10 deaths from HFMD in the south were in HCM City.\nThe doctor said that this epidemic boomed in HCM City for the first time in\n2003, returned to the city for the 2nd time in 2006 and broke out again in\nlate 2007. Most southern provinces don't have supervising systems for this\nepidemic. So far this year, only 7 of 20 southern provinces have released\nreports on HFMD: Ben Tre with 215 patients, Can To 124, Dong Nai 197, Dong\nThap 322, Kien Giang 261, HCM City 1018 and Vinh Long 220.\n\nThe HCM City Pasteur Institute set up a network to supervise the disease\nearly this year. According to reports from 3 big hospitals in HCM City\nChildren's Hospitals 1 and 2 and the Tropical Disease Hospital the total\nnumber of HFMD patients in 2007 was 2988, 30 per cent more than in 2006.\nThe local Department of Health said that 16 died from the disease in 2007\nand only 3 in 2006. By 8 May 2008, the city had 755 children with HFMD.\n\nThe disease mainly attacks children under 3 years old and it is transmitted\nthrough saliva, mucus, and excrement. Epidemiologists say the disease\ndevelops into an epidemic because of poor environmental hygiene in the\nrainy season. The disease is often caused by Coxsackievirus A16 and\nEnterovirus 71. The latter can cause serious mental complications and death.\n\n[byline: Huong Cat]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[A map of the provinces of Viet Nam can be accessed at\n<http://www.angelfire.com/co/hongnam/vnmap.html>.\n\nThe Asian HFDV outbreak shows no signs of abating, but the overall\nmortality remains low, apart from the city of Fuyang in Anhui province of\nChina. DS, edited]\n<http://finance.sina.com.cn/roll/20080506/01022197226.shtml>\n\n\nBeijing Identifies 15 Cases of EV71\n-----------------------------------\nYesterday [Mon 5 May 2008], Beijing Centers for Disease Control and\nPrevention reported the latest situation of Hand, Foot& Mouth Disease\n(HFMD). Up to Sun 4 May 2008], a total of 1482 cases of HFMD had\noccurred since the beginning of the year. There were no reports of\nfatalities. Routine tests were carried out on 57 sporadic cases of\nHFMD between April 30 and May 4 and among these 15 cases were\nidentified as enterovirus 71 (EV71).\n\n(By: Deng Lin)\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n\nA map of the provinces of China is available at\n<http://www.chinamapxl.com/political-map.html>. The provinces of\nAnhui, Hubei and Zhejiang have common borders. - Mod.CP].\n\n******\n[2] China - provinces\nDate: Mon 5 May 2008\nSource: Breitbadt.com, Associated Press report [edited]\n<http://www.breitbart.com/article.php?id=D90FDI2G1&show_article=1>\n\n\nA viral outbreak in China has sickened more than 6300 people and\nkilled another child, raising the death toll to 26 children,\nauthorities said Monday [5 May 2008].\n\nThe latest fatality from enterovirus 71 (EV71) was in coastal\nZhejiang province, the provincial Health Ministry said. It said 1198\nother children have been stricken in the province with the virus. It\nappealed for any sick children 'to be sent immediately to health\nclinics' and for the cases to be reported 'immediately to health and\neducation departments.'\n\nAn additional 5151 cases have been reported in neighboring Anhui\nprovince, where 22 children have died, according to the official\nXinhua News Agency. Most of the cases were near Fuyang, a\nfast-growing city in the central province's rural heartland.\n\nXinhua also reported 3 deaths in the southern province of Guangdong.\n\nEnterovirus 71 causes a severe form of hand, foot and mouth disease,\nwith symptoms including fever, mouth sores and rashes with blisters.\nIt is easily spread by sneezing or coughing. The virus mainly strikes\nchildren aged 10 or younger. Some cases lead to paralysis and fatal\nswelling of the brain.\n\nThe illness is not related to foot and mouth disease, which afflicts\nlivestock. There is no vaccine or specific treatment, but most\nchildren affected by mild forms of the disease typically recover\nquickly without problems. The World Health Organization says the\nvirus [infection] normally peaks in June and July, so there could\nstill be an increase in infections as the weather warms.\n\nThe outbreak is another headache for China's Communist government as\nit prepares to host this summer's [2008] Olympic Games, already\ntarnished by unrest among Tibetans in western China and an\ninternational torch relay disrupted by protests. WHO's China\nrepresentative, Hans Troedsson, said the disease was not a threat to\nthe Beijing Olympics because the disease mostly sickens young\nchildren.\n\nChina's Health Ministry has sent teams to Anhui to coordinate\ntreatment of the disease and prevent its spread. State-run television\nshowed workers spraying disinfectant around houses in rural areas\noutside Fuyang and medical teams visiting families with small\nchildren.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n& Corr. The figure stood at 15 799 on Monday [5 May 2008], Xinhua found.\n\nThe rising number was not a sign of a deteriorating situation but\nmainly due to a recent order by the Ministry of Health that made HFMD\na class C epidemic, the incidence of which must be reported.\n\nThe northern Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region reported 131 sporadic\ninfections, according to Wang Wenrui, an official with the region's\ndisease control and prevention center. There are currently 1391 cases receiving medical\ncare in hospital, with no additional deaths for 5 consecutive days.\n\nHFMD became a notifiable disease in China on 2 May [2008]. Because of\nthis change in reporting policy and the increased awareness of the\ngeneral public about the disease, it is expected there will be an\nincrease in the number of reported cases in the next weeks and months\nfrom Anhui province and the rest of China.\n\nThe Government of China has assured WHO of its strong technical and\npolitical commitment to control the disease in Anhui and other\nprovinces. In addition to enhanced surveillance, as there is no\nspecific treatment for enterovirus infections and a vaccine is not\ncurrently available, a nation-wide health campaign is ongoing,\nstressing the need for personal hygiene, especially hand washing.\nAdditional resources have also been provided to paediatric health\ncare providers by the Ministry of Health.\n\nHFMD is a common and usually mild childhood disease. EV71 is a\nfrequent cause of HFMD epidemics associated with neurological disease\nin a small proportion of cases. There have been a number of outbreaks\nof EV71 HFMD in the Asia-Pacific region since 1997. Outbreaks have\nbeen reported in Malaysia (1997), Taiwan , China (1998), Australia\n(1999) and Singapore (2000) among other areas in the region.\n\nWHO advises against the application of any travel or trade\nrestrictions relating to China while reinforcing the need for\nprevention through enhanced personal hygiene.\n\n--\nCommunicated by ProMED-mail rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[The increased number of reported cases is not a sign of a\ndeteriorating situation, but is mainly due to a recent order by the\nMinistry of Health that made HFMD a class C epidemic, the incidence\nof which must be reported. The 20 deaths are in\nFuyang city in Anhui Province, China.\n\nAll fatal cases died of serious complications such as neurogenic\npulmonary edema due to EV-71 infection. The overall case fatality\nrate has decreased from 11 percent during 10-31 Mar 2008 to 0.2\npercent during 17-29 Apr 2008. The number of hospitalised cases has\ngradually increased since the end of March 2008 with a sharp increase\nin the number of cases since 19 Apr 2008.\n\nPublic health experts predict that the number of cases will continue\nto increase and will peak around June-July 2008. Retrospective case\ninvestigation has revealed that sporadic cases had occurred since the\nbeginning of March [2008]. Cases have been reported from all over\nFuyang city.\n\nTesting for a variety of respiratory diseases of the initial cases\ndid not reveal any conclusive results. Subsequently, additional\ntesting and several expert consultations were conducted at the\nnational level. On 23 Apr 2008, EV-71 was confirmed. Health\nauthorities informed WHO and Hong Kong SAR Department of Health and\nthe Province of Taiwan's Department of Health immediately on these\nresults.\n\nChinese health authorities have put in place targeted prevention and\ncontrol measures in Fuyang city and Anhui Province, including\nenhanced surveillance, training of health care workers at all levels\nin treatment, prevention and control, strengthening of environmental\nhealth management, and the supervision and monitoring of drinking\nwater quality. A public awareness campaign is ongoing, stressing the\nneed for good personal hygiene, mostly by hand washing.\n\nNon-polio enteroviruses are common and distributed worldwide.\nAlthough infection often has no symptoms and goes unnoticed, these\nviruses are also associated with occasional outbreaks in which a\nlarger-than-usual number of patients develop clinical disease,\nsometimes with fatal consequences. No specific anti-viral therapy is\navailable, and treatment focuses on prevention of complications. As\nthere is no vaccine for this virus, control measures during outbreaks\nare focused on classical hygiene measures including frequent hand\nwashing and disinfection of soiled clothing and surfaces. In certain\nsituations, it may be advisable to close child-care facilities and\nschools to reduce the intensity of transmission. It is not necessary\nto restrict travel or trade.\n\nCurrently, many countries in the Western Pacific region have\nimplemented heightened surveillance for hand, foot and mouth disease\nand for severe complications in children.\n\nFor more information, see the WHO fact sheet 'Enteroviruses - non polio.'\n\n--\nCommunicated by\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Marianne Hopp\n\n[Since the previous report on 29 Apr 2008 (see: Hand, foot & mouth\ndisease - China (02): (Anhui) 20080429.1481), the number of cases has\nrisen from 'some 1200' to 1884, with the number of deaths remaining\n20.\n\nA map of the provinces of China showing the location of Anhui\nprovince is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/china-political-map.html>,\nand a map of Anhui province showing the location of the city of\nFuyang in the northwest of the province is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/provinces/anhui/map-of-anhui.html>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "\n\nChinese health authorities have put in place targeted prevention and\ncontrol measures in Fuyang city and Anhui Province, including\nenhanced surveillance, training of health care workers at all levels\nin treatment, prevention and control, strengthening of environmental\nhealth management, and the supervision and monitoring of drinking\nwater quality. \n\nA map of the provinces of China showing the location of Anhui\nprovince is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/china-political-map.html>,\nand a map of Anhui province showing the location of the city of\nFuyang in the northwest of the province is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/provinces/anhui/map-of-anhui.html>. The outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) has\nkilled 20 children in Fuyang, a city in eastern Anhui province, and\nhas affected some 1200 children altogether, according to the Anhui\nprovincial health department. Of those cases, 341 children are still\nin the hospital. A report by the state-run Xinhua news agency late\nSunday [27 Apr 2008] evening said the outbreak began in early March\nand cited the city's health department as confirming that the disease\nwas caused by enterovirus-71, one of several viruses that can cause HFMD.\n\nThe disease is common among children and infants, who can develop a\nfever, rash and sores in the mouth once infected. But the disease --\ncompletely unrelated to foot-and-mouth disease, which affects cattle,\npigs, and sheep -- rarely kills people. Most HFMD patients recover\nwithin a week or so. Clusters of fatal cases occasionally emerge and\nwere reported in Malaysia in 1997 and Taiwan in 1998, according to\nthe Web site of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention in Atlanta.\n\nEven though the family of viruses that caused the Chinese outbreak is\nfound around the world, and the particular strain involved has been\nreported in China in recent years, 'we believe the situation is still\nof concern, especially because of the current high reported case\nfatality rate compared to previous years,' Cris Tunon, an official\nwith the World Health Organization in Beijing, said in a statement.\n\nChina's Health Minister Chen Zhu visited Fuyang on Saturday [26 Apr\n2008], according to the Xinhua report. Chinese health officials at\nthe local level in the past have sometimes played down disease\noutbreaks early on, only to be caught off guard later. After families\n[arrived at] hospitals with their sick children, rumors began\ncirculating in Fuyang.\n\n'Because there is no information about the strange disease from the\nofficials, rumors from the street are becoming unrestrained,'\naccording to a story in the Democracy and Law Times, a Beijing-based\nnewspaper. 'Some people are calling this disease 'Baby SARS.''\n\nFeng Lizhong, deputy director of Anhui Provincial Health Department,\nsaid that when the outbreak started in March [2008], it was unclear\nwhat the disease was, so they reported the cases to higher-level\nhealth officials. Eventually, health officials arrived in Fuyang and\ninvestigated for about 10 days, Mr. Feng says, and sent virus samples\nto Beijing for analysis.\n\nEver since the outbreak of severe acute respiratory syndrome, or\nSARS, swept across China and eventually claimed nearly 800 lives\nworld-wide in 2002 and 2003, international health officials have long\nfeared that slow reporting about a disease outbreak on the Chinese\nmainland could thwart any effort to respond and contain the outbreak.\n\nHong Kong's Center for Health Protection issued a news release on 24\nApr 2008 detailing a single case of a 7-year-old boy from the\nmainland who was diagnosed with HFMD 3 days after he was admitted to\na Hong Kong hospital.\n\n[Byline: Nicholas Zamiska]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n\n[Since a previous report dated 27 Apr 2008 (see: Hand, foot & mouth\ndisease - China (Anhui), Singapore 20080429.1472), the number of\nfatalities has increased from 19 to 20 and the number of cases from\n'over 700' to 'some 1200.'\n\nA map of the provinces of China showing the location of Anhui\nprovince is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/china-political-map.html>, and a\nmap of Anhui province showing the location of the city of Fuyang in\nthe northwest of the province is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/provinces/anhui/map-of-anhui.html>. - All were below the age of 6, with the majority being under\n2. Altogether [at least] 25 children have died of the disease. Tests\nhave confirmed 24 of the deaths were triggered by the virus known as\nenterovirus 71 (EV71).\n\nAccording to the Guidelines Regarding Prevention and Control of HFMD\npublished on the Ministry of Health website, HFMD can be caused by a\nhost of intestinal viruses, but EV71 and the coxsackievirus A16 (Cox\nA16) were the most common.\n\nAnhui Province, in east China, and Guangdong Province, south China\nwere the worst hit areas. 22 of the deaths occurred in Fuyang, a city\nin northwestern Anhui, and the rest happened in Guangdong. These 2\nregions were followed by Beijing, Jiangsu, Hunan, and Hubei,\naccording to statistics released by local health departments.\n\nIn Anhui alone, 622 new cases were reported on Saturday [3 May 2008],\nincluding 362 in Fuyang, driving up the number of children with HFMD\nto 5151 in Anhui. Beijing has recorded at least 1010 cases of the\ndisease, while Guangdong registered 925 cases as of Sunday [4 May 2008] .\n\nBoth EV71 and Cox A16 can cause HFMD, which usually starts with a\nslight fever followed by blisters and ulcers in the mouth and rashes\non the hands and feet. Those sickened by EV71 often show serious\nsymptoms. It can also lead to meningitis, encephalitis, pulmonary\nedema, and paralysis in some children. There is no vaccine.\n\nSaying reports of HFMD could increase in the next few months, the\nHealth Ministry issued a circular late last month [April 2008]\nrequiring better management and surveillance of the disease. The\nministry asked hospitals for daily reports on the disease, and for\nlocal health departments to report emergencies promptly and increase\ninvestment in research into the disease.\n\n[Byline: Sharon Lee]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2] China\nDate: Mon 5 May 2008\nSource: The Canadian Press, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://canadianpress.google.com/article/ALeqM5hJd29FRftSKGRh4eMPrFxFjKxXHw>\n\n\nChina says hand-foot-mouth disease spreading among children\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nMore than 11 900 children have been reported sick with\nhand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) in China, and at least 26 of those\ncases have died, a state news agency said. 24 of the deaths, in the\ncentral province of Anhui and Guangdong province in the south, have\nbeen blamed on enterovirus 71, one of several viruses that cause the\ndisease, the official Xinhua News Agency said Monday [5 May 2008]. 2\nother children -- one in Guangdong and another in the coastal\nprovince of Zhejiang -- have also died of hand-foot-mouth disease but\nit wasn't immediately clear which strain of virus killed them, it said.\n\nThe Xinhua News Agency said 10 212 children had been reported\ninfected in the hardest-hit areas, including the provinces of Anhui,\nGuangdong, Zhejiang, and the capital Beijing. All were below the age\nof 6 and most were under the age of 2, it said. The total number of\ninfections reported nationwide by Monday [5 May 2008] was 11 905,\nXinhua said, with smaller outbreaks in Hebei, Jiangsu, Hunan, Hubei,\nShaanxi, Jiangxi, and Henan provinces and in the city of Chongqing.\n\nAlthough nearly all the deaths have been blamed on enterovirus 71\n(EV71), it was not immediately clear how many of the overall\ninfections were traced to that virus. Zhejiang's provincial health\nbureau said on its website that only 9 of its 1198 cases had tested\npositive for EV71. Chongqing said none of its 42 infections have been\nconfirmed to be cause by EV71.\n\nXinhua said the jump in cases was due in part to a new regulation\nfrom the Ministry of Health classifying hand-foot-mouth disease among\nthose that have to be reported to the central government. The agency\nsaid a majority of the cases were reported in Anhui province, where\n5840 cases were reported, nearly all of them in the fast-growing city\nof Fuyang.\n\nEnterovirus [71] causes a severe form of hand-foot-mouth disease with\nsymptoms including fever, mouth sores, and rashes with blisters. It\nis easily spread by sneezing or coughing. The viruses mainly strike\nchildren ages 10 and younger. Some cases can lead to fatal swelling\nof the brain.\n\nThe illness is not related to foot-and-mouth disease, which afflicts\nlivestock. There is no vaccine or specific treatment, but most\nchildren affected by mild forms of the disease typically recover\nquickly without problems. The World Health Organization (WHO) says\nthe virus normally peaks in June and July so there could be an\nincrease in infections as the weather warms.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[3] China\nDate: Mon 5 May 2008\nSource: China Daily, Xinhua News Agency report [edited]\n<http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2008-05/05/content_6662259.htm>\n\n\nChinese province reports 1198 hand-foot-mouth cases\n---------------------------------------------------\nZhejiang Province in east China has recorded 1198 cases of\nhand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD), including one death, this year\n[2008], the provincial health department said on Monday [5 May 2008].\n\nA 5-year-old boy died of the epidemic triggered by the intestinal\nvirus known as EV71 in Wenzhou city on 6 Apr 2008 when medical\nefforts failed. Another 8 HFMD cases also tested positive for EV71, a\nhighly contagious virus that preys on children usually aged between 2\nand 6. The rest of the registered cases were possibly caused by Cox A\n16 [human coxsackievirus A 16] or [an echovirus], according to Lin\nJunfen, an expert with the provincial center for disease control and\nprevention.\n\nZhejiang has witnessed an increasing number of HFMD cases in recent\nyears. It reported 101 cases in 2005, 793 cases in 2006, and 1607\ncases in 2007, said Zhao Feng, an official with the health\ndepartment. A medical emergency reporting mechanism has been\nestablished in the province to closely track suspected cases, and\nlocal authorities have been reminding people of paying more attention\nto sanitation.\n\nAltogether 26 children have died of the disease across the nation,\nwith 22 registered in Anhui Province and 3 in Guangdong Province.\nTests have confirmed 25 of the deaths were triggered by EV71.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[4] Taiwan\nDate: Tue 6 May 2008\nSource: The China Post [edited]\n<http://www.chinapost.com.tw/taiwan/national/national%20news/2008/05/06/155077/CDC-reports.htm>\n\n\nCDC reports 2nd death from enterovirus\n--------------------------------------\nPublic health officials reported the death of a 3-year-old boy in\nsouthern Kaohsiung yesterday [5 May 2008]; the 2nd fatal enterovirus\ncase this year. They urged all parents and schoolteachers to be more\nvigilant against enterovirus [infection], as temperatures in Taiwan\ncontinue to rise into the summer months. Chou Jih-haw, deputy\ndirector of the Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department\nof Health (DOH), said that the latest victim was a boy aged 3 years\nand 4 months who had probably been infected by his 5-year-old sister.\n\nOn 11 Apr 2008, the boy developed a fever, with rashes and sores in\nhis mouth, and he was checked into the hospital with spasms the\nfollowing day [12 Apr 2008], Chou said. The boy lapsed into a coma\nshortly after he was admitted, and died 5 days later despite efforts\nto save him, Chou said. An investigation found that the boy's sister\nalso had an enterovirus infection, and had been admitted to the\nhospital on 13 Apr 2008. But she fully recovered because her case was\nnot that serious.\n\n'Children under 3 years old are most vulnerable to the disease\nbecause they have no antibodies, making them a high risk group in\nserious cases of enterovirus, especially in cross infection\nsituations,' Chou said. The 1st enterovirus death occurred in March\n[2008] in Yunlin County, southwestern Taiwan, the CDC reported.\n\nHealth officials at the CDC said that the number of confirmed serious\ncases of enterovirus has reached 60 this year [2008], and among them\nthere have been 2 deaths; 7 other patients remain in intensive care,\nwhile one has been hospitalized for about 4 months due to\nencephalitis complications.\n\nEnterovirus infections can be deadly for young children. The virus\nenters the body through the gastrointestinal tract and often moves on\nto attack the nervous system, leading to symptoms of fever, muscle\naches, and aseptic or viral meningitis. In a massive outbreak in\nTaiwan in 1998, 405 children were infected and 78 of them eventually\ndied. The most recent outbreak came in 2005, with 145 children\ninfected and 15 dying from the virus.\n\nDOH officials said people should maintain good personal hygiene by\nfrequently washing their hands. Parents and teachers at elementary\nschools and kindergartens should especially supervise young children\nto clean their hands in southern Taiwan during warmer weather, they\nsaid. Young children should also be kept away from places with big\ncrowds, they advised.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The HFMD outbreaks continue to spread through China with up to 12\n000 children affected and 26 fatalities reported. "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - ASIA: CHINA (HUBEI), MALAYSIA (SARAWAK)\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nIn this update:\n[1] China - Hubei province\n[2] Malaysia - Sarawak\n\n******\n[1] China - Hubei province\nDate: Fri 2 May 2008\nSource: China View, Xinhua News Agency [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-05/02/content_8091942.htm>\n\n\nHubei reports 340 cases of hand-foot-mouth disease\n--------------------------------------------------\nCentral China's Hubei Province has seen 340 cases of hand-foot-mouth\ndisease this year [2008], but no deaths reported, local health\nauthorities said on Friday [2 May 2008].\n\nAt least 5 cases were caused by an intestinal virus known as human\nenterovirus 71 (EV 71) which has left 21 children dead and 2946 ill\nin Fuyang City, in neighboring Anhui Province, since early March\n[2008].\n\nMost of the cases in Hubei were isolated, except for 39 children aged\n3 and 4 reported at 3 kindergartens in Guanghua district, Qianjiang\nCity since 29 Apr 2008, the Provincial Health Department said in a\nstatement. Experts from the provincial disease control center\ncollected and tested samples from 5 children on Thursday morning [1\nMay 2008], determining that they had been infected with EV71, it\nsaid. But no figures were provided on the total number of children in\nthe city and the province at large who have been infected with EV71.\nAccording to the statement, 33 children in Qianjiang have recovered\nor are recovering, and 6 are being treated as outpatients.\n\nNo new cases of hand-foot-mouth disease have been reported in Hubei\nsince 30 Apr 2008, it said, and local health authorities have been\nordered to make daily reports on the disease. 'Experts from the\nprovincial disease control center are still in Qianjiang to guide the\ndisease control work,' the statement said.\n\nHand-foot-mouth disease is a common childhood illness that mainly\naffects children under 10. Symptoms include fever, sores in the mouth\nand a rash with blisters. It often begins with a sore throat.\nModerately contagious, the disease, more common in summer and autumn,\ncan be transmitted through nose and throat discharges. It can\nsometimes be fatal if complications occur.\n\nChina 1st reported hand-foot-mouth disease in Shanghai in 1981. An\noutbreak of the disease in northern Tianjin in 1983 caused more than\n7000 infections. Last year in Linyi City, eastern Shandong Province,\n2 boys and a girl, all under the age of 2, died from the disease.\nEV71 can cause hand, foot and mouth disease, which usually starts\nwith a slight fever followed by blisters and ulcers in the mouth and\nrashes on hands and feet. It may also cause high fever, meningitis,\nencephalitis, pulmonary edema and paralysis in a small number of\nchildren. Infection can lead to high death rates in serious cases and\nno vaccine id available.\n\n******\n[2] Malaysia - Sarawak\nDate: Fri 2 May 2008\nSource: The Star online [edited]\n<http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2008/5/2/nation/20080502180227&sec=nation>\n\n\nPractice good hygiene to keep foot and mouth disease at bay\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nSarawak is stepping up prevention and control measures for hand foot\nand mouth disease (HFMD) following recent outbreaks in Singapore and\nChina. Deputy Chief Minister Tan Sri Dr. George Chan said the state\nhealth department's routine HFMD surveillance showed that 1729 cases\nof the disease had been reported as of April 26 this year [2008],\nincluding 3 small, localised outbreaks.\n\nThe 1st occurred at Universiti Malaysia Sarawak (Unimas) on 10-25 Mar\n2008 involving 48 adults, the 2nd in Kampung Pichin, Serian (4-22 Apr\n2008) involving 24 children and the last at Al Hidayah Abim Nursery\nin Sarikei (9-24 Apr 2008) involving 10 children. Dr. Chan said none\nof the cases involved enterovirus 71 (EV71), which potentially causes\na more severe form of the disease. 'The outbreaks were mild and no\none was hospitalised. All the outbreaks have now been controlled.\n\n'However, because of the increased number of cases in Singapore\nincluding a few with EV71, and also in Anhui, China, where there have\nbeen 20 deaths, this is a good time to warn the public, especially\nthose looking after young children, to make sure they follow hygienic\npractices,' he told a press conference at his office here on Friday\n[2 May 2008].\n\nHe said parents with young children and operators of childcare\ncentres should take preventive measures such as practising good\nhygiene at all times. He also advised childcare centre operators to\nmake sure their premises were clean and to screen children for\nsymptoms of HFMD, In addition, parents of young children should take\nthe necessary precautions, such as washing their hands before eating\nand after going to the toilet, covering their mouths and noses when\ncoughing or sneezing and ensuring cleanliness in their homes,\nincluding their children's toys.\n\nSarawak last experienced a major outbreak of HFMD in 2006, when more\nthan 14 000 cases and 13 deaths were reported.\n\n[Byline: Sharon Limg]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the WHO non-polio enteroviruses are common and\ndistributed worldwide. Although infection often has no symptoms and\ngoes unnoticed, these viruses are also associated with occasional\noutbreaks in which a larger-than-usual number of patients develop\nclinical disease, sometimes with fatal consequences. Currently human\nenterovirus 71 is associated with outbreaks of HFMD in the Chinese\nprovinces of Anhui and Hubei.\n\nSince the preceding report from Anhui dated 1 May 2008 (see: Hand,\nfoot & mouth disease - China (03): (Anhui), WHO 20080501.1504) the\nnumber of confirmed case of HFMD has increased from 1884 to 2946 and\nthe number of fatalities has risen from 20 to 21. In Anhui province\nthe outbreak is centered on the city of Fuyang, whereas a similar\noutbreak in the neighboring province of Hubei is more dispersed and\nfewer cases and no deaths have been reported so far.\n\nBy contrast a contemporaneous outbreak of HFMD in the Sarawak\nprovince of Malaysia, which does not involve human enterovirus 71,\nalthough extensive, is following a milder course.\n\nA map of the provinces of China showing the location of the adjacent\nprovinces of Anhui and Hubei is available at\n<http://www.sacu.org/provmap.html>. Children are generally\nmore affected.\n\n'The number of patients this week doubled over last week,' said\nTruong Huu Khanh, head of the department.\n\nAn increase in victims was also reported at Pediatrics Hospital\nNo 2. About 30 patients a day are being admitted.\n\nIt said cases in the 1st 3 months of this year [2008] were 7 times\nhigher than for the same period last year [2007].\n\n'These figures show that the risk of a serious epidemic is very\nhigh,' said one doctor. Most children are admitted with long lasting\nfever, nausea and vomiting. Their hands, feet and mouth are often\ncovered with pus-filled blisters.\n\n'Convulsion, waking up with a start or with glowing [sic] eyes are other\nsymptoms,' said Dr Khanh.\n\nThe disease is easily treated, but if left alone can damage the brain\nand heart. Death sometime occurs.\n\n'Children under 3 years of age can get the disease through touching\nnose fluids, spittle or touching bottles, food or toys belonging to\nthose already suffering,' said Khanh.\n\nTo prevent the disease, parents should take note of any symptoms and\ntake their children to hospital for diagnosis and treatment if they\npersist, said Khanh.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-MBDS <promed-mbds@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is the 1st outbreak of hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD)\nreported in Viet Nam in 2008. The etiological agent and detailed\nclinical manifestation of the cases are not described in the above\nnewswire. As there are no fatalities reported at present, it is\nlikely that coxsackievirus is responsible for this outbreak.\n\nAs mentioned in prior PRO/MBDS postings, HFMD can be caused by\nseveral viruses, the most frequent of which are coxsackievirus A16\nand enterovirus 71. HFMD caused by coxsackievirus A16 infection tends\nto be a mild disease, with most patients recovering within 7 to 10\ndays without medical treatment. On rare occasions, a patient with\ncoxsackievirus A16 infection may also develop a viral meningitis\nleading to a short hospitalization. Infection with enterovirus 71 may\nalso cause viral meningitis and, rarely, more serious manifestations,\nsuch as encephalitis, or a poliomyelitis-like paralytic disease. The\nencephalitis associated with enterovirus 71 infection may be fatal,\nsuch as that seen during outbreaks of HFMD in Malaysia in 1997 and in\nTaiwan in 1998.\n\nThere were 2 prior reports of outbreaks of HFMD in Ho Chi Minh city\nduring 2007. The etiological agent and detailed\nclinical manifestation of the cases are not described in the above\nnewswire.", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "enterovirus 71 infection", "hand, foot and mouth disease", "poliomyelitis"], "syndromes": ["encephalitis", "meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-04-25 00:00:00", "1997-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-03-25 00:00:00", "2008-03-25 00:00:00", "1998-03-25 00:00:00", "2007-09-25 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Viet Nam", "country": "Vietnam"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "Ho Chi Minh", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "76138", "headline": "PRO/EDR> Hand, foot & mouth disease - China (Anhui), Singapore", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=76138", "date": "2008-04-29 11:00:20", "main_text": "HAND, FOOT & MOUTH DISEASE - CHINA (ANHUI), SINGAPORE\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1] China (Anhui)\n[2] Singapore: background\n\n******\n[1] China (Anhui)\nDate: Sun 27 Apr 2008\nSource: China View, Xinhua News Agency report [edited]\n<http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-04/27/content_8061094.htm>\n\n\nA total of 19 children have died and more than 700 others fallen ill\nin an outbreak of a lethal intestinal virus in Fuyang City, east\nChina's Anhui Province, since March [2008]. 'Experts from the\nMinistry of Health, Anhui Province, and Fuyang City confirmed the\nvirus is enterovirus 71 or EV-71 based on epidemiological surveys,\nclinical diagnosis, and lab work,' said the city's health department.\n\nHospitals in Fuyang, in northwest Anhui, started to take in children\nwith fever, along with blisters, ulcers in the mouth, or rashes on\nthe hands and feet, in early March [2008]. Some of the victims were\ndiagnosed with brain, heart, and lung damage. Most of the victims\nwere aged between 2 and 6. By Saturday [26 Apr 2008], there were 789\ncases of infections, of which, 19 were fatal. A total of 204 children\nremain in hospital for further medical observation, of whom, 4 are\nsaid to be in critical condition.\n\nThe Ministry of Health sent a team in mid-April [2008], and they have\nbeen working with health workers to find the cause of the infection.\nChen Zhu, minister of health, on Saturday [26 Apr 2008] visited\nFuyang to oversee work. Fuyang has set up a leading group for control\nand prevention of the lethal virus, backed with 3 million yuan (about\nUSD 428 571) from Anhui Province and Fuyang City. Other efforts to\nstop the infection spreading include improved disease monitoring,\nmore epidemiological surveys, and lab tests. Schools, kindergartens,\nand villages are being inspected for hygiene.\n\nEnterovirus 71 can cause hand-foot-mouth disease, which usually\nstarts with a slight fever followed by blisters of ulcers in the\nmouth and on the hands and feet. It may cause high fever, meningitis,\nencephalitis, pulmonary edema and paralysis in a small number of\nchildren. Paralysis is more common in children under 2 years of age\nand meningitis is more common in children from 2-5 years of age, said\nYang Weizhong, deputy chief of Chinese Center for Disease Control and\nPrevention. Infections could lead to high mortalities in serious\ncases and neither vaccine nor therapeutic treatment is available.\n\n[Editor: An Lu]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) is a common illness of infants and\nchildren, which has tended to be more severe and to occur in more\npronounced outbreaks in South Asia. HFMD is a consequence of\ninfection by an enterovirus and is particularly associated with\ninfection by human coxsackievirus A16 (and less commonly A4, A5, A9,\nA10, B2, or B5). Human echovirus 19 was responsible for an outbreak\nof HFMD in Shandong province of China in 2003. Beginning in the 1970s\nhuman enterovirus 71 has been associated with outbreaks exhibiting\nsome neural involvement (meningitis and encephalitis). Cases of fatal\nencephalitis occurred during outbreaks of HFMD due to human\nenterovirus 71 infection in Malaysia in 1997 and in Taiwan in 1998.\n\nDespite their distinctive names, human coxsackievirus A16 and human\nenterovirus 71 are similar viruses now classified together as members\nof the same virus species _Human enterovirus A_. Human enterovirus 71\nhas been the predominant cause of HFMD in south China. The strains\nisolated from Mainland China are closely related to most isolates\nfrom Taiwan, but different from most strains isolated elsewhere. The\nsymptoms of human enterovirus 71 infection in Mainland China were not\nas severe as those described in Taiwan's outbreak. Recent molecular\ndata indicate that human enterovirus 71 and human coxsackievirus A16\nare genetically diverse rapidly evolving viruses, which may be one\nreason why HFMD outbreaks are more severe in some parts of Asia.\n\nA map of the provinces of China showing the location of Anhui\nprovince is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/china-political-map.html>, and a\nmap of Anhui province showing the location of the city of Fuyang in\nthe northwest of the province is available at\n<http://www.mapsofworld.com/china/provinces/anhui/map-of-anhui.html>. - Mod.CP]\n\n******\n[2] Singapore: background\nDate: Mon 28 Apr 2008\nSource: GIDEON (Global Infectious Disease & Epidemiology Network) [edited]\n<http://www.gideononline.com/>\n\n\nRecent outbreaks highlight the fact that Hand-foot-mouth disease\n(HFMD) is the 2nd most commonly reported viral disease in Singapore.\nIn fact, since 2001 rates of HFMD have approached those of varicella.\nSee graph at\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/HFM-Singapore.jpg>.\n\nThe following data regarding enteroviral infection in Singapore are\nextracted from Gideon\n<http://www.gideononline.com/blog/2008/04/28/enterovirus-infections-in-singapore/>.\n\nEnteroviruses are responsible for 0.2 percent of lower respiratory\ninfection in the age group 0 to 20 years (1990 to 1994).\n\nDuring 1996 to 1997, 44 percent of school children ages 5 to 12, and\n50 percent of their mothers were found to be seropositive toward\nenterovirus 71.\n- Enterovirus 71 accounted for 71 percent of enteroviral isolates in\n2000; 44.3 percent in 2001; 3.5 percent in 2002.\n\nEpidemics of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis due to enterovirus 70 were\nreported in 1971 and 1980.\n- Epidemics of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis due to coxsackie 24 were\nreported in 1975; 1985; 1992; and 2002.\n\nHFMD has been a notifiable disease in Singapore since October 2000.\n- Over 81 percent of patients with HFMD are below age 5 (1998 to 1999).\n- Enterovirus 71 was identified in all fatal cases reported during\n2000 to 2001.\n\nNotable outbreaks\n-----------------\n1970 - an outbreak of HFMD (agent not identified) was reported -- the\n1st in Singapore.\n1970 - an outbreak (60 000 cases) of acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis\nwas caused by coxsackievirus A24.\n1972 - an outbreak (104 cases) of HFMD due to coxsackievirus A16 was reported.\n1974 - an outbreak (53 cases) of 'Bornholm disease' due to coxsackie\nB3 was reported.\n1975 - an outbreak (40 000 cases) of hemorrhagic conjunctivitis due\nto coxsackie 24 was reported.\n1981 - an outbreak (742 cases) of HFMD due to coxsackievirus A16 was reported.\n1997 - an outbreak (8 cases) of echovirus 30 meningitis was reported\nin a nursery -- the 1st reports of this strain in Singapore.\n2000 - an outbreak (3790 cases) of HFMD was reported --\ncoxsackievirus and enterovirus 71 were implicated.\n2002 - an outbreak (16 228 cases) of HFMD was reported --\ncoxsackievirus A16 was implicated in 76.9 percent of cases.\n\n--\nSteve Berger\nGeographic Medicine\nTel Aviv Medical Center\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[ProMED-mail thanks Professor Berger for compiling these data. A teacher from PAP Community Foundation (PCF) Ayer Rajah\nWest -- which was added to the voluntary closure list on Thursday [24\nApr 2008] -- said attendance was good, with no absentees except for\nthose who were sick. Ms. Choy Mei Har, supervisor at Raffles\nMontessori Kindergarten (Aljunied), said there had been 'one or 2'\ncases in the nursery classes where concerned parents initially kept\ntheir children at home but have since allowed them to return to\nschool. They were a little worried, but they found that there was\nnothing to be worried about,' said Ms Choy. 'I think parents are\ndefinitely concerned, but they are also more aware about HFMD now.\nThey are careful to keep their children at home if they are sick, and\nthey also know that it's not something that can't be cured.'\n\nStill, Ms Lee Geok Moy, a 33-year-old administrator, intends to keep\nher daughter at home until the number of cases subsides. 'I think\nit's better to be on the safe side for now,' she said, adding that\nthe childcare centres she checked near her home had all reported\ncases of HFMD. Meanwhile, Care Corner Child Development Centre, which\nwas added on Thursday [24 Apr 2008] to the list of preschools advised\nto close voluntarily, clarified that only its centre at Woodlands\nCrescent was affected.\n\nAnother 78 cases of HFMD were reported as of 3:00 pm on Friday [25\nApr 2008], bringing the week's total so far to 1162.\n\n[Byline: Lin Yanqin]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 26 Apr 2009\nSource: Borneo Bulletin Weekend Online [edited]\n<http://www.brunei-online.com/weekend/news/apr26h6.htm>\n\n\nSeveral parents have expressed their concern over the Hand, Foot and\nMouth Disease (HFMD) outbreak which has been reported in Singapore,\nwhere 880 new cases were reported in 4 days. This is especially so for\nthose who travelled to the neighbouring country [Malaysia]. The DPA\n[German Press Agency] news service reported yesterday [25 Apr 2008]\nthat teachers, administrative staff and cleaners scrubbed Singapore\npreschools and childcare centres Friday [25 Apr 2008] to curb the HFMD\noutbreak. DPA added, with the latest Health Ministry of Singapore data\nshowing this year's [2008] total infections at 8400, officials are now\nproviding daily updates instead of weekly ones.\n\nAt least 16 schools have been closed because of the outbreak. Another\n9 have been urged to voluntarily shut down for 10 days. The\ndisinfection is aimed at halting the transmission of the disease,\nwhich is spread through saliva, blister fluid, feces and droplets in\nthe air. Professionals have been called to service air conditioners\nand fumigate.\n\nBrunei\n------\nSources said such HFMD cases have also occurred in Brunei but have\nbeen on the decline lately. From early to the end of August 2007,\nabout 90 HFMD cases were recorded in Brunei, the Ministry of Health\nsaid, while from early March to mid April 2006, some 580 cases were\nrecorded, the majority of which were outpatient cases.\n\n[Byline: Azlan Othman]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common illness of infants\nand children, which has tended to be more severe and to occur in more\npronounced outbreaks in South Asia. HFMD is a consequence of\ninfection by an enterovirus and is particularly associated with\ninfection by human coxsackievirus A16 (and less commonly A4, A5, A9,\nA10, B2, or B5). Beginning in the 1970s human enterovirus 71 has been\nassociated with outbreaks exhibiting some neural involvement\n(meningitis and encephalitis). Cases of fatal encephalitis occurred\nduring outbreaks of HFMD in Malaysia in 1997 and in Taiwan in 1998.\nDespite their distinctive names, human coxsackievirus A16 and human\nenterovirus 71 are similar viruses now classified together as members\nof the same virus species _Human enterovirus A_.\n\nThe almost universal sign of the disease is enanthem [rash on a mucous\nmembrane], most commonly on the buccal mucosa [inside the mouth].\nExanthema [skin rashes] soon follow, most frequently on hands and\nfeet. The internal lesions are ulcerative and on the hands and on the\nfeet usually vesicular [blisters]. The virus is present in vesicular\nfluid, pharyngeal [throat] secretions and feces. Consequently, HFMD is\na highly contagious infection but one usually with a benign outcome.\n\nLast year [2007], there were 688 cases of HFMD recorded in Singapore\nbetween 15-21 Apr 2007, a number which was 70 percent higher compared\nto the 398 cases recorded in the same period of the previous year\n[2006]. The 2007 outbreak was attributed to human coxsackievirus A16\ninfection, and, in the absence of information to the contrary, it\nmust be presumed that the same virus is responsible for the 2008\noutbreak.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap showing the location of Singapore can be\naccessed at:\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=1.4,103.8,6e>.\n- Mod.CP]\n\n[see also>\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam: HCM, RFI 20080423.1435\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan: (Pingtung) 20080220.0695\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Taiwan: (Kaohsiung) 20080109.0108\n2007\n----\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Thailand 20071123.3794\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Viet Nam (HCM city) 20070926.3193\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Malaysia (Selangor) 20070924.3171\nHand, foot & mouth disease - India (Calcutta) 20070923.3160\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Beijing) 20070713.2253\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Hong Kong) 20070530.1741\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Maldives 20070529.1719\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong)(04) 20070524.1667\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (03) 20070520.1604\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) (02) 20070516.1560\nHand, foot & mouth disease - China (Shandong) 20070514.1540\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Singapore 20070424.1338\nHand, foot & mouth disease - Sri Lanka (Colombo) 20070311.0869]\n......................................................cp/msp/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Lin Ting, deputy director-general of the Centers\nfor Disease Control under the DOH, said that the girl's parents took\nher to a Kaohsiung medical center on 4 Feb 2008 after discovering\nblisters all over her body. The child was released from hospital the\nnext day after her condition improved. However, on 6 Feb 2008, the\nchild developed a fever, symptoms of hand, foot and mouth disease\n(HFMD), as well as arm and leg spasms, Lin said. The parents brought\nthe child back to the same medical center, and the child was\nimmediately admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit. On 19 Feb\n2008, after conducting tests, the hospital reported the suspected\nenterovirus-71 case to the CDC. The child was released from the\nmedical center several days later after her condition had improved.\n\nLin said that although the latest data shows that enterovirus may be\non the wane, the data was compiled ahead of the start of school\nfollowing the extended holiday break, which he noted may be the\nreason for the decline in new enterovirus cases. Pointing out that\nenterovirus may make a resurgence when school starts again, Lin\nreminded parents and teachers to not let their guard down and to pay\nattention to students' sanitary habits as well as to make sure that\nthey wash their hands often to avoid being infected. He also urged\nparents to take their kids to a hospital immediately if they develop\na fever, HFMD symptoms, or arm and leg spasms.\n\nIn 2007, there were a total of 49 cases of confirmed enterovirus\ninfections in Taiwan, with 2 fatalities. So far this year [2008],\nthere have been 14 cases, with no fatalities, which Lin said shows\nthat citizens have become more aware of the threat of enterovirus.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The hand-foot-mouth disease (HFMD) syndrome commonly observed in\ninfants and young children can be caused by several enteric viruses.\nHuman enterovirus-71 and human coxsackievirus A16 are the most\nfrequent pathogens. Human enterovirus-71 infections, however, tend to\nhave more severe outcomes and have been associated with cases of\nacute neurologic disease including poliomyelitis-like paralysis,\nencephalitis, and aseptic meningitis. Hand-foot-mouth disease occurs\nworldwide, but causes greatest concern in Southeast Asia and the Far\nEast. It is unclear whether this is due to the prevalence of more\nvirulent enteroviruses or to lower standards of hygiene.\nHand-foot-mouth disease in children is unrelated to the\nfoot-and-mouth disease of ruminants.\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=36.5,103.9,4> shows the location of\nthe city of Pingtung at the southern tip of the island of Taiwan. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "Pointing out that\nenterovirus may make a resurgence when school starts again, Lin\nreminded parents and teachers to not let their guard down and to pay\nattention to students' sanitary habits as well as to make sure that\nthey wash their hands often to avoid being infected. A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n\n The Department of Health (DOH) confirmed yesterday [19 Feb 2008] an\nenterovirus-71 case involving a 21-month-old child in Pingtung\nCounty, bringing the total number of confirmed cases in Taiwan to 14\nfor the year [2008]. \n\nLin said that although the latest data shows that enterovirus may be\non the wane, the data was compiled ahead of the start of school\nfollowing the extended holiday break, which he noted may be the\nreason for the decline in new enterovirus cases. Lin Ting, deputy director-general of the Centers\nfor Disease Control under the DOH, said that the girl's parents took\nher to a Kaohsiung medical center on 4 Feb 2008 after discovering\nblisters all over her body. What worries him most is that the disease has broken out much\nearlier than in previous years, when it peaked in March or November.\nDr. Le Truong Giang, Deputy Director of the HCMC Health Department,\nis urging the authorities to take urgent action to contain and\neliminate hand, foot and mouth, above all by sanitizing every school\nand classroom.\nThe disease is caused [predominantly] by Coxsackie and Entero 71\nviruses [i.e. Human coxsackievirus A16 and Human enterovirus 71,\naccording to ICTV nomenclature - Mod.CP], which lurk in toys and\nfood, so parents should pay careful attention to their children's\nfood and surroundings. It is a human disease unrelated to the\nfoot-and-mouth disease affecting ruminants and other animals. HFMD is\ncharacterised by fever and vesicles in the mouth and on distal\nextremities. Complications are uncommon in most outbreaks, in\ncontrast to the current outbreak in Viet Nam. Pictures of typical\nHFMD lesions can be viewed at\n<http://www.nlm.nih.gov/medlineplus/ency/article/000965.htm>.\nHFMD is moderately contagious. Infection is spread from person to\nperson by direct contact with nose and throat discharges, saliva,\nfluid from blisters, or the stool of infected persons. A child is\nmost contagious during the 1st week of the illness. Individual cases\nand outbreaks of HFMD occur worldwide, more frequently in summer and\nearly autumn.\nA variety of enteric picornaviruses have been associated with HFMD in\nthe past, the most frequently observed being Human coxsackievirus A16\nand Human enterovirus 71. Currently, outbreaks of relatively mild\nHFMD in India and Malaysia have been reported in ProMED-mail within\nthe past few days (see references below). The figure was also 70 percent higher compared to the 398 cases\nrecorded in the same period last year [2006].\nNot only is the number of cases a record high for this year [2007],\nit has also exceeded the epidemic threshold the Health Ministry has\nset for HFMD. The last HFMD epidemic in Singapore took place in\nend-March last year [2006], when 784 cases were recorded in a week. A\ntotal of 3 child-care centres had to be closed during the outbreak.\nThe Health Ministry has been posting weekly updates of the HFMD\nsituation on its website.\nThe Ministry said the present strain is CA16 [presumably an\nabbreviation for coxsackivirus A16. - Mod.CP]. This is unlike the\nEV71 virus, which is more likely to cause complications. And although\nthe number of HFMD cases reported to Health Ministry has increased,\nthe number of cases seeking treatment or admission to hospitals has\ndropped compared to the previous week. A Health Ministry spokesperson\nadded that the Ministry has not detected the EV71 [Enterovirus 71]\ncirculating among HFMD patients.\nThe Ministries of Health and Community Development Youth and Sports\nhave sent out alert letters to child-care centres and schools with\nreported clusters of HFMD cases. This is to remind them to put in\nplace measures to curb disease transmission.\n[Byline: Teoh Song Keng and Julia Ng]\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur A-lan Banks\n[Hand, foot and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common illness of infants\nand children, which has tended to be more severe in South Asia than\nelsewhere. The disease\nis highly contagious and transmitted through saliva, air, or skin\ncontact. It can be fatal if complications occur.
