Doctors warn that the numbers of cases in other\nareas of the country too has seen a sharp increase.\nThe disease typically affects children under the age of 5, but older\nchildren and adults could occasionally be susceptible. Consultant\nDermatologist of the Lady Ridgeway Hospital, Dr. J.K. Seneviratne,\nconfirming the outbreak of the disease, said that symptoms of\ninfection include slight fever, loss of appetite, sore throat, and a\nrash of red spots which develop into small vesicles or fluid\ncontaining blisters in the mouth, diaper area and hands and feet\nincluding the palms and soles.\nThe blisters are like those caused by chicken pox but do not itch.\nThey do, however, cause pain if pressed. There is no specific\ntreatment other than pain relief. Recovery takes between one week to\n10 days. Dr. Seneviratne added that in extremely rare cases\nconvulsions and paralysis had occurred. He said these complications\nlast occurred in a 1999 epidemic, which occurred in Hong Kong. He\nstressed complications were extremely rare and said there was no need\nto panic. He said once the disease was contracted, patients became\nimmune to it.\nDr. P.H. Chandrawansa, Consultant Dermatologist of the Matara General\nHospital, confirmed a sharp increase in the number of affected\nchildren and warned that the disease spreads mainly through oral or\ndroplet transmission. He advised stringent hand cleansing and that\nyoung children avoid contact with affected patients.\n[Byline: Ayesha R. Dudley, Ph.D\n[Hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD) is a common illness of infants\nand children. It is more prevalent and more severe in the countries\nof Southeast Asia than elsewhere. It is characterized by fever, sores\nin the mouth, and a rash with blisters. HFMD begins with a mild\nfever, poor appetite, malaise ('feeling sick'), and frequently a sore\nthroat. The skin rash develops over one to 2 days with flat or raised\nred spots, some with blisters. The rash does not itch, and it is\nusually located on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. It\nmay also appear on the buttocks. The most common cause is\ncoxsackievirus A16, although sometimes HFMD is caused by enterovirus\n71 (EV71) or other enteroviruses.\nAccording to the CDC website, HFMD caused by coxsackievirus A16\ninfection is a mild disease, and nearly all patients recover without\nmedical treatment in 7 to 10 days. Complications are uncommon.\nRarely, the patient with coxsackievirus A16 infection may also\ndevelop 'aseptic' or viral meningitis, in which case the person has\nfever, headache, stiff neck, or back pain, and may need to be\nhospitalized for a few days. EV71 encephalitis may be fatal. Cases of\nfatal encephalitis occurred during outbreaks of HFMD in Malaysia in\n1997 and in Taiwan in 1998. The mortality reported in the press\nreports of the current HFMD outbreak in the city of Linyi in Shandung\nprovince (26 deaths among 292 children), if accurate, would be an\nunprecedented event. Clarification of the situation would be appropriate.\nA map of Shandong province can be viewed at\n<http://www.maps-of-china.com/shandong-s-ow.shtml>.\n- Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n JW] that commonly occurs in infants and\nchildren in the summer and autumn months,' Medical authorities in\nLinyi said the deaths were caused by an outbreak of 'hand-foot-mouth\ndisease,' which had infected up to 292 children in the city at that\ntime, the Shanghai Morning Post reported. Dr. Jane Cardosa has sent the following explanation.\nProMED-mail and the Moderator appreciate Dr. Cardosa's prompt and\ninformative response. - Mod.CP]\nMy laboratory has been investigating HFMD outbreaks in Sarawak since\nthe initial enterovirus 71 (EV71) outbreak in Sarawak in 1997, and\nour data shows that in Sarawak, EV71 outbreaks occur in a regular\ncyclical pattern every 3 years. In an outbreak year, we start seeing\ncases in early February. The outbreaks have peaked between March and\nMay. In 2000 and in 2003, we did not have many fatal cases, but in\nthis year's [2006] outbreak, we have seen more than in the previous 2\noutbreaks. All outbreaks we have documented (1997, 2000, 2003 and\n2006) have been predominantly caused by EV71 of genogroup B. Our\nsurveillance findings have recently been published in BMC Public\nHealth (see: Sentinel surveillance for human enterovirus 71 in\nSarawak, Malaysia: Lessons from the first 7 years. Podin, Y., et al.,\nBMC Public Health. 2006 Jul 7;6(1):180; Epub ahead of print at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?db=pubmed&cmd=Retrieve&dopt=AbstractPlus&list_uids=16827926&query_hl=11&itool=pubmed_docsum>.\nEarly in the year, we posted preliminary data on the likelihood of an\noutbreak occurring this year [2006], and Dr. Peter McMinn wrote to\nProMED pointing to our study website URL\n<http://www.ichr.uwa.edu.au/apnet/> in the hope that early warning\nwould encourage early public health intervention.\nSarawak is a large state on the island of Borneo, and it must be\nappreciated that public health coverage of the entire state poses\nconsiderable logistical problems, especially since many communities\nlive in remote areas. As our reporting system is rather\ncomprehensive, we get to hear of and investigate cases throughout the\nstate. As ProMED-mail has reported, we have seen a resurgence of HFMD\ncases in the period after epidemiological week 20, and our\nvirological investigations confirm that these cases are predominantly\ndue to EV71 still, and the virus continues to circulate in the\nnorthern part of the state, particularly in the more remote areas of\nthe interior, and these numbers contribute towards the '2nd wave'\ndescribed in the popular press. You will appreciate that what we are\nseeing is simply a shift in the geographical location of the current\nhot-spots and not a 2nd peak in areas where the outbreak has already\npeaked. You will also appreciate that our efforts to keep this\noutbreak investigation transparent also leads to difficulties with\nsensationalistic or inaccurate lay reporting, but it is important to\nkeep the community at risk informed and in doing so, enlist their\nparticipation in controlling the spread of the virus.\nI shall be happy to provide further details to anyone who may need them.\n--\nJane Cardosa\n<janecardosa@yahoo.co.uk>", "summary": "As ProMED-mail has reported, we have seen a resurgence of HFMD\ncases in the period after epidemiological week 20, and our\nvirological investigations confirm that these cases are predominantly\ndue to EV71 still, and the virus continues to circulate in the\nnorthern part of the state, particularly in the more remote areas of\nthe interior, and these numbers contribute towards the '2nd wave'\ndescribed in the popular press. Deputy Chief Minister George Chan said the\nboy died on Fri 7 Jul 2006 but described the death as an isolated case. The\nState has been battling the outbreak since February and the number of cases\nhad declined in recent months. The critically ill boy was first admitted to\na local hospital on Thu [6 Jul 2006] but died the following day despite\nbeing flown to Miri hospital.\nChan said the number of new cases had dropped to around 200 to 250 per week\nsince mid-April from between 1000 and 1300 cases per week previously. The\nillness affects mainly infants and young children, causing painful mouth\nand throat ulcers, fever and blisters on hands and feet.\nThe Health Ministry on 3 Mar 2006 ordered the closure for a few weeks of\nall 488 kindergartens and child-care centres in Sarawak, which is on the\nisland of Borneo. Sarawak has been hit periodically by the disease. In the\nworst outbreak in 1997, 31 people died.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[HFMD is a common illness of infants and children, characterized by fever,\nsores in the mouth, and a rash with blisters. It begins with a mild fever,\npoor appetite, malaise, and frequently a sore throat. One or 2 days after\nthe fever begins, painful sores develop in the mouth, usually on the\ntongue, gums, and inside of the cheeks. The skin rash develops over 1-2\ndays with flat or raised red spots, some with blisters, usually on the\npalms of the hands and soles of the feet -- hence the name.\nHFMD is usually associated with infection by human coxsackievirus A16 or\nhuman enterovirus 71 (EV-71). Occasionally cases due to infection by other\ngroup A or B B coxsackieviruses have been recorded. Coxsackievirus A16\ninfection is normally a mild disease and nearly all patients recover\nwithout medical treatment in 7 to 10 days. Complications are\nuncommon. EV-71 may also cause viral meningitis and, rarely, more serious\ndiseases, such as encephalitis, or a poliomyelitis-like paralysis. EV71\nencephalitis may be fatal. Cases of fatal EV-71-associated encephalitis\nhave occurred during outbreaks of HFMD in Malaysia and Taiwan [see\nProMED-mail references below]. A more serious case was detected in Brunei and a\n2-year-old boy died of HFMD yesterday. The case was detected in\nBrunei-Muara District. However, the public should not panic,' Dr.\nMeng Keang said.\nAsked about the last case that was detected in Brunei, Dr. Meng Keang\nsaid it occurred in February 2006, but in small numbers: 2-3 cases.\nIt is a common infection among children under 5 years old, he said.\nThe disease is caused by an enterovirus. It is a common infection but\ncomplications can cause death.\nSigns include red spots on the palm, leg surface and blisters in the\nmouth and tongue [URL for picture of hand lesions included below. -\nMod.RY]. It really hurts the tongue and those afflicted will\nexperience discomfort when swallowing food or drinking fluids.\nParent have been advised to consult a doctor if their child has any\nof the following conditions: persistent high fever, repeated vomiting\nand poor appetite, extreme tiredness and sleepiness, irritability,\nabdominal distension, urine retention, shortness of breath, fast\nheart beat or pulse (of more than 160 per minute), unsteady gait or\nlimb weakness, muscle jerks, abnormal eye movement and cold sweating.\nThe disease spreads through direct contact via patient's mucus, fluid\nfrom running nose, saliva, and liquid from blisters and stools.\nThere's no specific treatment for the disease. The treatment given is\nto decrease the intensity of the symptoms.\nThe public, especially parents and those at childcare centres, are\nadvised to take precautionary steps. Personal hygiene is most\nimportant in avoiding to contract and transmit enterovirus infection.\nThese include washing hands thoroughly before eating, after going to\nthe toilet or handling nappy/excreta, covering mouth and nose when\ncoughing or sneezing, cleaning thoroughly surfaces of toys and other\nappliances and maintaining cleanliness among children, especially\nthose under 5 years old. Infected children should stay away from\npublic places like schools and childcare centres. Parents should not\nbring their children to the affected areas.\nShould parents come across these symptoms in their children, they\nshould bring them to the nearest hospital or go to emergency wards in\nthe 4 districts after office hours.\nFor further information on the disease, the public can contact\n2242424 extension 393.\nHFMD FACTBOX\nWhat is HFMD?\nHFMD is often confused with foot-and-mouth disease among cattle,\nsheep and swine. Although the names are similar, the diseases are not\nrelated and are caused by different viruses. Viruses from the group\ncalled enteroviruses cause HFMD.\nHFMD, caused by coxsackievirus A16 infection, is a mild disease and\nnearly all patients recover without medical treatment in 7-10 days.\nComplications are uncommon.\nIs HFMD contagious?\nIt is moderately contagious. Infection spreads from person to person\nby direct contact with nose and throat discharges, saliva, fluid from\nblisters, or the stool of infected persons. A person is most\ncontagious during the first week of the illness.\nThe usual period from infection to onset of symptoms is 3-7 days.\nFever is the first symptom of HFMD.\nWho is at risk of HFMD?\nChildren under 10 years old are at risk but it may occur in adults\ntoo. Infants, children and adolescents are more likely to be\nsusceptible to infection as they are less likely than adults to have\nantibodies and be immune from previous exposures to them.\nWhat are the symptoms?\nPersistent high fever, repeated vomiting and poor appetite, extreme\ntiredness and sleepiness, irritability, abdominal distension, urine\nretention, shortness of breath, fast heart beat or pulse (of more\nthan 160 per minute), unsteady gait or limb weakness, muscle jerks,\nabnormal eye movement and cold sweating.\nHow it can be prevented?\nWashing hands thoroughly before eating, after going to the toilet or\nhandling nappy/excreta; covering mouth and nose when coughing or\nsneezing; cleaning thoroughly surfaces of toys and other appliances\nand maintaining cleanliness among children especially those aged\nunder 5 years. Infected children should stay away from public places\nlike schools and childcare centres. Parents should not bring their\nchildren to the affected areas.\n[Byline: Azlan Othman & Lyna Mohammed]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Brunei has experienced the first death out of a total of 17 cases of\nHFMD -- a rough case fatality rate of 5.9 percent. HFMD is caused by\nenteroviruses, among which coxsackievirus A16 (CA16) is the most\ncommon etiologic agent. Usually no complications of HFMD are caused\nby CA16 infection, although aseptic or viral meningitis may occur\noccasionally. A second common cause of HFMD is enterovirus 71(EV71).\nIn addition to HFMD, EV71 may also cause aseptic or viral meningitis,\nencephalitis, or a polio-like paralysis. EV71 meningitis or\nencephalitis may on rare occasions be fatal.\nCases of fatal encephalitis occurred during widespread outbreaks of\nHFMD in Bulgaria in 1975 (29 deaths), Malaysia in 1997 (29 deaths)\nand Taiwan in 1998 (78 deaths). In the 1998 epidemic several\nenteroviruses were involved. However, enterovirus 71 infection was\nassociated with most, if not all, of the serious clinical\nmanifestations and with nearly all deaths. Most of those who died\nwere younger than 5 years, and the majority died of pulmonary edema\nand pulmonary hemorrhage.\nNo effective treatments are available. General treatment is\npalliative. Preventive measures are focused on enforcement of\npersonal hygiene and public awareness campaigns.\nSince the advent of the 1998 outbreak, Department of Health (DOH) of\nTaiwan has determined the pattern of the annual seasonal HFMD\nepidemic, the peak of which tends to fall in the beginning of July.\nThe DOH schedules the reminder campaign according to this pattern.\nThe disease has been brought under control. RY], in an outbreak the health\nministry has called an epidemic.\n2 of the deaths were caused by enterovirus 71, the more virulent type\nof the group of [entero-] viruses that cause hand, foot and mouth\ndisease, the World Health Organization said today [11 Mar 2006],\nciting a Malaysian health ministry statement. All 488 kindergartens\nand 9 primary schools in Sarawak state, on the island of Borneo, are\nclosed for 2 weeks, the WHO said.\nSarawak is trying to prevent a repeat of 1997, when 31 children died\nfrom the disease, Ramlee Rahmat, director of disease control at the\nhealth ministry, said by telephone yesterday [10 Mar 2006].\nThe nation of 26 million people is speeding up efforts to contain the\ndisease, which Ramlee said had infected 3269 children in Sarawak as\nof 8 Mar 2006. The illness is\nunrelated to foot and mouth disease found among cattle, sheep, and\nswine. The state has a\npopulation of 2.18 million, according to the Sarawak government's\nwebsite.\nThe disease 'has reached epidemic levels in Sarawak because of the\nunusually sharp increase in the number of cases within such a short\nperiod of time,' Yap Soo Kian, press secretary to the health\nminister, said in an interview.\n--\nPablo Nart\n<pablo.nart@terra.es>\n******\n[2]\nDate: Sat 11 Mar 2006\nFrom: Pablo Nart <pablo.nart@terra.es>\nSource: Yahoo news, Wed 8 Mar 2006 [edited]\n<http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20060308/hl_afp/malaysiahhealthdisease_06030817261\n5>\n\nMalaysia declared that an outbreak of hand-foot-and-mouth disease in\nthe eastern state of Sarawak has escalated into an epidemic, with\nsome 200 cases being reported daily.\nHealth Minister Chua Soi Lek said the disease had reached epidemic\nproportions 'because of the increase in the number of cases in the\nbeginning of this year [2006].'\nState health officials have recorded a total of 3087 cases since 1\nJan 2006. Of these cases, 5 deaths\nin children under 4 years of age have been reported; the latest case died on\n31 May 2005. The case number and death toll of the disease from 1 Jan to 10\nJun 2005 are much higher than those within the same period of time last year\n(2004), which were 14 cases with no deaths.\nSo far, all these cases are less than 5 years of age. This year's enterovirus\nepidemic occurred predominantly in the Central Taiwan with 34 cases, followed\nby Northern Taiwan (14), Southern Taiwan (11), and Eastern Taiwan (1)\nrespectively. The epidemic curve of reported severe enterovirus infections in\nCentral Taiwan and Northern Taiwan has been gradually descending; however, it\nseems to be slightly rising in Southern Taiwan, according to our surveillance\ndata analysis.\nOf these 60 confirmed cases in 2005 so far, at least 30 cases (50 percent)\nwere associated with enterovirus 71 (EV71) infections, which were lab-\nconfirmed either by virus isolation or neutralization antibody tests. Since\n1998, Taiwan CDC has paid special attention to EV71 infections. The VP1 region\nof this virus strain would be targeted and sequenced for routine EV\nsurveillance and viral genomic study. The major outbreak of EV71 infection in\n1998 was caused mostly by subtype C EV71 (based on VP1 phylogenetic analysis,\nref: J Virol 1999, 73: 9969-9975). Almost all EV71 sequences in our lab from\n1999 to 2003 were subtype B. However, in 2004 all EV71 strains in our lab were\nsubtype C. It is still subtype C for 2005 so far.\nThe sequences are very close among the isolates either from 2004 or 2005. Even\nthough all Taiwan EV71 isolates in 1998 and 2004/2005 belong to subtype C,\nthey are somehow different based on the sequence comparison. Either subtype B\nor C will cause severe and sometimes even fatal cases in Taiwan. Rabbit anti-\nEV71 (1998, subtype C) antiserum can neutralize either subtype B or C EV71,\nincluding isolates from 2004.\n--\nDr. Ho-Sheng Wu, Ph.D.\nDirector, Surveillance Division\nCenter for Disease Control\nDepartment of Health, Taiwan\n<wuhs@cdc.gov.tw>\n[Dr. Wu's update on the current seasonal epidemic of hand, foot and mouth\ndisease (HFMD) is informative in that the Taiwan CDC has identified the\nsubtypes of EV71 that make up 50 percent of HFMD cases of the outbreak. In general, ProMED encourages transparent reporting by\nhealth authorities throughout the world, so that any outbreak of infectious\ndiseases can be closely monitored, studied, and controlled by means of group\nefforts within the global village.\nSubtype C of EV71 is responsible for the current HFMD season and those of 2004\nand 1978. Noting that enteroviruses are transmitted\nvia direct contact with secretions from an infected person or contact with\ncontaminated surfaces or objects, Hou said practicing good personal hygiene\nis critical to preventing infections.\n[Byline: Sofia Wu]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Hou Sheng-mao was quoted as saying that none of the enterovirus strains\n(isolated from the patients) have mutated significantly. Generally\nspeaking, genetic mutation of a viral genome takes place all the time. And\nit happens more readily in RNA viruses (such as EV71 in the family of\npciornaviridae) than in DNA viruses. However, in the context of the current\noutbreak, what Hou meant regarding absence of significant mutation was not\nelaborated, either by himself or by the media. What epidemiologists,\nclinicians and public health authorities are most concerned about are\npathogenicity and/or severity of the disease prior to medication and drug\nresistance of the causative agents responsible for the outbreak when\nsubjected for treatment. Since no unusual trend of the seasonal HFMD\nepidemic was noted, it could be implicated in the aspect of anti-EV71 drug\nresistance. Pyridyl imidazolidinone is a novel class of potent and\nselective human enterovirus 71 inhibitors which target enterovirus 71\ncapsid protein VP1. Site-directed mutagenesis of enterovirus 71 infectious\ncDNA revealed that a single amino acid alteration at the position 192 of\nVP1 can confer resistance to the inhibitory effects of the antiviral drug\n[see reference: Shin-Ru Shih et al. Mutation in Enterovirus 71 Capsid\nProtein VP1 Confers Resistance to the Inhibitory Effects of Pyridyl\nImidazolidinone. Antimicrobial Agents and Chemotherapy, September 2004,\nVol. 48 (9):3523-3529]. Further information from the Department of Health,\nTaiwan and colleagues familiar with HFMD and enteroviral infections are\nwelcome. - Mod.RY]\n[The above newswire mentions there are 50 cases and 5 deaths currently\nassociated with this outbreak. The Centers include 106 private and 119 government\nhealth clinics, and 109 treatment centers. The\ndisease is especially dangerous when contracted by children under the\nage of 3.\n'The next 2 weeks might be the peak of the infections,' said Wu Ping-hui, an\nofficial from the [Taiwan] Center for Disease Control. 'As the virus is\nspread by physical contact, before parents and older children touch younger\nchildren, they are advised to take showers or wash their hands when coming\nhome from the outdoors,' he said. Wu also suggested that parents avoid\nexposing their young children to public places.\nSymptoms\n--------\nThe symptoms of the disease include continuous high fever, excessive\nsleepiness, continuous vomiting, unusual inactivity, numbness in the\nlimbs, and shortness of breath, Wu said. He suggested that 'parents\nshould pay more attention to these symptoms, as they are quite\nsimilar to those of common colds and are easily disregarded.' The\nchildren with these symptoms should be taken to see a doctor quickly\nto prevent any delay in obtaining treatment for the potentially\nlethal disease, Wu said.\nAccording to CDC statistics, 3 children have died of the virus this\nyear [2005], one in February in Taichung County, and the other 2 last\nweek [2nd week May 2005] in Yunlin and Changhua counties.\nDeaths\n------\nAccording to the CDC, the 3 young children all died of [pnfection with]\nEnterovirus 71, which often presents like other enterovirus infections and\ncan have no symptoms, or the patient may show signs of hand, foot & mouth\ndisease, rashes, meningitis, encephalitis or some combination of these. But\nit may also come with unusual symptoms, such as hemorrhage and acute flaccid\nparalysis.\nEnterovirus 71, which hits Taiwan every summer, caused a large\noutbreak in Taiwan in 1998, with 78 deaths, and smaller outbreaks\nrecurred in 2000 and 2001.\nThere are still 29 children with severe Enterovirus infections, 3 in\nnorthern Taiwan, 18 in central Taiwan, 7 in southern Taiwan, and one\nin eastern Taiwan. 15 of the 29 cases are infected by EV71 virus.\nThe child who died in Chunghua was one year and 7 months old. He was\nfound infected on 16 May 2005 and died just 4 days later. After his\ndeath, his brother was also found infected with the same virus, CDC\nsaid, adding that his parents must not have thought their older child\nwas infected, and missed the opportunity to send their younger child\nto see the doctor before the disease became serious. 'Normally, the\n2nd child to be infected by the virus is more serious than the 1st\nchild in one family, as the magnitude of the virus will increase as\ntime goes by,' Wu said. Because of this, Wu added, if one child has\nbecome infected with the virus, the parents should be watchful for\nany possibility that it will be transmitted to other children.\nHealth officials say there is no known vaccine for the intestinal bug.\nEnterovirus 71 was 1st isolated in 1969 and has since been associated\nwith sporadic outbreaks in various parts of world, including the\nUSA, Brazil, Europe, Australia and Malaysia.\n[Byline: Shih Hsiu-chuan]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Taiwan is currently facing the annual outbreak season for hand, foot &\nmouth disease (HFMD). Viruses from the group called enteroviruses cause\nHFMD. The most common cause is coxsackievirus A16; sometimes, HFMD is caused\nby enterovirus 71 or other enteroviruses. The enterovirus group includes\npolioviruses, coxsackieviruses, echoviruses and other enteroviruses. HFMD\ncaused by coxsackievirus A16 infection is a mild disease, and nearly all\npatients recover without medical treatment in 7 to 10 days. Complications\nare uncommon. Rarely, the patient with coxsackievirus A16 infection may also\ndevelop 'aseptic' or viral meningitis, in which the person has fever,\nheadache, stiff neck, or back pain, and may need to be hospitalized for a\nfew days. Another cause of HFMD, EV71 virus may also produce viral\nmeningitis and, rarely, more serious diseases, such as encephalitis, or a\npoliomyelitis-like paralysis. EV71 encephalitis may be fatal. Cases of fatal\nencephalitis occurred during outbreaks of HFMD in Malaysia in 1997 and in\nTaiwan in 1998.\nHand, foot & mouth disease is usually characterized by tiny blisters\non the inside of the mouth and the palms of the hands, fingers, and\nsoles of the feet. Young children are primarily affected, but it may\nbe seen in adults. Most cases occur in the summer and early fall.\nOutbreaks may occur among groups of children, especially in child\ncare centers or nursery schools. Symptoms usually appear 3 to 5 days\nafter exposure.\nHand, foot & mouth disease is usually spread through person-to-person\ncontact. People can spread the disease when they are shedding the virus in\ntheir feces. It is also spread by the respiratory tract from mouth or\nrespiratory secretions (such as from saliva on hands or toys). The virus has\nalso been found in the fluid from the skin blisters. The infection is spread\nmost easily during the acute phase/stage of illness when people are feeling\nill, but the virus can be spread for several weeks after the onset of\ninfection.\nThe symptoms are much like a common cold with a rash The rash appears\nas blisters or ulcers in the mouth, on the inner cheeks, gums, sides\nof the tongue, and as bumps or blisters on the hands, feet, and\nsometimes other parts of the skin. The skin rash may last for 7 to 10\ndays.\nThere is no specific treatment for the virus that causes HFMD. Help prevent\nand control its spread by:\n- Washing hands well, especially after going to the bathroom,\nchanging diapers and/or handling diapers or other stool-soiled\nmaterial.\n- Covering the mouth and nose when coughing or sneezing.\n- Washing toys and other surfaces that have saliva on them.\n- Excluding children from child care or school settings if there is\na fever, or ulcers in the mouth and the child is drooling.\nFor reviews, please see refs: [Taiwan] CDC HFMD Fact sheet:\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dvrd/revb/enterovirus/hfhf.htm>;\nEpidemiology and Disease Control Program (EDCP) Fact sheet:\n<http://edcp.org/factsheets/handfoot.html>.\nWith annual timely public awareness campaigns by the Taiwan CDC and\nthe island-wide public health network, the frequency of reporting\noutbreaks of Enterovirus 71 or HFMD has been chronologically reduced.\nProMED welcomes further information from Taiwan health authorities. -\nMod.RY]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n After his\ndeath, his brother was also found infected with the same virus, CDC\nsaid, adding that his parents must not have thought their older child\nwas infected, and missed the opportunity to send their younger child\nto see the doctor before the disease became serious. In a small proportion of\ncases there may be severe neurological sequelae (For a description of a\nrecent fatal case in Macao, see 'Enterovirus 71 encephalitis, fatal - China\n(Macao) 20040415.1027'). One HFMD case was\nreported from Bandung, West Java province, and the other from Jakarta. So\nfar, there have been no deaths.\nHFMD is a common illness of infants and children. It is characterized by\nfever, sores in the mouth, and a rash with blisters. HFMD begins with a\nmild fever, poor appetite, malaise ('feeling sick'), and frequently a sore\nthroat. One or 2 days after the fever begins, painful sores develop in the\nmouth. They begin as small red spots that blister and then often become\nulcers. They are usually located on the tongue, gums, and inside of the\ncheeks. The skin rash develops over 1 to 2 days with flat or raised red\nspots, some with blisters. The rash does not itch, and it is usually\nlocated on the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. It may also appear\non the buttocks. A person with HFMD may have only the rash or the mouth ulcers.\nHFMD usually is not serious. HFMD caused by Coxsackievirus A16 infection is\na mild disease, and nearly all patients recover without medical treatment\nin 7 to 10 days. Complications are uncommon. Rarely, the patient with\ncoxsackievirus A16 infection may also develop 'aseptic' or viral\nmeningitis, in which the person has fever, headache, stiff neck, or back\npain, and may need to be hospitalized for a few days. Another cause of\nHFMD, enterovirus 71 (EV71) may also cause viral meningitis and, rarely,\nmore serious diseases, such as encephalitis, or a poliomyelitis-like\nparalysis. EV71 encephalitis may be fatal. Cases of fatal encephalitis\noccurred during outbreaks of HFMD in Malaysia in 1997 and in Taiwan in 1998.\nHFMD is moderately contagious. Infection is spread from person to person by\ndirect contact with nose and throat discharges, saliva, fluid from\nblisters, or the stool of infected persons. A person is most contagious\nduring the 1st week of the illness. HFMD is not transmitted to or from pets\nor other animals.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[These sporadic cases of hand, foot and mouth disease, though insignificant\nin number, may be the forerunners of a more serious epidemic, particularly\nif Enterovirus 71 proves to be the etiologic agent. Epidemics of HFMD in\nrecent years have tended to be more serious in East Asia than elsewhere in\nthe world. Information on the identity of the agent would have general\ninterest. - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n From: Alfonso Rodriguez <arodriguezm@SaludFMV.org>\nSource: Asean Disease Surveillance and Ministry Of Health, Indonesia, Thu\n27 May 2004 [edited]\n<http://www.asean-disease-surveillance.net/ASNNews_Detail.asp?ID=1518>\n\nIndonesia: Hand, Foot & Mouth Disease Cases Reported in Bandung and Jakarta\n Rarely, the patient with\ncoxsackievirus A16 infection may also develop 'aseptic' or viral\nmeningitis, in which the person has fever, headache, stiff neck, or back\npain, and may need to be hospitalized for a few days. No public announcement has been made about\nthe outbreak by the Department of Health, and officials only\nconfirmed the infections after questions were filed by the Sunday\nMorning Post last week.\nA department spokeswoman said 5 children from the kindergarten\nsection of the respected Yew Chung International School in Kowloon\nTong had contracted the disease. The children, all aged 4, have been\ntold to stay at home. None of the children, whose parents have been\ncontacted by the department, have developed complications. The\ndepartment spokeswoman said the parents of all the other children at\nthe school were notified on Thu 11 Mar 2004 -- at least 48 hours\nafter the first child fell ill.\nHealth officials did not say whether the school had acted properly in\nnotifying the parents. Teachers have expressed anger, claiming school\nmanagers delayed telling the parents about the outbreak. There were\nunconfirmed reports that as many as 10 children were infected during\nthe school's annual sports day last weekend.\nYew Chung's assistant director, Winnie Cheng, refused to confirm or\ndeny whether the school was aware that its pupils were infected as\nearly as 6 Mar 2004. 'There is no need to confirm or deny this,\nbecause I have no information on this aspect. We have very strict\nhygiene measures to sterilise the school compound. Our cleaners wipe\ndown the furniture, stationary and playground equipment on a daily\nbasis,' she said.\nHand, foot and mouth disease, which caused a public health scare when\nit spread across Asia 6 years ago, is a viral infection that can lead\nto flu-like symptoms in the early stages. Fever may persist for 4-5\ndays. A painless rash may also develop on the palms and soles and\nsometimes on the buttocks, and there may be a loss of appetite,\nespecially if painful mouth ulcers make it difficult for the patient\nto swallow.\nEnterovirus 71 (EV71) [the causative agent of hand, foot and mouth\ndisease] killed 100 people in Taiwan between 1998 and 2000. The\nDepartment of Health said, however, that there was no cause for alarm\nas [on this occasion] the effects of the disease were relatively mild.\nMedical sector legislator Lo Wing-lok yesterday urged the department\nto investigate Yew Chung's delay in informing other parents about the\ndisease. 'What the school clearly has on its hands now is an outbreak\nof hand, foot and mouth disease,' he said. 'Once a school has\nconfirmed that its students have contracted the disease, then they\nshould contact other parents as soon as possible so they will be\nalert, and this will minimise the risk of others contracting the\ndisease.' In 2003 there were 50 reported cases of EV71 infections in\nHong Kong, down from 477 in 2002.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Some time ago a ProMED-mail correspondent provided the following\ninformation, posted now because of its relevance to the preceding\nnews report.\nA paper entitled 'Enterovirus 71 outbreaks, Taiwan: occurrence and\nrecognition', by Lin TY, Twu SJ, Ho MS, Chang LY, Lee CY of the Chang\nGung University, Taoyuan, Taiwan, can be found in Emerg. Infect. Dis.\n2003 Mar;9(3):291-3. The abstract reads:\n'Enterovirus 71 (EV71) caused a large outbreak in Taiwan in 1998 with\n78 deaths, and smaller outbreaks recurred in 2000 and 2001. The\noutbreak was recognized because of a large number of hand, foot, and\nmouth disease cases and the rapid deaths of children with the\ndisease. Virologic and pathologic studies indicated that EV71 was the\nmost important agent related to severe and fatal cases and that a\nneurogenic inflammatory response was involved in the pathogenesis of\ncardiopulmonary collapse resulting from fulminant EV71 infection.\nSeroepidemiologic study suggested that EV71 had circulated for at\nleast 16 years and that the accumulation of susceptible hosts might\nhave triggered the 1998 outbreak. However, a change in EV71\nneurovirulence and host genetic susceptibility may also have affected\nthe clinical outcome. The Taiwan outbreak shows that worldwide\nattention should be paid to such outbreaks, new antiviral drugs\nshould be developed, and that vaccination of children under 5 years\nof age may be warranted.' - Mod.CP]", "summary": "A ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n Once a school has\nconfirmed that its students have contracted the disease, then they\nshould contact other parents as soon as possible so they will be\nalert, and this will minimise the risk of others contracting the\ndisease.' The\noutbreak was recognized because of a large number of hand, foot, and\nmouth disease cases and the rapid deaths of children with the\ndisease. Chiang Ying-lung, Deputy\nDirector-General of the Center for Disease Control, stated that the\nepidemic, which broke out earlier than last year and is creeping up slowly,\nwill reach its peak in a week.\nEnteroviruses infect the human gastrointestinal tract and often spread to\nother areas of the body, especially the nervous system. The mortality rate\namong children is high. So far 37 enteroviral cases have been identified\nthis year; 7 of the victims, all children, succumbed to the infectious disease.\nThe disease assumed epidemic proportions for the first time in Taiwan in\n1998, claiming 70 lives. The nation has since experienced an enterovirus\nepidemic each year. A Health\nDepartment spokesman said on Tue 18 Jun 2002 that they were first told of\nthe outbreak on Thu 13 Jun 2002 and the number of infected children at the\nschool in the New Territories had since doubled.\nThe children were treated but none have needed hospitalization. Authorities\nhave allowed the school in Tsuen Kwan O, a newly developed residential\ndistrict in Hong Kong's outlying territories, to remain open for the time\nbeing. 'It may not be necessary to shut the school since the disease may be\n[restricted] to kids belonging to a [single] class. We have told the school\nto advise parents to keep their children at home until they are fully well.'\nThis viral infection, which can be fatal, is spread through contact with\nnasal discharges, saliva, faeces and fluid from blisters, and contact with\nitems used by an infected individual. The incubation period for the disease\nis 3 to 7 days. Symptoms include fever, sore throat, runny nose, mouth\nulcers, a painless rash on the hands, feet or buttocks, vomiting and\ndiarrhea. Officials were checking whether the children were infected with\nthe potentially deadly virus species known as _Enterovirus 71_, which\nkilled 30 children in Malaysia in 1997 and more than 50 in Taiwan the\nfollowing year.\nEnterovirus 71 is one of several viruses that can cause hand, foot & mouth\ndisease, which is not usually life-threatening but sometimes causes\npotentially fatal inflammation of the heart muscles, spinal cord, or brain.\nSo far this year 4 people in Hong Kong have been infected with enterovirus\n71 but all have recovered, Lee said.
